TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]informatique génétique[COLOR_REVERT] permet d'entrainer des missiles [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]porteurs d'épidemie[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Dualism
TEXT.French: Dualisme
TEXT.Polish: Dualizm

TEXT.English: [TAB]Moral dualism is the belief of the coexistence (in eastern and naturalistic religions) or conflict (in western religions) between the "benevolent" and the "malignant". Most religious systems have some form of moral dualism - in western religions, for instance, a conflict between good and evil. [PARAGRAPH:2]Like ditheism/bitheism, moral dualism does not imply the absence of monist or monotheistic principles. Moral dualism simply implies that there are two moral opposites at work, independent of any interpretation of what might be "moral" and - unlike ditheism/bitheism - independent of how these may be represented. [PARAGRAPH:2]For example, Mazdaism (Mazdaen Zoroastrianism) is both dualistic and monotheistic (but not monist) since in that philosophy God—the Creator—is purely good, and the antithesis—which is also uncreated—is an absolute one. Zurvanism (Zurvanite Zoroastrianism), Manichaeism and Mandaeism, are representative of dualistic and monist philosophies since each has a supreme and transcendental First Principle from which the two equal-but-opposite entities then emanate. This is also true for the lesser-known Christian gnostic religions, such as Bogomils, Catharism, etc. More complex forms of monist dualism also exist, for instance in Hermeticism, where Nous "thought" - that is described to have created man - brings forth both good and evil, depending on whether it receives prompting from God or from the demons.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Poglád reprezentowany przez wiele religii, doktryn religijnych i herezji, dotyczácy natury i pochodzenia dobra i zôa istniejácego w äwiecie. Radykalny dualizm zakôada istnienie dwóch równorzêdnych siô "Dobra" i "Zôa", "Äwiatôa" i "Ciemnoäci", "Dobrego Boga" i "Zôego Boga", równorzêdnych i wspóôodwiecznych. Widzialny äwiat miaôby byâ efektem äcierania siê tych dwóch siô. Doktryny dualistyczne wiáëá materiê z pierwiastkiem "zôym", zaä element duchowy - z "dobrym". Äwiat materialny miaôby byâ stworzony przez "Zôego Boga", utoësamianego, w doktrynach dualistycznych zwiázanych z chrzeäcijañstwem, z Bogiem Starego Testamentu (stád odrzucajá one Stary Testament). Czôowiek miaô powstaâ w wyniku "uwiêzienia" elementu duchowego w materialnym ciele. Bierze siê z tego niechêâ wyznawców dualistycznych pogládów do materii i do prokreacji, jako przedôuëajácej "uwiêzienie" pierwiastka duchowego w materii.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Now the two primal Spirits, who reveal themselves in vision as Twins, are the Better and the Bad, in thought and word and action. Between these two the wise ones chose aright; the foolish not so." - Zoroaster (c.628 - c.551)
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Maintenant, les deux Esprits primaires, qui se révèlent dans la vision comme des jumeaux, sont le Bien et le Mal, en pensée, en parole et en action. Entre ces deux le sage choisi juste, le fou non." - Zoroaster (c.628 - c.551)
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Dobro i Zôo majá to samo oblicze, wszystko zaleëy jedynie od momentu, w którym staná na drodze czôowieka." - Paulo Coelho

TEXT.English: Early Metalworking

[BOLD]Copper Working[\BOLD], The Metal Age starts when human beings began to use metal to make tools. For archaeologists, the transition from the stone to the metal age occurs when these metal tools appear alongside stone tools. The type of metal used initially was probably influenced by the surface availability of the metal in natural form, and appears to have been either gold or copper, both being softer, lower melting point metals. A lower melting point was probably critical since the development of metallurgy closely paralleled the ability to produce hotter fires as well as the development of containers to hold and cast the melted metal. The use of gold may even have started with the mechanical shaping of the metal, first in cold form, then heated and softened, and finally melted and cast.
TEXT.Polish: [BOLD]Obróbka Miedzi[\BOLD], Epoka miedzi rozpoczela sie kiedy ludzie zaczeli uzywac metali do wyrobu narzedzi. Epoka miedzi to okres przejsciowy miedzy archeologicznymi epokami kamienia i brazu, w trakcie którego wsród ludów neolitycznych weszly do uzycia pierwsze wyroby z metalu, przede wszystkim z miedzi (narzedzia, bron, ozdoby), chociaz nadal w powszechnym uzyciu byly narzedzia wyrabiane z kamienia i krzemienia.

TEXT.English: "The brightest crowns that are worn in heaven have been tried, and smelted, and polished, and glorified through the furnace of tribulation." - Edwin Chapin
TEXT.French: "Les plus brillantes couronnes qui sont portés au paradis ont été essayées, fondues, polies, glorifiées à travers la fournaise de la tribulation." - Edwin Chapin
TEXT.Polish: "Gdyby nie bylo szóstego dnia, nie byloby i czlowieka, miedz pozostalaby na zawsze tylko miedzia, a olów olowiem." - Paulo Coelho

TEXT.English: The use of copper required the development of metallurgy - the science of extracting metal from metal ores - and casting the molten metal in castings.
TEXT.French: L'utilisation du cuivre a nécessité le développement de la métallurgie - la science de l'extraction du métal à partir de minerais métalliques - et la coulée du métal en fusion dans les pièces moulées.
TEXT.Spanish: El uso del cobre necesitó del desarrollo de la metalurgia: la ciencia de la extracción del metal a partir de minerales, para luego fundir el metal líquido en fundiciones.
TEXT.Polish: Odslania na mapie Miedz. Odblokowuje [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Ambasade Asyryjska[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Kopalnie Miedzi[COLOR_REVERT] i [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Kopalnie Cynku[COLOR_REVERT]. Pozwala wyszkolic wiele jednostek oszczepniczych i wlóczniczych.

TEXT.English: Ecological Engineering
TEXT.French: Ingénierie écologique
TEXT.Polish: Inëynieria Ekologiczna

TEXT.English: [TAB]Ecological Engineering is an emerging field of study integrating ecology and engineering, concerned with the design, monitoring and construction of ecosystems. The design of sustainable ecosystems intent to integrate human society with its natural environment for the benefit of both.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Inëynieria ekologiczna to teoretyczna i stosowana wiedza z wielu dziedzin nauki i techniki. Stanowi podstawê racjonalnego uëytkowania i ochrony ärodowiska przyrodniczego oraz naturalnych i antropogenicznych zasobów. Sôuëy ona ekologicznemu rozwojowi cywilizacji.Inëynieria ekologiczna chroni, dostosowuje i tworzy warunki niezbêdne do ëycia czôowieka, roälin i zwierzát. Gôównym celem inëynierii ekologicznej jest tworzenie podstaw i systemów racjonalnego uëytkowa.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Ecological Engineering is a tool in sustainable management of our resources using resource management principles of the ecosystems" - Jana, Banergee, Guterstam and Heeb
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Le Génie écologique est un outil de gestion durable de nos ressources en utilisant les principes de gestion des ressources des écosystèmes" - Jana, Banergee, Guterstam and Heeb
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Ekologia i ochrona ärodowiska to (…) nie tylko wielki przemysô, kopalnie i huty. To takëe Twoje i moje codzienne gesty, to Twoja i moja kuchnia, ôazienka, garaë, ogród. To wybór przez Ciebie i przeze mnie ärodków komunikacji, sposobu spêdzania wolnego czasu i taka ochrona ärodowiska zaczyna siê najbliëej: najbliëej w tym pokoju, mieszkaniu, domu." - Eryk Mistewicz

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Ecological Engineering[COLOR_REVERT] allows your Workers to build [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Geothermal Factory[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Windtrap[COLOR_REVERT]. It also allows the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Paradise[COLOR_REVERT] civic and allows you to construct [COLOR_PROJECT_TEXT]SS Life Support[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Electronics
TEXT.French: Électronique
TEXT.Polish: Elektronika

TEXT.English: [TAB]The field of electronics deals with the practical application and manipulation of electricity and electromagnetic phenomena. The invention of the vacuum tube in the early 20th century marked the beginning of modern electronics. The vacuum tube was capable of amplifying weak radio signals, allowing them to be transmitted over greater distances. Vacuum tubes also allowed music and voice to be superimposed onto radio waves for transmission. The early study of electronics revolutionized a number of fields, especially the field of communications. Because of the vacuum tube, the technology of radio communications was highly developed by World War II. After the war, electronics research continued to advance rapidly. Post-war advances include the earliest examples of digital computers and, eventually, transistors and integrated circuits: miniaturized replacements for the vacuum tube.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Elektronika – dziedzina techniki i nauki zajmujácá siê wytwarzaniem i przetwarzaniem sygnaôów w postaci prádów i napiêâ elektrycznych lub pól elektromagnetycznych.Do realizacji tych celów sôuëá róënorodne przyrzády i ukôady: elementy aktywne: póôprzewodnikowe (tranzystory, tyrystory, ukôady scalone itp.), lampy próëniowe (diody, triody, pentody itd.) elementy bierne: rezystory, kondensatory, cewki, diody póôprzewodnikowe itp. elementy akustoelektroniczne: filtry, rezonatory, linie opóéniajáce, czujniki itp. elementy optoelektroniczne: lasery, äwiatôowody, detektory promieniowania itp. elementy fotoniczne (ôáczáce elementy akustoelektroniczne z optoelektronicznymi): modulatory, wzmacniacze, detektory itp. Historycznie elektronika wyrosôa z radiotechniki – pierwszymi ukôadami elektronicznymi byôy powstajáce w czasach I wojny äwiatowej nadajniki i odbiorniki radiowe. Jest nauká interdyscyplinarná skupiajácá w sobie przede wszystkim wiedzê elektrotechniki i elektrochemii, ale równieë informatyki, telekomunikacji itp.Obecnie elektronika ze wzglêdu na zapotrzebowanie z róënych dziedzin ëycia zawiera w sobie jeszcze wiêcej kierunków. Do najwaëniejszych oprócz radiotechniki naleëá teë optoelektronika, telekomunikacja, elektronika cyfrowa, mikroelektronika, lasery. Swój rozwój elektronika zawdziêcza badaniom w róënych dziedzinach nauki, gôównie fizyce (póôprzewodniki, optyka, magnetyzm), chemii i matematyce (symulowanie ukôadów, analiza zachowania, przetwarzanie sygnaôów, analiza stabilnoäci i inne).

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Our rockets can find Halley's comet, and fly to Venus with amazing accuracy, but side by side with these scientific and technical triumphs is an obvious lack of efficiency in using scientific achievements for economic needs, and many Soviet household appliances are of poor quality" - Mikhail Gorbachev

TEXT.English: Elephant Riding
TEXT.French: Dressage d'éléphants
TEXT.Polish: Udomowienie Sôoni

TEXT.English: [TAB]Elephants are regarded as among the most intelligent of mammals and can be trained to work and to perform. Indian elephants are extensively used as beasts of burden, especially in teak forests, where they carry logs with their trunks. They are not considered truly domesticated, as they do not breed well in captivity; young animals are captured from the wild. Training and handling take skill, as elephants have complex emotions and vary individually in temperament. African elephants are often said to be less tractable, but they too were formerly used for work, as well as for warfare. Hannibal's army crossed the Alps using 37 African elephants, which were at that time probably found in the Atlas Mts. Elephants seen in zoos and circuses are usually of the Indian species, although the famous Jumbo, who toured the United States in the late 19th century giving rides to children, was an African elephant. In Thailand and Myanmar (Burma), albino elephants have long been held sacred. Elephants have been extensively hunted for food and for ivory, and their numbers are now greatly reduced; however, they are now afforded protection in certain areas which is helping to prevent the destruction of their numbers.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Sôoñ afrykañski (Loxodonta africana) to gatunek ssaka z rodziny sôoniowatych, najwiêkszy ze wspóôczeänie ëyjácych gatunków ssaków ládowych. Wczeäniej uznawany jako jeden gatunek wraz z afrykañskim sôoniem leänym (Loxodonta cyclotis). Zwierzê stadne, zamieszkuje afrykañská sawannê, lasy i stepy od poôudniowych krañców Sahary po Namibiê, póônocná Botswanê i póônocná czêäâ Afryki. W staroëytnoäci wykorzystywane jako zwierzêta bojowe.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"The Indian Elephant is said sometimes to weep." - Charles Darwin
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"On dit que l'éléphant indien parfois verse des larmes." - Charles Darwin
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Mówi siê, ëe czasami Sôoñ indyjski pôacze." - Charles Darwin

TEXT.English: Environmental Economics
TEXT.Polish: Ekonomia Ekologiczna

TEXT.English: [TAB]Environmental economics is a subfield of economics concerned with environmental issues. Central to environmental economics is the concept of an externality. This means that some effects of an activity are not taken into account in its price.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Ekonomia ekologiczna jest nauká analizujácá i opisujácá procesy gospodarcze, spoôeczne i ekologiczne bêdáce podstawá realizacji zrównowaëonego rozwoju ( en: sustainable development). Ekonomia ekologiczna odwoôuje siê do ekologicznego paradygmatu ekonomii i stoi w opozycji do ekonomii ärodowiska i zasobów naturalnych opierajácej siê na paradygmacie ekonomizacji ärodowiska.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"The blunt truth about the politics of climate change is that no country will want to sacrifice its economy in order to meet this challenge, but all economies know that the only sensible long term way of developing is to do it on a sustainable basis." - Tony Blair
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"La vérité brute sur la politique du changement climatique est qu'aucun pays ne veut pas sacrifier son économie afin de répondre à ce défi, mais toutes les économies savent que la seule façon sensée à long terme de se développer est de le faire sur une base durable." - Tony Blair
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Ekonomia nie moëe byâ wyrzucona do klas szkolnych i biur statystycznych, nie moëe byâ nauká ezoteryczná. Jest to filozofia ludzkiego ëycia i ludzkiej aktywnoäci, odnosi siê ona do kaëdego i do wszystkiego." - Ludwig von Mises

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Environmental Economics[COLOR_REVERT] allows workers to build [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Treefarms[COLOR_REVERT] and improves the output of [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Lumbermill[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Watermill[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]économie environnementale[COLOR_REVERT] permet aux ouvriers de construire des [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]fermes arboricole[COLOR_REVERT] et augmente la production des [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]moulins à vent[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]moulins à eau[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Explosives
TEXT.French: Explosifs
TEXT.Polish: Materiaôy Wybuchowe

TEXT.English: [TAB]An explosive is a chemical compound or mixture that undergoes rapid combustion and produces heat, gas, and pressure effects. The earliest explosive compound known was gunpowder, which was first used in Europe in the 13th century, and was the only explosive known for hundreds of years. The first modern explosive, a compound known as nitroglycerin, was discovered in 1846. Compounds similar to nitroglycerin are the most commonly used explosives today. Explosives vary in brisance, or shattering effect, and in their stability under various environmental conditions. Aside from their obvious use in weaponry, explosives are also used in such peaceful applications as rocket propellants and for mining and demolition work. [PARAGRAPH:2]From gunpowder to the modern forms of nitroglycerine and nitrocellulose, the energy that is released comes from the conversion of nitrogen containing compounds to nitrogen gas. In gunpowder, this present in the [potassium nitrate] that is used, and in nitroglycerine this is present in [nitroso] groups that are present. Although these compounds release a large amount of energy, to start the reaction, often an initiator is required, something that is far more unstable, but by itself does not contain enough energy in a small enough space. One example of a compound that is sometimes used is [Potassium Iodate].
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Materiaô wybuchowy to pojedynczy zwiázek chemiczny lub mieszanina kilku zwiázków chemicznych, która jest zdolna w odpowiednich warunkach do gwaôtownej reakcji chemicznej o charakterze egzotermicznym, której towarzyszy wydzielenie wielkiej iloäci produktów gazowych w postaci wybuchu (detonacji lub deflagracji). Prawdopodobnie pierwszym materiaôem wybuchowym byô wynaleziony w Chinach proch czarny. Inicjacja reakcji, której ulega materiaô wybuchowy, wymaga bodéców zewnêtrznych. Mogá one byâ rozmaite w zaleënoäci od charakteru materiaôu wybuchowego. Moëe to byâ np.: dziaôanie mechaniczne (wybuch innego materiaôu, uderzenie, potarcie, a czasem nawet lekki dotyk), ogrzanie, dopôyw äwiatôa lub prádu elektrycznego, czy teë kontakt z inná substancjá chemiczná.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Kaboom?! Yes, Ricco kaboom!" - The Madagascar Penguins
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Kaboom?! Oui, Ricco kaboom!" - The Madagascar Penguins
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Próbowaliäcie mnie zabiâ na wszelkie sposoby, a ja wciáë ëyjê. Wybuch urwaô mi tylko kilka rák, ale to pestka. Teraz mam ich caôe mnóstwo! Wielkie rêce. Piêkne rêce. Mam ich na kopy." - fragment filmu "Szklanká po ôapkach"

TEXT.English: Fermentation
TEXT.Polish: Fermentacja

TEXT.English: [TAB]Fermentation in food processing typically refers to the conversion of sugar to alcohol using yeast, bacteria, or a combination thereof, under anaerobic conditions. A more general definition of fermentation is the chemical conversion of carbohydrates into alcohols or acids.[PARAGRAPH:2]Human beings are known to have made fermented foods since Neolithic times. The earliest types were beer, wine, and leavened bread (made primarily by yeasts) and cheeses (made by bacteria and molds). These were soon followed by East Asian fermented foods, yogurt and other fermented milk products, pickles, sauerkraut, vinegar (soured wine), butter, and a host of traditional alcoholic beverages. More recently molds have been used in industrial fermentation to make vitamins B-2 (riboflavin) and B-12, textured protein products (from Fusarium and Rhizopus in Europe) antibiotics (such as penicillin), citric acid, and gluconic acid. Bacteria are now used to make the amino acids lysine and glutamic acid. Single-celled protein foods such as nutritional yeast and microalgae (spirulina, chlorella) are also made in modern industrial fermentations.[PARAGRAPH:2]For early societies, the transformation of basic food materials into fermented foods was a mystery and a miracle, for they had no idea what caused the usually sudden, dramatic, and welcomed transformation. Some societies attributed this to divine intervention; the Egyptians praised Osiris for the brewing of beer and the Greeks established Bacchus as the god of wine. Likewise, at many early Japanese miso and shoyu breweries, a small shrine occupied a central place and was bowed to daily.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Fermentacja – to proces beztlenowych przemian enzymatycznych zwiázków chemicznych (przede wszystkim zawierajácych grupê hydroksylowá) której efektem jest uzyskanie energii, najczêäciej pod postaciá ATP. Proces umoëliwia uzyskanie energii uëytecznej metabolicznie – ATP – w warunkach beztlenowych organizmom stale lub okresowo ëyjácym w warunkach beztlenowych. Fermentacje przeprowadzane sá przez liczne drobnoustroje lub wytworzone przez nie enzymy.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Beer... Now there's a temporary solution." -Homer Simpson
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Bière... Maintenant, il y a une solution temporaire." -Homer Simpson
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Zapominacie, ëe owoce naleëá do wszystkich, a ziemia - nie naleëy do nikogo." - Jan Jakub Rousseau

TEXT.English: Flintlock
TEXT.French: Silex
TEXT.Polish: Zamek Skaôkowy

TEXT.English: [TAB]Flintlock is the general term for any firearm based on the flintlock mechanism. Introduced about 1630, the flintlock rapidly replaced earlier firearm-ignition technologies, such as the matchlock and wheellock mechanisms. It continued to be in common use for over two centuries, replaced by percussion cap and, later, cartridge-based systems in the early-to-mid 19th century. The Model 1840 U.S. musket was the last flintlock firearm produced for the U.S. military although there is some evidence that obsolete flintlocks were still seeing action in the earliest days of the American Civil War. In fact, during the first year of the war, the Army of Tennessee (Confederacy) had over 2,000 flintlock muskets in service. While technologically obsolete, flintlock firearms have enjoyed a renaissance among black powder shooting enthusiasts and many fine flintlock rifles and pistols are still being made today.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Zamek skaôkowy to zamek rêcznej broni palnej odprzodowej, potocznie nazywanej flintá, od ang. flint - krzemieñ, w którym zapalenie prochu na panewce nastêpuje od iskier powstaôych przy uderzeniu skaôki (krzemienia) zamocowanej w szczêkach kurka o krzesiwo (pôytkê metalowá) przymocowane z prawej strony broni. Po naciäniêciu spustu broni,kurek ze skaôká opadaô na krzesiwo. Iskry padaôy na panewkê z prochem zapalajác go. Pôomieñ z panewki poprzez otwór zapaôowy z boku lufy dostawaô siê do komory powodujác zapôon ôadunku prochowego. Zamek skaôkowy wynaleziony zostaô ok. 1570 roku, a rozpowszechniô siê na poczátku XVII w, wypierajác wczeäniej stosowane zamki lontowe i koôowe. Zastápienie pirytu stosowanego w zamku koôowym krzemieniem pozwoliôo na uproszczenie i potanienie konstrukcji, a przy tym znaczne uproszczenie obsôugi broni. Zamek skaôkowy stosowany byô powszechnie od XVII do poôowy XIX wieku (do koñca broni odprzodowej), zastápiono go przez zamek kapiszonowy, nastêpnie przez broñ odtylcowá.

TEXT.English: Free Artistry
TEXT.French: Talent artistique
TEXT.Polish: Wolnoäâ Twórczoäci

TEXT.English: [TAB]The love of beauty seems a trait mankind was innately born with. When attempting to create things of beauty, and when done so skillfully, the product is art. From our ancient cave dwelling ancestors to our electronically amplified contemporaries, painting, sculpture and music have all played a pivotal role in the quality of human life. A division can be made between the fine arts and the useful arts (such as pottery making or weaving), though the process through which the artists labor remains similar. Today commercial art is increasingly demanding to be considered a serious art, and in many cases with good reason.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Sztuka – dziedzina dziaôalnoäci ludzkiej, uprawiana przez artystów. Nie istnieje jedna spójna, ogólnie przyjêta definicja sztuki, gdyë jej granice sá redefiniowane w sposób ciágôy, w kaëdej chwili moëe pojawiâ siê dzieôo, które w arbitralnie przyjêtej, domkniêtej definicji siê nie mieäci[1]. Sztuka speônia rozmaite funkcje, m.in. estetyczne, spoôeczne, dydaktyczne, terapeutyczne, jednak nie stanowiá one o jej istocie[2].

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"A great book provides escapism for me. The artistry and the creativity in a story are better than any drugs." - Wentworth Miller
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Un grand livre me permet de m'évader. L'art et la créativité dans une histoire sont meilleures que toutes les drogues." - Wentworth Miller
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Dyscyplina sztuki wymaga wolnoäci." - Stanisôaw Jerzy Lec

Bach[COLOR_REVERT] (merveille mondiale).

TEXT.English: Fuel Cells
TEXT.French: Piles à combustible
TEXT.Polish: Ogniwa Paliwowe

TEXT.English: [TAB]A fuel cell is an electrochemical energy conversion device. It produces electricity from various external quantities of fuel (on the anode side) and an oxidant (on the cathode side). These react in the presence of an electrolyte. Generally, the reactants flow in and reaction products flow out while the electrolyte remains in the cell. Fuel cells can operate virtually continuously as long as the necessary flows are maintained. [PARAGRAPH:2]Fuel cells are different from batteries in that they consume reactant, which must be replenished, whereas batteries store electrical energy chemically in a closed system. Additionally, while the electrodes within a battery react and change as a battery is charged or discharged, a fuel cell's electrodes are catalytic and relatively stable. Many combinations of fuel and oxidant are possible. A hydrogen cell uses hydrogen as fuel and oxygen as oxidant. Other fuels include hydrocarbons and alcohols. Other oxidants include air, chlorine and chlorine dioxide.[PARAGRAPH:2]The principle of the fuel cell was discovered by German scientist Christian Friedrich Schönbein in 1838 and published in the January 1839 edition of the "Philosophical Magazine". Based on this work, the first fuel cell was developed by Welsh scientist Sir William Robert Grove in 1843. The fuel cell he made used similar materials to today's phosphoric-acid fuel cell. In 1955, W. Thomas Grubb, a chemist working for the General Electric Company (GE), further modified the original fuel cell design by using a sulphonated polystyrene ion-exchange membrane as the electrolyte. Three years later another GE chemist, Leonard Niedrach, devised a way of depositing platinum onto the membrane, which served as catalyst for the necessary hydrogen oxidation and oxygen reduction reactions. This became known as the 'Grubb-Niedrach fuel cell'. GE went on to develop this technology with NASA and McDonnell Aircraft, leading to its use during Project Gemini. This was the first commercial use of a fuel cell. It wasn't until 1959 that British engineer Francis Thomas Bacon successfully developed a 5 kW stationary fuel cell. In 1959, a team led by Harry Ihrig built a 15 kW fuel cell tractor for Allis-Chalmers which was demonstrated across the US at state fairs. This system used potassium hydroxide as the electrolyte and compressed hydrogen and oxygen as the reactants. Later in 1959, Bacon and his colleagues demonstrated a practical five-kilowatt unit capable of powering a welding machine. In the 1960s, Pratt and Whitney licensed Bacon's U.S. patents for use in the U.S. space program to supply electricity and drinking water (hydrogen and oxygen being readily available from the spacecraft tanks).
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Ogniwo paliwowe to ogniwo generujáce energiê elektryczná z reakcji utleniania stale dostarczanego do niego z zewnátrz paliwa. W odróënieniu od ogniw galwanicznych (akumulatory, baterie) w których energia wytwarzanego prádu musi zostaâ wczeäniej zgromadzona wewnátrz tych urzádzeñ (co znacznie ogranicza czas ich pracy) ogniwa paliwowe nie muszá byâ wczeäniej ôadowane. Wystarczy tylko doprowadziâ do nich paliwo. W przypadku ogniw galwanicznych ôadowanie moëe byâ procesem trwajácym wiele godzin, a ogniwa paliwowe sá gotowe do pracy po niewielkim czasie wymaganym do nagrzania. Ogromná zaletá ogniw wodorowych jest bardzo niewielkie zanieczyszczenie powietrza, które one powodujá. Powstajáce w nich spaliny skôadajá siê wyôácznie z obojêtnej dla ärodowiska pary wodnej. Silniki spalinowe oprócz pary wodnej wytwarzajá teë dwutlenek wêgla, czad, ozon, tlenki azotu oraz szereg innych toksycznych substancji. Zastosowanie ogniw paliwowych w samochodach moëe uchroniâ miasta przed smogiem i zmniejszyâ rozmiary efektu cieplarnianego. Wiêkszoäâ ogniw paliwowych do produkcji energii elektrycznej wykorzystuje wodór na anodzie oraz tlen na katodzie. Sá to ogniwa wodorowe. Proces produkcji energii nie zmienia chemicznej natury elektrod oraz wykorzystywanych elektrolitów. W ogniwach galwanicznych wytwarzanie prádu opiera siê na szeregu reakcji chemicznych, które doprowadzajá do zmiany skôadu elektrolitów lub elektrod. Aby odwróciâ ten proces konieczne jest dôugotrwaôe ôadowanie.

TEXT.English: Gene Manipulation
TEXT.French: Manipulation des gènes
TEXT.Polish: Manipulacje Genami

TEXT.English: [TAB]Genetic engineering, recombinant DNA technology, genetic modification/manipulation (GM) and gene splicing are terms that are applied to the direct manipulation of an organism's genes. Genetic modification of an organism can be achieved through a number of methods, most notably traditional breeding and recombinant technologies. The goal of both is the same, introduction of DNA (in the form of a gene) which in turn finds expression as favorable physical characteristics. Transgenic endeavors have found success in improving crop technology, the manufacture of human insulin through the use of modified bacteria, the manufacture of erythropoietin in Chinese hamster ovary cells, and the production of new types of experimental mice such as the OncoMouse (cancer mouse) for research. -- Wikipedia
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Inëynieria genetyczna – ingerencja w materiaô genetyczny organizmów, w celu zmiany ich wôaäciwoäci dziedzicznych. Polega ona na wprowadzaniu do komórek organizmu, którego cechy chcemy zmieniâ (biorcy), okreälonego odcinka DNA innego organizmu (dawcy). Odpowiednie fragmenty DNA wycina siê z DNA dawcy za pomocá enzymów restrykcyjnych. Nastêpnie tak wydzielone fragmenty DNA wprowadza siê do komórek biorcy za pomocá specjalnych przenoäników (wektorów). W tej roli wykorzystywane sá m.in. wirusy, plazmidy, kosmidy. Wprowadzone do komórki biorcy wraz z przyôáczonym fragmentem DNA dawcy umoëliwiajá namnaëanie siê w niej genów zawartych w tym DNA. Metody inëynierii genetycznej sá juë wykorzystywane do produkcji wielu lekarstw, np. insuliny, niektórych witamin i in. Ma to ogromne znaczenie praktyczne. Dawniej, przed opracowaniem metody biosyntezy insuliny metodami inëynierii genetycznej, otrzymywano já z trzustek zwierzêcych. Byôa to metoda bardzo droga, gdyë iloäâ insuliny otrzymana z jednej trzustki byôa niewielka, a proces jej wydzielania kosztowny. Inëynieria genetyczna wykorzystywana jest równieë do wytwarzania tzw. organizmów transgenicznych. Ma równieë duëe znaczenie w rozwoju genetyki. Umoëliwia bowiem poznanie funkcji peônionych przez okreälone geny.

TEXT.English: Glass Blowing
TEXT.French: Soufflage du verre
TEXT.Polish: Dmuchanie Szkôa

TEXT.English: [TAB]Glassblowing is a glassforming technique that involves inflating the molten glass into a glass blob with the aid of the blowpipe, or blow tube. A person who blows glass is called a glassblower, glassmith, or gaffer. [PARAGRAPH:2]As a novel glass forming technique created in the middle of the first century B.C., glassblowing exploited a working property of glass which was previously unknown to the glassworkers – inflation. Inflation refers to the expansion of a molten blob of glass by introducing a small amount of air to it. This property is based on the liquid structure of glass where the atoms are held together by strong chemical bonds in a disordered and random network, therefore molten glass is viscous enough to be blown and gradually hardens as it loses heat. n order to increase the stiffness of the molten glass, which in turn facilitates the process of blowing, there is a subtle change in the composition of glass. With reference to their studies of the ancient glass assemblages from Sepphoris of Israel, Fischer and McCray postulated that the concentration of natron, which acts as flux in glass, is slightly lower in blown vessels than those manufactured by casting. Lower concentration of natron would have allowed the glass to be stiffer for blowing. A full range of glassblowing techniques was developed within decades of its invention.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Przemysô szklarski – dziaô przemysôu zajmujácy siê produkcjá szkôa uëytkowego (dekoracyjnego, laboratoryjnego), szkôa pôaskiego, materiaôów budowlanych ze szkôa i opakowañ szklanych. Zaliczany jest do gaôêzi przemysôu mineralnego lub chemicznego.

TEXT.English: Globalization
TEXT.French: Mondialisation
TEXT.Polish: Globalizacja

TEXT.English: [TAB]Globalizataion can be found in five different areas economic, cultural, political, religious, and social systems. It should not be narrowly confused with economic globalization, which is only one aspect. While some scholars and observers of globalization stress convergence of patterns of production and consumption and a resulting homogenization of culture, others stress that globalization has the potential to take many diverse forms. In economics, globalization is the convergence of prices, products, wages, rates of interest and profits towards developed country norms. Globalization of the economy depends on the role of human migration, international trade, movement of capital, and integration of financial markets. The International Monetary Fund notes the growing economic interdependence of countries worldwide through increasing volume and variety of cross-border transactions, free international capital flows, and more rapid and widespread diffusion of technology. Theodore Levitt is usually credited with globalization's first use in an economic context. -- Wikipedia
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Globalizacja jest pojêciem uëywanym do opisywania zmian w spoôeczeñstwach i gospodarce äwiatowej, które wynikajá z gwaôtownego wzrostu miêdzynarodowej wymiany handlowej i kulturowej. Opisuje zwiêkszenie wymiany informacyjnej, przyspieszenie i spadek cen transportu, a takëe wzrost handlu miêdzynarodowego oraz inwestycji zagranicznych spowodowanych znoszeniem barier oraz rosnácych wspóôzaleënoäci miêdzy pañstwami. W ekonomii termin ten oznacza gôównie zjawiska zwiázane z liberalizacjá wymiany handlowej lub “wolnym handlem”. W szerszym znaczeniu odnosi siê do rosnácej integracji i wspóôzaleënoäci miêdzy jednostkami dziaôajácymi globalnie na platformie spoôecznej, politycznej czy ekonomicznej.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"It has been said that arguing against globalization is like arguing against the laws of gravity." - Kofi Annan

TEXT.English: Grand War
TEXT.Polish: Wielka Wojna

TEXT.English: [TAB]The French Revolution and the Napoleonic Wars that followed revolutionized military strategy. The impact of this period was still to be felt in the American Civil War and the early phases of World War I. [PARAGRAPH:2]With the advent of cheap small arms and the rise of the drafted citizen soldier, armies grew rapidly in size to become massed formations. This necessitated dividing the army first into divisions and later into corps. Along with divisions came divisional artillery; light-weight, mobile cannon with great range and firepower. The rigid formations of pikemen and musketeers firing massed volleys gave way to light infantry fighting in skirmish lines. [PARAGRAPH:2]Napoleon I of France took advantage of these developments to pursue a brutally effective "strategy of annihilation" (see scorched earth) that terrorized the populace and cared little for the mathematical perfection of the geometric strategy. Napoleon invariably sought to achieve decision in battle, with the sole aim of utterly destroying his opponent, usually achieving success through superior manoeuvre. As ruler and general he dealt with the grand strategy as well as the operational strategy, making use of political and economic measures. [PARAGRAPH:2]While not the originator of the methods he used, Napoleon very effectively combined the relatively superior maneuver and battle stages into one event. Before this, General Officers had considered this approach to battle as separate events. However, Napoleon used the maneuver to battle to dictate how and where the battle would progress. The Battle of Austerlitz was a perfect example of this maneuver. Napoleon withdrew from a strong position to draw his opponent forward and tempt him into a flank attack, weakening his center. This allowed the French army to split the allied army and gain victory.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Za jej symboliczny poczátek uwaëa siê zdobycie przez lud Paryëa twierdzy Bastylia 14 lipca 1789 roku[1]. Natomiast za koniec rewolucji uznaje siê kres rzádów Dyrektoriatu 9 listopada (18 brumaire'a) 1799 roku[2], kiedy to Napoleon Bonaparte przeprowadziô zamach stanu ogôaszajác siê dzieñ póéniej Pierwszym Konsulem. Zdaniem legitymistów o koñcu rewolucji moëna mówiâ dopiero w momencie Restauracji Burbonów w 1814 r. Mimo to równieë w okresie Restauracji politycy zwani ultrasami krytykowali króla Ludwika XVIII za akceptacjê parlamentaryzmu i odrzucenie moëliwoäci powrotu do "ancien régime'u"[3].

TEXT.English: Guerrilla Warfare
TEXT.French: Guerre de guérilla
TEXT.Polish: Partyzantka

TEXT.English: [TAB]Guerrilla warfare [(Span., "little war")], fighting by groups of irregular troops (guerrillas) within areas occupied by the enemy. When guerrillas obey the laws of conventional warfare they are entitled, if captured, to be treated as ordinary prisoners of war; however, they are often executed by their captors. The tactics of guerrilla warfare stress deception and ambush, as opposed to mass confrontation, and succeed best in an irregular, rugged, terrain and with a sympathetic populace, whom guerrillas often seek to win over by propaganda, reform, and terrorism. Guerrilla warfare has played a significant role in modern history, especially when waged by Communist liberation movements in Southeast Asia and elsewhere, as well as during WW2, where the Germans were constantly beset with losses by fighters behind their lines. [PARAGRAPH:2]In extreme situations, usually spawned by an oppressive or militaristic system of government, small groups of citizens have been known to form armed factions. In many cases, these splinter groups lack the numbers, finances and armament to start a full-scale revolution. Instead, they adopt a practice of undermining governmental authority through covert military operations. These operations usually take the form of hit-and-run raids, where rebel soldiers launch a surprise attack on an enemy target, then disappear into hiding, only to strike again at some other time and place. Such tactics, known as guerrilla warfare, seldom have any lasting effect individually. However, over many years, guerrilla factions can become a serious threat to governmental authority if the rebels cannot be caught and suppressed. Tactics of this sort were used to great effect by the partisan forces in Nazi-occupied Europe during World War II, and due to their radio links to Great Britain were able to orchestrate the damage that was done.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Forma walki zbrojnej jednej ze stron, polegajáca na dziaôaniach nieregularnych, odwrotach, przemarszach i innych formach walki, przy poparciu ludnoäci przeciwko okupantowi lub rodzimym rzádom. Jest to równieë wojna, w której sá atakowane maôe oddziaôy wroga. Dziaôania partyzantki to szybkie ataki nêkajáce, przeprowadza siê je z ukrycia, z przygotowaniem zasadzek.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"In guerrilla warfare they taught us to use our weaknesses as strengths." -Edward "Brill" Lyle "Enemy of the State"
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Dans la guérilla, ils nous ont appris à utiliser nos faiblesses comme des forces." -Edward "Brill" Lyle "Enemy of the State"
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"W wojnie partyzanckiej, oni nauczyli nas uëycia naszych sôaboäci jako naszej siôy." -Edward "Brill" Lyle "Enemy of the State"

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Guerrilla Warfare[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to train [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Artillery[COLOR_REVERT] and enables [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Ambush[COLOR_REVERT] promotions.
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]guerres des guérillas[COLOR_REVERT] permettent de fabriquer de l'[COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]artillerie[COLOR_REVERT] et activent la promotion [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]ambuscade[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Guided Weapons
TEXT.French: Armes téléguidées
TEXT.Polish: Broñ Samonaprowadzajáca

TEXT.English: [TAB]Precision-guided munitions (PGMs, smart munitions, smart bombs, guided bomb units or GBUs) are guided weapons intended to maximize damage to the target while minimizing civilian damage. Because the damage effects of an explosive weapon fall off with distance according to a power law, even modest improvements in accuracy (and hence reduction in miss distance) enable a target to be effectively attacked with fewer or smaller bombs. Thus, even if some bombs miss, fewer air crews are put at risk and the harm to civilians is somewhat reduced. The creation of precision-guided munitions resulted in the renaming of older bombs as "gravity bombs", "dumb bombs" or "iron bombs".
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Bomba kierowana (ang. Guided Bomb Unit) – bomba lotnicza wyposaëona w stery i system kierowania, dziêki czemu moëliwa jest zmiana toru lotu i precyzyjne naprowadzenie na cel. Bomba kierowana moëe byâ naprowadzana telewizyjnie, termowizyjnie, laserowo, inercyjnie, lub przy pomocy systemu GPS. Bomby kierowane czasami wyposaëane sá w stateczniki o duëej rozpiêtoäci lub rozkôadane skrzydôa, co zwiêksza ich zasiêg.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"We have guided missiles and misguided men." - Martin Luther King, Jr.
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Nous avons des missiles guidés et des hommes égarés." - Martin Luther King, Jr.
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Ludzie byli dawniej bliësi sobie. Musieli. Broñ nie niosôa daleko." - Stanisôaw Jerzy Lec

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Guided Weapons[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to train many modern units, including the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Mobile SAM[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Missile Cruiser[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Missile Submarine[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Strike Fighter[COLOR_REVERT], and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Guided Missile[COLOR_REVERT]. It also enables the [COLOR_PROJECT_TEXT]AA Missile Defense[COLOR_REVERT] project and several advanced promotions.

Cela active le projet [COLOR_PROJECT_TEXT]défense anti-missile[COLOR_REVERT] et plusieurs promotions avancées.

TEXT.English: Heraldry
TEXT.French: Héraldique
TEXT.Polish: Heraldyka

TEXT.English: [TAB]Heraldry in its most general sense encompasses all matters relating to the duties and responsibilities of officers of arms. To most, though, heraldry is the practice of designing, displaying, describing, and recording coats of arms and badges. Historically, it has been variously described as "the shorthand of history" (Fox-Davies), "the floral border in the garden of history" (Moncreiffe and Pottinger) and "future-proofed branding" (Clackson). The origins of heraldry lie in the need to distinguish participants in combat when their faces were hidden by iron and steel helmets. Eventually a system of rules developed into the modern form of heraldry.[PARAGRAPH:2]The system of blazoning arms that is used today was developed by the officers of arms since the dawn of the art. This includes a description of the escutcheon (shield), the crest, and, if present, supporters, mottoes, and other insignia. An understanding of these rules is one of the keys to sound practice of heraldry. The rules do differ from country to country, but there are some aspects that carry over in each jurisdiction.[PARAGRAPH:2]Though heraldry is nearly 900 years old, it is still very much in use. Many cities and towns in Europe and around the world still make use of arms. Personal heraldry, both legally protected and lawfully assumed, has continued to be used around the world. Heraldic societies thrive to promote understanding of and education about the subject. - Wikipedia
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Heraldyka jest nauká o herbach. Jedna z nauk pomocniczych historii, zajmuje siê badaniem rozwoju i znaczenia oraz zasadami ksztaôtowania siê herbów. Wywodzi siê od sôowa herold - oznaczajácego urzêdnika dworskiego, wywoôujácego nazwiska rycerzy biorácych udziaô w turniejach. W innych jêzykach europejskich nazywana jest podobnie (ang. heraldry, franc. heraldique , niem. Heraldik) lub sôowami pochodzácymi od nazwy herb. Jednym z podstawowych narzêdzi heraldyki jest blazonowanie, czyli jêzyk opisu herbów, zaä podstawowym materiaôem do badañ sá zachowane do dzisiaj role herbowe, herbarze, wizerunki herbów na pieczêciach, pôytach nagrobnych i innych zabytkach.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Heraldry is the fusion of fact and fancy, myth and manner, romance and reality. It is an exuberant union of family, art, and history." – Charles Burnett
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"L'Héraldique est la fusion de la réalité et de la fantaisie, du mythe et de la manière, de la romance et de la réalité. Il s'agit d'une union exubérante de la famille, de l'art et de l'histoire." – Charles Burnett
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Heraldyka jest poôáczeniem faktu i fantazji, mitu i zwyczaju, romantycznoäci i rzeczywistoäci. To jest obfity zwiázek rodziny, sztuki i historii." – Charles Burnett

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Heraldry[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to train [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Heavy Cavalry[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Man-At-Arms[COLOR_REVERT] (with [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Stirrup[COLOR_REVERT]) and build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Royal Tournament[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]héraldique[COLOR_REVERT] permet de recruter de la [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]cavalerie lourde[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]hommes d'armes[COLOR_REVERT] (avec [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]étrier[COLOR_REVERT]) et de construire le [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]tournoi royal[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Holy War
TEXT.French: Guerre sainte
TEXT.Polish: Äwiêta Wojna

TEXT.English: [TAB]Fundametalism is a religious movement that arose among conservative members of various Protestant denominations early in the 20th cent., with the object of maintaining traditional interpretations of the Bible and of the doctrines of the Christian faith in the face of Darwinian evolution, secularism, and the emergence of liberal theology.[PARAGRAPH:2]A group protesting "modernist" tendencies in the churches circulated a 12-volume publication called The Fundamentals (1909-12), in which five points of doctrine were set forth as fundamental: the Virgin birth, the physical resurrection of Christ, the infallibility of the Scriptures, the substitutional atonement, and the physical second coming of Christ. The debate between fundamentalists and modernists was most acute among the Baptists and the Presbyterians but also arose within other denominations. In a highly publicized case, the so-called Monkey Trial (1925), the fundamentalist leader William Jennings Bryan won Tennessee's case against J. T. Scopes, for teaching evolution in the public schools. However, other attempts by fundamentalists in the 1920s to rid the churches of modernism and the schools of evolution failed.[PARAGRAPH:2]By the 1930s many fundamentalists began to withdraw into independent churches and splinter denominations, and fundamentalism became identified in the public mind with anti-intellectualism and extremism. Many fundamentalists rejected this image, and a movement was begun in the late 1940s to present their position in both a more scholarly and popular way. This movement, known as neoevangelicalism (or, more simply, evangelicalism), sought a wider following from the major denominations through its various schools, youth programs, publications, and radio broadcasts. The separatists saw these efforts as compromising fundamentalist views and sought to disassociate themselves from these religious institutions and such well-known evangelical fundamentalists as Billy Graham.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Fundamentalizm - rygorystyczne trzymanie siê zasad i norm wyznaczonych przez daná religiê (tzw. fundamentalizm religijny), doktrynê polityczná (tzw. fundamentalizm polityczny) lub ideologiê (np. fundamentalizm äwiatopogládu naukowego). Zarzut fundamentalizmu czêsto wykorzystywany jest w mowie nienawiäci w celu zdyskredytowania oponenta. Okreälenie kogoä mianem fundamentalisty w spoôeczeñstwie nastawionym na otwartoäâ wobec róënych pogládów ma zwykle na celu przeniesienie sporu z pôaszczyzny rzeczowej na emocjonalná, z jednoczesnym poniëeniem przeciwnika przez skojarzenie z nim odczuâ negatywnych i tym samym ustawienie siê po stronie przewaëajácej.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"The main doctrine of a fanatic's creed is that his enemies are the enemies of God." - Andrew White

TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Gôówna doktryna wiary fanatyka gôosi, ëe jego wrogowie sá wrogami Boga." - Andrew White

TEXT.English: Homo Superior
TEXT.French: Homo-supérior
TEXT.Polish: Nadczôowiek

TEXT.English: [TAB]Homo Superior or Superhuman is an entity with intelligence or abilities exceeding normal human standards. [PARAGRAPH:2]Superhuman can mean an improved human, for example, by genetic modification, cybernetic implants, or as what humans might evolve into, in the distant future. Occasionally, it could mean an otherwise "normal" human with unusual abilities, such as psychic abilities or exceptional proficiency at something, far beyond the norm.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Nadczôowiek wyróënia siê wiêkszymi umiejêtnoäciami oraz zdolnoäciami oraz wyëszá inteligencjá nië przeciêtny czôowiek. Jest genetycznie zmodyfikowany i przewaënie wykorzystywani sá w celach militarnych a nawet medycznych.

TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Bêdê nauczaô was nadczôowieka. Czôowiek jest czymä, co trzeba przezwyciêëaâ." - Fryderyk Nietzsche

TEXT.English: Horse Breeding
TEXT.French: Élevage des chevaux
TEXT.Polish: Hodowla Koni

TEXT.English: [TAB]The history of horse breeding goes back millennia. Though the precise date is in dispute, humans could have domesticated the horse as far back as approximately 4500 BCE. However, evidence of planned breeding has a more blurry history. [PARAGRAPH:2]One of the earliest people known to document the breedings of their horses were the Bedouin of the Middle East, the breeders of the Arabian horse. While it is difficult to determine how far back the Bedouin passed on pedigree information via an oral tradition, there were written pedigrees of Arabian horses by A.D. 1330. The Akhal-Teke of West-Central Asia is another breed with roots in ancient times that was also bred specifically for war and racing. The nomads of the Mongolian steppes bred horses for several thousand years as well.[PARAGRAPH:2]The types of horses bred varied with culture and with the times. The uses to which a horse was put also determined its qualities, including smooth amblers for riding, fast horses for carrying messengers, heavy horses for plowing and pulling heavy wagons, ponies for hauling cars of ore from mines, packhorses, carriage horses and many others. - Wikipedia
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Koñ i wieäci o nim zanikajá w neolicie aë do czasu, kiedy znajdujemy pierwsze wzmianki o udomowieniu konia, ok.3500 lat p.n.e., dochodzimy wiec do ery rydwanow i jezdzcow.W epoce brázu koñ jest juz udomowiony, ujeëdëony, trenowany do róënych prac. Niektórzy otaczajá go czciá, dla niego tworzy siê bóstwa, zapewniajáce pôodnoäâ i dôugowiecznoäâ. W tej erze bierze poczátek, jak já nazywajá póéniej, hiszpañska szkoôa jazdy, w ktorej koñ szkolony jest na dôugiej lonëy, ujeëdëany i wykorzystywany jako "partner" w hodowli byków. W muzeum archeologii w Madrycie znajdujá siê podkowy, uprzêëe oraz wyposarzenie jeédéca z IV i III wieku p.n.e, a wiêc z wczeäniejsze nië w historii rzymskiej czy greckiej.

TEXT.English: Humanism
TEXT.French: Humanisme
TEXT.Polish: Humanizm

TEXT.English: [TAB]Humanism is a broad category of ethical philosophies that affirm the dignity and worth of all people, based on the ability to determine right and wrong by appeal to universal human qualities, particularly rationality. It is a component of a variety of more specific philosophical systems and is incorporated into several religious schools of thought. Humanism entails a commitment to the search for truth and morality through human means in support of human interests. In focusing on the capacity for self-determination, humanism rejects the validity of transcendental justifications, such as a dependence on belief without reason, the supernatural, or texts of allegedly divine origin. Humanists endorse universal morality based on the commonality of the human condition, suggesting that solutions to human social and cultural problems cannot be parochial. [PARAGRAPH:2]Renaissance humanism was a movement that affected the cultural, political, social, and literary landscape of Europe. Beginning in Florence in the last decades of the 14th century, Renaissance humanism revived the study of Latin and Greek, with the resultant revival of the study of science, philosophy, art and poetry of classical antiquity.(see Burckhard The Civilisation of the Renaissance in Italy) The revival was based on interpretations of Roman and Greek texts, whose emphasis upon art and the senses marked a great change from the contemplation on the Biblical values of humility, introspection, and meekness. Beauty was held to represent a deep inner virtue and value, and an essential element in the path towards God.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Humanizm – prád filozoficzny, etyczny i kulturowy, uznajácy czôowieka za najwyëszá wartoäâ i podkreälajácy jego godnoäâ. Wielu humanistów (w tym ludzi wierzácych) postuluje rozstrzyganie dylematów etycznych poprzez odwoôywanie siê do pojêâ uniwersalnych, wspólnych wszystkim ludziom. Poszukujá oni éródôa prawdy i moralnoäci w czôowieku i jego dáëeniu do szczêäcia. Niekoniecznie wyklucza to samá wiarê w Boga, choâ humanizm äwiecki jest prêëná odnogá tej filozofii. Ten poglád skôania jednak do szukania rozumowego uzasadnienia praw etycznych, nie odwoôujácego siê do twierdzeñ jakiejkolwiek religii, podobnie jak nie potrzeba siê do nich odwoôywaâ przy badaniu praw fizyki.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"O supreme generosity of God the Father, O highest and most marvelous felicity of man. To him it is granted to have whatever he chooses, to be whatever he wills." -Giovanni Pico della Mirandola
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"O suprême générosité de Dieu le Père, ô le plus élevé et le plus merveilleux bonheur de l'homme. Pour lui, il est accordé d'avoir ce qu'il choisi, et d'être ce qu'il veut" -Giovanni Pico della Mirandola
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"umanizm to nie znaczy mówiâ: "Zrobiôem to, czego ëadne zwierze by nie zrobiôo", to znaczy mówiâ: "Odrzuciliämy to, czego chciaôo w nas zwierzê, i chcemy odnaleéâ czôowieka wszêdzie tam, gdzie znaleéliämy to, co go miaëdëy." - André Malraux

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Humanism[COLOR_REVERT] enables the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Free Church[COLOR_REVERT] civic. This tech also reduces the Science output of [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Monasteries[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]humanisme[COLOR_REVERT] active la doctrine [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]église libre[COLOR_REVERT]. Cette technologie réduit la génération de science des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]monastères[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Hydroponics
TEXT.Polish: Hydroponika

TEXT.English: [TAB]Hydroponics is the science of growing vegetables in nutrient solutions rather than in soil. The earliest references to hydroponics date back to the seventeenth century, and while notable advances in research were seen over the following centuries, the first practical applications of hydroponics did not appear until the early twentieth century, and mass adoption didn't occur until the middle of the twenty-first century. There are two primary benefits to growing plants in nutrient solutions rather than in soil: the nutrient solution can be sterilized (unlike soil), greatly reducing the occurrence of disease and pests in the plants, and a much greater number of crops can be grown in a small area. [PARAGRAPH:2]The primary downside to this method of cultivation is that it requires a fair degree of technical know-how to install and maintain the complicated machines necessary to keep the "scum-ponds" healthy and productive. However, once education levels improved in rural populations across the world, this was no longer an impediment, and the practice has since spread rapidly, greatly increasing the world's food supply.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les cultures hydroponiques consistent à faire pousser des légumes dans des solutions nutritives plutôt qu'en les plantant dans le sol. Les premières expériences menées dans ce sens datent du dix-septième siècle et les progrès dans ce domaine n'ont jamais ralenti depuis lors. La première application pratique des cultures hydroponiques a été introduite au début du vingtième siècle, mais leur développement à l'échelle industrielle ne fut véritablement au point qu'au milieu du vingt-et-unième siècle. Il y a deux avantages majeurs à faire pousser des plantes dans des solutions nutritives plutôt que dans la terre : la solution peut être stérilisée (contrairement à la terre), ce qui réduit considérablement les risques de maladies ainsi que l'usage des pesticides ; et la quantité de plantes produites est nettement plus importante pour une même surface.[PARAGRAPH:2]Le principal inconvénient de cette méthode est le fait qu'elle requiert un certain savoir-faire technologique pour être mise en place et qu'elle nécessite une machinerie très complexe afin de maintenir un bon niveau de productivité. Cependant, le niveau d'éducation s'est nettement amélioré dans les milieux ruraux et la pratique des cultures hydroponiques s'est très largement répandue, augmentant considérablement la production mondiale de nourriture.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Hydrokultur ist die Wissenschaft der Kultivierung von Pflanzen in Nährlösung statt in Erde. Die früheste Erwähnung dieser Form der Pflanzenzucht datiert auf das 17. Jahrhundert. In den darauf folgenden Jahrhunderten wurden bemerkenswerte Fortschritte erzielt, so dass im frühen 20. Jahrhundert erste praktische Anwendungen dokumentiert sind und ab Mitte des 21. Jahrhunderts eine verbreitete Nutzung einsetzte. Die Züchtung von Pflanzen in Nährlösung statt in Mutterboden hat vor allem zwei Vorteile: Die Nährlösung kann sterilisiert werden (im Gegensatz zum Mutterboden), wodurch sich das Risiko von Krankheiten und Schädlingsbefall deutlich reduziert. Und zum anderen lässt sich der Ernteertrag schon auf einer vergleichsweise kleinen Bebauungsfläche massiv steigern. [PARAGRAPH:2]Der größte Nachteil der Hydrokultur ist dagegen, dass ein gewisses Maß an technischem Wissen erforderlich ist, um die komplexen Gerätschaften zu installieren und zu steuern, die das "Feuchtbiotop" gesund und produktiv halten. Mit steigendem Bildungsniveau auch in der ländlichen Bevölkerung überall auf der Welt stellte dies jedoch schon bald kein nennenswertes Hindernis mehr dar und so fand diese Kultivierungsmethode seither sehr schnelle Verbreitung, wodurch sich die weltweite Nahrungsversorgung spürbar verbesserte.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]L'idroponica è la scienza che permette di crescere i vegetali in soluzioni nutrienti, invece che nel suolo. I primi riferimenti all'idroponica risalgono al diciassettesimo secolo e, mentre ci sono stati notevoli sviluppi nei secoli seguenti, le prime applicazioni pratiche dell'idroponica non sono apparse se non all'inizio del ventesimo secolo e l'uso diffuso non venne adottato fino alla metà del ventunesimo. Ci sono due benefici principali, nel crescere le piante in soluzioni nutrienti invece che nella terra: la soluzione nutriente può essere sterilizzata (a differenza del suolo), riducendo di molto malattie e parassiti delle piante, e può essere coltivata una quantità molto più grande su un'area ridotta. [PARAGRAPH:2]Lo svantaggio principale di questo metodo di coltivazione è che richiede un discreto grado di conoscenze tecniche, per installare e far funzionare i complicati macchinari necessari a mantenere le vasche sane e produttive. Dopo che i livelli di educazione della popolazione rurale mondiale sono saliti, però, questo non è stato più un problema e la pratica si è diffusa rapidamente, aumentando di molto la produzione di cibo mondial
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La hidroponía es la ciencia de cultivar vegetales en soluciones de nutrientes en vez de en la tierra. Las primeras referencias a la hidroponía datan del s. XVII y, aunque se experimentaron notables avances en los siguientes siglos, las primeras aplicaciones prácticas no tuvieron lugar hasta principios del s. XX y no se aplicó masivamente hasta mediados del XXI. Existen dos beneficios principales en el cultivo de plantas en soluciones de nutrientes en lugar de en tierra: las primeras pueden esterilizarse (al contrario que la segunda), lo que reduce enormemente los casos de enfermedades y plagas en las plantas y aumenta el número de cultivos que pueden plantarse en un área muy reducida. [PARAGRAPH:2]La principal contrapartida de este método de cultivo es que requiere un buen nivel de conocimientos técnicos para instalar y mantener las complicadas máquinas necesarias para conservar las "algas flotantes" productivas y en buen estado. Sin embargo, una vez mejorados los niveles educativos en las poblaciones rurales de todo el mundo, ya no hubo impedimento alguno, y dicha práctica se ha extendido rápidamente y ha incrementado enormemente los suministros alimenticios del mund
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Hydroponika to nauka uprawy roälin w pôynie. Pierwsze wzmianki o hydroponice pochodzá z siedemnastego wieku i pomimo znaczácych postêpów w badaniach w kolejnych wiekach, pierwsze faktyczne uëycie hydroponiki rozpoczêto dopiero na poczátku dwudziestego wieku, a masowe zastosowanie w poôowie wieku dwudziestego. Sá dwie podstawowe podstawowe zalety hydroponiki: roztwór wodny moëe byâ wysterylizowany (w przeciwiêstwie do gleby), co znacznie zmniejsza ryzyko pojawienia siê chorób oraz szkodników na roälinach hodowlanych, oraz wiêsza iloäâ plonów moëe byâ uprawiana na danym obszarze.[PARAGRAPH:2]Wadá jest jedynie niezbêdna techniczna wiedza jak zainstalowaâ i obsôugiwaâ wszelkie skomplikowane maszyny utrzymujáce "mêtne stawy" pôodnymi i zdrowymi. Jednak kiedy poziom wiedzy na ten temat w wiejskich obszarach poprawiô siê przestaôo byâ to przeszkodá a zastosowanie szybko siê rozpowszechniôo znaczáco zwiêkszajác zasoby ëywnoäci na äwiecie.

TEXT.English: "All right. Maybe it DOES taste like wet cardboard - but it sure beats starving." - Dexter Ambrose231, Agricultural Engineer
TEXT.French: "D'accord, ça a un goût de carton, mais c'est toujours mieux que mourir de faim." - Dexter Ambrose231, Ingénieur agricole

TEXT.Polish: "No dobra, moëe i smakuje to jak karton, ale chyba to lepsze nië gôodowanie?" - Dexter Ambrose231, Inëynier Agralny

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Hydroponics[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Hydroponic Farms[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]fermes hydroponiques[COLOR_REVERT] permettent la construction des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]fermes hydroponiques[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Hypersonic Flight
TEXT.French: Vol hypersonique
TEXT.Polish: Prêdkoäâ Hipersoniczna

TEXT.English: [TAB]In aerodynamics, hypersonic speeds are speeds that are highly supersonic. In the 1970s, the term generally came to refer to speeds of Mach 5 (5 times the speed of sound) and above. The hypersonic regime is a subset of the supersonic regime.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Prêdkoäâ naddéwiêkowa w aerodynamice prêdkoäâ obiektu lub przepôywu, poruszajácego siê szybciej nië prêdkoäâ déwiêku (przy temperaturze +20 °C = 340 m/s). Prêdkoäci ponad piêciokrotnie wiêksze od prêdkoäci déwiêku czêsto nazywane sá prêdkoäciami hipersonicznymi. Przy zbliëaniu siê do prêdkoäci déwiêku dochodzi do powstawania fal uderzeniowych i zjawisk zwiázanych z tak zwaná barierá déwiêku i gromem déwiêkowym.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"The best safety device is the pilot, who, deep down, regardless of the aircraft, retains a sense of fallibility and vulnerability. No system can ever substitute for that." - Arnold Reiner
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Le meilleur dispositif de sécurité est le pilote, qui, au fond, indépendamment de l'avion, conserve un sens de la faillibilité et de la vulnérabilité. Aucun système ne peut jamais se substituer à cela." - Arnold Reiner
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Czasoprzestrzeñ dyktuje masie jak siê poruszaâ, a masa dyktuje czasoprzestrzeni jak siê zakrzywiaâ." - John Wheeler

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Hypersonic Flight[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Aerospace Complex[COLOR_REVERT] and construct [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Aurora Scramjets[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]vol hypersonique[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire le [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]complexe aérospatial[COLOR_REVERT] et le [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]stato-réacteur Aurora[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Imperialism
TEXT.French: Impérialisme
TEXT.Polish: Imperializm

TEXT.English: "We must bear in mind that imperialism is a world system, the last stage of capitalism - and it must be defeated in a world confrontation." - Che Guevara
TEXT.French: Nous devons garder à l'esprit que l'impérialisme est un système mondialisé, la dernière étape du capitalisme - et qu'il doit être défait dans une confrontation mondiale - Ernesto Guevara

TEXT.English: In its largest sense, imperialism is the establishment of power or authority by one country over another. Empires are usually established by military force, but in the modern age, "imperialism" is sometimes used to describe cultural or economic control of weaker nations by more powerful ones.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]The phrase "Age of Imperialism" is used to define the imperialistic policies of European nations, the United States, and Japan in the 19th and early 20th centuries, incluing the "Great Game" of controlling Afghanistan and the "Scramble for Africa" where the European powers divided nearly the whole continent into colonies. Much of this open imperialism stopped after the exhaustion of World War I and the Great Depression.
[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Imperialism[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Crystal Palace[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Reichstag[COLOR_REVERT] wonders.
TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]impérialisme[COLOR_REVERT] vous permet de construire les merveilles du "[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Crystal Palace[COLOR_REVERT]" et du "[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Reichstag[COLOR_REVERT]".

TEXT.English: Insurance
TEXT.French: Assurance
TEXT.Polish: Ubezpieczenia

TEXT.English: In law and economics, insurance is a form of risk management primarily used to hedge against the risk of a contingent, uncertain loss. Insurance is defined as the equitable transfer of the risk of a loss, from one entity to another, in exchange for payment. An insurer is a company selling the insurance; an insured or policyholder is the person or entity buying the insurance policy. The insurance rate is a factor used to determine the amount to be charged for a certain amount of insurance coverage, called the premium. Risk management, the practice of appraising and controlling risk, has evolved as a discrete field of study and practice.
TEXT.French: En droit et en économie, l'assurance est une forme de gestion des risques, principalement utilisé pour se prémunir contre le risque d'une perte incertaine et contingente. L'assurance est définie comme le transfert équitable du risque de cette perte, d'une entité à une autre, en échange de paiement. L'assureur est une entreprise qui vend de l'assurance, un assuré ou preneur d'assurance est la personne physique ou morale achetant la police d'assurance. Le taux d'assurance est un facteur servant à déterminer le montant à payer pour une certaine quantité de la couverture d'assurance, appelé prime. La gestion des risques, la pratique de l'évaluation et du contrôle du risque, a évolué comme un champ distinct d'étude théorique et pratique.

TEXT.English: "You don't need to pray to God any more when there are storms in the sky, but you do have to be insured."[NEWLINE] - Bertolt Brecht
TEXT.French: "Lorsqu'il y a des tempêtes dans le ciel, plus besoin de prier Dieu, mais il faut par contre être assuré."[NEWLINE] - Bertolt Brecht
TEXT.Polish: "I ten winien, co kijem bezpieczeñstwo mierzyô, I ten, co bezpieczeñstwo gôupiemu powierzyô."[NEWLINE] - Ignacy Krasicki

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Insurance[COLOR_REVERT] provides +1 trade route per city and increases trade route income. [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Trade Missions[COLOR_REVERT] also produce more gold.
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]assurances[COLOR_REVERT] procurent une route commerciale supplémentaire par ville et augmente le revenu généré par ces routes. Les [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]missions commerciales[COLOR_REVERT] produisent également plus d'or.

TEXT.English: Interstellar Travel
TEXT.French: Voyages interstellaires
TEXT.Polish: Podróë Miêdzygwiezdna

TEXT.English: [TAB]Interstellar space travel is unmanned or manned travel between stars. The concept of interstellar travel in starships is a staple in science fiction. Interstellar travel is tremendously more difficult than interplanetary travel. Intergalactic travel, the travel between different galaxies, is even more difficult.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Lot miêdzygwiezdny – lot statku kosmicznego w przestrzeni miêdzygwiazdowej, zwôaszcza z Ukôadu Sôonecznego (z Ziemi) w okolice innych gwiazd nië Sôoñce. Warunkiem koniecznym do zrealizowania lotu miêdzygwiezdnego z Ziemi jest nadanie pojazdowi kosmicznemu trzeciej prêdkoäci kosmicznej (przy starcie z Ziemi jest to minimum 16,7 km/s) i skierowanie go na trajektoriê ucieczkowá z Ukôadu Sôonecznego.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"The Earth is just too small and fragile a basket for the human race to keep all its eggs in." - Robert Heinlein
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"La Terre est un panier trop petit et fragile pour que le genre humain puisse garder tous ses oeufs dedans." - Robert Heinlein
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Podróë kosmiczna jest triumfem rozumu i klêská rozsádku." - Max Born

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Interstellar Travel[COLOR_REVERT] lets you build the [COLOR_PROJECT_TEXT]SS Thrusters[COLOR_REVERT] spaceship part and the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Starport[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]voyage interstellaire[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire le module de [COLOR_PROJECT_TEXT]propulseur SS[COLOR_REVERT] du vaisseau spatial et la [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]base de lancement stellaire[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Invention
TEXT.French: Invention
TEXT.Polish: Wynalazczoäâ

TEXT.English: [TAB]The contrivance of a previously unknown device, method or process, which can in turn be used to accomplish an objective in a ways thought to be impossible, is known as invention. Essentially, inventiveness is the ability to take one or more newly discovered concepts and find a way to put them to practical use. The earliest inventions of mankind date back to ancient stone and metal tools used for hunting, digging, and other everyday tasks. After writing allowed the ideas of various civilizations to be exchanged and studied, mankind's inventions became increasingly more useful and innovative. Most inventions are geared toward improving or simplifying human existence in some way. Often, inventions themselves make it possible to make new discoveries, which then go on to inspire better and more innovative inventions.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Alchemia – przednaukowa praktyka ôáczáca elementy zawarte obecnie w chemii, fizyce, sztuce, semiotyce, psychologii, metalurgii, medycynie, astrologii, mistycyzmie i religii. Wspólnym celem alchemików byôo odkrycie metody transmutacji oôowiu w zôoto (kamieñ filozoficzny), lekarstwa na wszelkie choroby (panaceum) oraz eliksiru nieämiertelnoäci. Alchemiê moëna uwaëaâ za bezpoäredniego przodka wspóôczesnej chemii.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Necessity, who is the mother of invention." - Plato
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"La nécessité, qui est la mère de l'invention." - Plato
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Ogieñ czyni alchemiê, zarówno w piecu hutniczym, jak w kuchennym." - Paracelsus

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Invention[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Artesian Well[COLOR_REVERT] and train [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Heavy Cavalry[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Trebuchets[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]invention[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire le [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]puits artésien[COLOR_REVERT] et de recruter de la [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]cavalerie lourde[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]trébuchets[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Invisibility
TEXT.French: Invisibilité
TEXT.Polish: Niewidzialnoäâ

TEXT.English: [TAB]Invisibility is the state of an object which cannot be seen. An object in this state is said to be Invisible (literally, "not visible"). Engineers and scientists have performed various kinds of research to investigate the possibility of finding ways to create real optical invisibility for objects. [PARAGRAPH:2]Although it has been shown that making opaque objects perfectly invisible ("non-scattering scatterers") is impossible, 2006 theoretical work predicts that the imperfections need not be serious, and metamaterials may make real-life "cloaking devices" practical. he technique is suspected to be applied to radio waves within five years, and eventually visible light is a possibility. The theory that light waves can be acted upon the same way as radio waves is now a popular idea among scientists and can be compared to a stone in a river, in where the water passes around it, but leaving no trace of a stone being in the water slightly down-stream. Comparing light waves to the water and whatever object that is being "cloaked" to the stone, the desire is to have light waves pass around that object, leaving no visible aspects of it, possibly not even a shadow. [PARAGRAPH:2]Two teams of scientists worked separately to create two "Invisibility Cloaks" from 'metamaterials' engineered at the nanoscale level. They demonstrated for the first time the possibility of cloaking 3-dimensional (3-D) objects with artificially engineered materials that redirect radar, light or other waves around an object, like water flowing around a smooth rock in a stream. While one uses a type of fishnet of metal layers to reverse the direction of light, the other uses tiny silver wires. Xiang Zhang, of the University of California, Berkeley said: "In the case of invisibility cloaks or shields, the material would need to curve light waves completely around the object like a river flowing around a rock. An observer looking at the cloaked object would then see light from behind it, making it seem to disappear." [PARAGRAPH:2]Researcher Jason Valentine's team made a material that affects light near the visible spectrum, in a region used in fibre optics: 'Instead of the fish appearing to be slightly ahead of where it is in the water, it would actually appear to be above the water's surface. It's kind of weird. For a metamaterial to produce negative refraction, it must have a structural array smaller than the wavelength of the electromagnetic radiation being used." Valentine's team created their 'fishnet' material by stacking silver and metal dielectric layers on top of each other and then punched through with holes. The other team used an oxide template and grew silver nanowires inside porous aluminum oxide at tiny distances apart, smaller than the wavelength of visible light. This material refracts visible light.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]W 1897 roku Herbert George Wells napisaô ksiáëkê "Niewidzialny czôowiek". Od czasu jej wydania, niewidzialnoäâ materii istniaôa tylko jako fikcja. W tym tygodniu przeksztaôciôa siê w rzeczywistoäâ i choâ czeka já dôuga droga do ideaôu, otwiera zupeônie nowy rodziaô w historii techniki.Grupa badawcza z Duke University w Póônocnej Karolinie zademonstrowaôa moëliwoäâ znikania przedmiotów materialnych.Obiekt, który widzimy moëe nagle "zniknáâ"... W jaki sposób?Uëyto do tego specjalnych czêstotliwoäci mikrofali, które otaczajác obiekt odniesienia oddziaôywujá ze spektrum widzialnym doprowadzajác do zôudzenia nieobecnoäci. Äwiatôo widzialne "opôywa" obiekt po czym kieruje siê w stronê siatkówek naszych oczu. Wraëenie jest niesamowite.W latach 90-tych, fizyk Lawrence Krauss napisaô ksiáëkê pt. "Fizyka Star Treka". Wyjaäniô w niej w jaki sposób kosmici zwani Romulanami stworzyli pojazd kosmiczny niewidoczny dla zewnêtrznych obserwatorów. Udaôo to siê im osiágnáâ przez zaginanie promieni äwietlnych wokóô statku.Prace trwajá i bêdá trwaâ, poniewaë obecna wersja urzádzenia jest jedynie prototypem majácym na celu udowodnienie samej moëliwoäci tworzenia niewidzialnych przestrzeni.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"The invisible and the non-existent look very much alike" - Delo McKown
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"L'invisible et l'inexistant ont l'ai très semblables" - Delo McKown
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"(...)Ëyâ w harmonii ze äwiatem widzialnym i niewidzialnym." - Paulo Coelho

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Invisibility[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to train [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Special Infantry[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Fusion Destroyers[COLOR_REVERT], and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Fusion Transports[COLOR_REVERT]. The first civilization to discover [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Invisibility[COLOR_REVERT] receives a free [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Great Spy[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]invisibilité[COLOR_REVERT] permet de recruter de l'[COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]infanterie spéciale[COLOR_REVERT], des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]destroyers à fusion[COLOR_REVERT], et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]transports à fusion[COLOR_REVERT]. La première civilisation à découvrir l'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]invisibilité[COLOR_REVERT] reçoit un [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]espion illustre[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Jet Propulsion
TEXT.French: Propulsion par réaction
TEXT.Polish: Napêd Odrzutowy

TEXT.English: [TAB]Jet propulsion is a method of propulsion in which an object is propelled in one direction by a "jet" or stream of gases moving in the other direction. This follows from Isaac Newton's third law of motion - "To every action there is an equal and opposite reaction." The most common application of this principle is the jet engine. This is now the most common aircraft engine. There are two types of jet engine: the turbojet and the turbofan. The turbofan is quieter and more efficient than the turbojet.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Silnik odrzutowy to silnik dziaôajácy na zasadzie wyrzucania z duëá prêdkoäciá strumienia gazów, co wywoôuje siôê ciágu w przeciwná stronê na podstawie trzeciego prawa dynamiki Newtona. Potocznie przez silnik odrzutowy rozumie siê najczêäciej silniki turboodrzutowe i turbowentylatorowe. Podstawá teoretyczná pracy silnika odrzutowego jako silnika cieplnego jest obieg Braytona-Joule'a.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"The challenge was subtle adjustment of jet propulsion." - Junichiro Kawaguchi
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Le défi était l'ajustement subtil de la propulsion à réaction." - Junichiro Kawaguchi
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Kiedyä ludzie mówili, ëe prêdkoäâ dëwiêku jest nieosiágalna, kto wie co bêdzie za kilka lat." - Andrzej Koman

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Jet Propulsion[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]P59[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Carrier[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]propulsion par réaction[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]P59[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]porte-avions[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Journalism
TEXT.French: Journalisme
TEXT.Polish: Dziennikarstwo

TEXT.English: "News is only the first rough draft of history." - Alan Barth
TEXT.French: L'actualité est seulement le premier brouillon de l'histoire - Alan Barth

TEXT.English: Journalism is the investigation and reporting of events, issues and trends to a broad audience. Though there are many variations of journalism, the ideal is to inform the intended audience about topics ranging from government and business organizations to cultural aspects of society such as arts and entertainment. The field includes editing, photojournalism, and documentary.
[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Journalism[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Press Agency[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Publishing House[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]journalisme[COLOR_REVERT] vous permet de construire l'[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]agence de presse[COLOR_REVERT] et la [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]maison d'édition[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Jurisprudence
TEXT.French: Jurisprudence
TEXT.Polish: Prawoznawstwo
