TEXT.English: [TAB]Jurisprudence, study of the nature and the origin and development of law. It is variously regarded as a branch of ethics or of sociology. Many of the major systematic philosophers (e.g., Aristotle, St. Thomas Aquinas, and Kant) have expounded jurisprudential theories. Before the 19th cent. most jurisprudents adhered to natural law, which maintained that sound legal doctrine was derivable only from a supposed law of nature established by divine ordinance. The natural-law school did not deny that the details of legal regulation depended upon the will of the sovereign. However, the positivist, or analytical, school, which first became important in the late 18th cent., insisted that law was entirely a matter of sovereign decree, distinct from morality and theology. Among important 19th-century trends was the view, represented by Savigny, that a people's legal system expressed the national spirit. In the mid-19th cent. many jurisprudents attempted to avoid what they felt were theoretical preconceptions and to demonstrate a uniform evolution from primitive times to modern industrialized society. Other thinkers were skeptical of evolutionary explanations and sought the basic principles underlying all systems of law in various fields, including economics and psychology. Among the more important legal thinkers in the United States have been Learned Hand, Oliver Wendell Holmes, and Roscoe Pound. [PARAGRAPH:2]Civil law, as used in this article, a modern legal system based upon Roman law, as distinguished from common law. Civil law is based on written legal codes, a hallmark of the Roman legal system, in which disputes were settled by reference to a written legal code arrived at through legislation, edicts, and the like; common law is based on the precedents created by judicial decisions over time. The tendency in civil law is to create a unified legal system by working out with maximum precision the conclusions to be drawn from basic principles. The civil law judge is bound by the provisions of the written law. The traditional civil law decision states the applicable provision from the code or from a relevant statute, and the judgment is based upon that provision.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Prawoznawstwo, inaczej jurysprudencja (w piämiennictwie okreälana teë jako doktryna prawa lub nauka prawa) jest jedná z nauk spoôecznych, zajmujácá siê prawem. Jest to obszerna dziedzina wiedzy o tworzeniu i funkcjonowaniu prawa oraz jego stosowaniu. Nazwa „jurysprudencja” wywodzi siê od ôaciñskiego sôowa iurisprudentia (ius,iuris - prawo; prudentia - wiedza), bywa niekiedy stosowana w wêëszym zakresie w odniesieniu do orzecznictwa sádowego.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"If I didn't have a sense of humour, how could I stand this trial now?" - Hermann Göring
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Si je n'ai pas eu un sens de l'humour, comment pourrais-je supporter ce procès aujourd'hui?" - Hermann Göring
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Nie przywôaszczaj sobie ëadnego prawa wzglêdem ludzi, którego oni sami ci nie dali, i nie przyznawaj ëadnego wzglêdem siebie, którego im nie daôeä." - Aleksander Äwiêtochowski

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Jurisprudence[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]District Courthouses[COLOR_REVERT] and the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Supreme Court[COLOR_REVERT] National Wonder.
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]jurisprudence[COLOR_REVERT] permet la construction d'un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]tribunal de district[COLOR_REVERT] et de la [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]cour suprême[COLOR_REVERT] (merveille nationale).

TEXT.English: Knowledge Management
TEXT.French: Management de la connaissance
TEXT.Polish: Zarzádzanie Wiedzá

TEXT.English: [TAB]Knowledge Management ('KM') comprises a range of practices used by organisations to identify, create, represent, and distribute knowledge. It has been an established discipline since 1995 with a body of university courses and both professional and academic journals dedicated to it. Many large companies have resources dedicated to Knowledge Management, often as a part of 'Information Technology' or 'Human Resource Management' departments. Knowledge Management is a multi-billion dollar world wide market. [PARAGRAPH:2]Knowledge Management programs are typically tied to organisational objectives such as improved performance, competitive advantage, innovation, developmental processes, lessons learnt transfer (for example between projects) and the general development of collaborative practices. Knowledge Management is frequently linked and related to what has become known as the learning organisation, lifelong learning and continuous improvement. Knowledge Management may be distinguished from Organisational Learning by a greater focus on the management of knowledge as an asset and the development and cultivation of the channels through which knowledge, information and signal flow.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Zarzádzanie wiedzá - to zespóô sformalizowanych sposobów gromadzenia i wykorzystywania wiedzy formalnej oraz wiedzy cichej uczestników organizacji (np. pracowników firmy). Zarzádzanie wiedzá, to próba jak najlepszego wykorzystania wiedzy, która jest dostêpna w organizacji, tworzenie nowej wiedzy oraz zwiêkszanie jej zrozumienia.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Knowledge is power" - Sir Francis Bacon
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Savoir, c'est pouvoir" - Sir Francis Bacon
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Co my wiemy, to tylko kropelka. Czego nie wiemy, to caôy ocean." - Isaac Newton

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Knowledge Management[COLOR_REVERT] enables the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Technocracy[COLOR_REVERT] civic and the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Info Net[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]gestion des connaissances[COLOR_REVERT] active la doctrine [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]technocratie[COLOR_REVERT] et permet de construire '[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Info Net[COLOR_REVERT]'.

TEXT.English: Labour Union
TEXT.French: Syndicalisme
TEXT.Polish: Zwiázki Zawodowe

TEXT.English: [TAB]Labour unions arose in the 18th and 19th century in response to the poor working conditions brought on by an intense competition for jobs, and the increasing dependence of the working class on their employers created by the move toward industrialization. Early labour unions, formed by skilled labourers in specific fields, met with opposition from both employers and the government. In the 19th century, laws were passed legalizing trade unions, and by the 20th century unions were formed in semi- or unskilled fields such as mining, transportation, and dock working. Binding their interests together and bargaining collectively, trade unions forced factory and business owners to provide better working conditions and economic status for their workers.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Zwiázek zawodowy - masowa organizacja spoôeczna zrzeszajáca na zasadzie dobrowolnoäci ludzi pracy najemnej. Podstawowym zadaniem zwiázków zawodowych jest obrona interesów pracowników i dziaôanie na rzecz poprawy ich sytuacji ekonomicznej i spoôecznej. Zwiázki próbujá wiêc przeciwdziaôaâ zwolnieniom, kontrolujá przestrzeganie kodeksu pracy przez pracodawców, zabiegajá o wyësze pensje i lepsze warunki pracy dla pracowników. Czêsto prowadzá równieë dziaôalnoäâ samopomocowá (np. fundusze strajkowe), edukacyjná (np. kursy przekwalifikowujáce) i oäwiatowá (np. kampanie informacyjne o prawach przysôugujácych pracownikom).Zwiázki zawodowe nie muszá siê kierowaâ dobrem firmy w której pracujá przez co czasem firma z powodu negatywnych dziaôañ moëe upaäâ lub ponieäâ dotkliwe straty zarówno finansowe ale teë wizerunkowe. Zwiázki zawodowe powstaôy w Wielkiej Brytanii w roku 1824.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"All that serves labour serves the nation. All that harms is treason. If a man tells you he trusts America, yet fears labour, he is a fool. There is no America without labour, and to fleece the one is to rob the other." - Abraham Lincoln
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Tout ce qui sert le travail sert la nation. Tout ce qui le nuit est trahison. Si un homme vous dit qu'il veut croire en l'Amérique, et a peur du travail, il est un sot. Il n'y a pas d'Amérique sans travail, et escroquer l'un c'est voler l'autre." - Abraham Lincoln
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Wszyscy którzy sôuëá pracá, sôuëá narodowi. Wszycy którzy krzywdzá, zdradzajá. Jeëeli mêëczyzna mówi ci, ëe ufa Ameryce, jednak pracuje w strachu, jest gôupcem. Nie ma ëadnej Ameryki bez pracy i jeäli jeden rabuje to okrada wszystkich" - Abraham Lincoln

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Labour Union[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Labour Union[COLOR_REVERT] National Wonder and enables the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Socialized[COLOR_REVERT] civic.
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]syndicalisme[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire le [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]syndicat de travailleur[COLOR_REVERT] (merveille nationale) et active la doctrine [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]socialisé[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Leadership
TEXT.French: Commandement
TEXT.Polish: Dowodzenie

TEXT.English: [TAB]Through the Middle Ages, military forces were only assembled as needed, and continued to serve until the current conflict had ended. Though certain leaders had proven to be adept and occasionally brilliant in their methods, the short periods for which they served made their fame short-lived. As regular armies became more prevalent, military leaders had the opportunity to distinguish themselves through the formulation of brilliant military tactics. The tactics of leaders such as these would be studied by successive generations, and modified to fit new situations up to and including the present day.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Przez äredniowiecze, siôy wojskowe byôy zbierane tylko wtedy gdy byôy potrzebne, i sôuëyôy dopóki nie zakoñczyô siê konflikt. Chociaë pewni liderzy okazali siê biegli i czasami bôyskotliwi w ich metodach, krótkie okresy, w których oni sôuëyli, uczyniôy ich sôawê krótkotrwaôymi. Jako ëe regularne armie staôy siê bardziej przewaëajácymi, wojskowi liderzy mieli okazjê, do wyróënienia i sformuôowania bôyskotliwej wojskowej taktyki. Taktyki liderów jak tych byôa studiowana przez kolejne pokolenia, i modyfikowana, by dopasowaâ nowe sytuacje do nich i wykorzystaâ tego samego dnia.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Soldiers usually win the battles and generals get the credit for them." - Napoleon Bonaparte
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Habituellement, Les soldats gagnent les batailles et les généraux en récoltent les Honneurs." - Napoleon Bonaparte
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Ëoônierze zwykle wygrywajá bitwy, a generaôowie dostajá pieniádze za nich." - Napoleon Bonaparte

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Leadership[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to upgrade your [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Barracks[COLOR_REVERT] to [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Garrisons[COLOR_REVERT]. The first civilization to discover this tech receives a free [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Great General[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]commandement[COLOR_REVERT] permet d'améliorer les [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]casernes[COLOR_REVERT] en [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]garnisons[COLOR_REVERT]. La première civilisation à découvrir cette technologie reçoit un [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]général illustre[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Logistics
TEXT.French: Logistique
TEXT.Polish: Logistyka

TEXT.English: [TAB]Logistics is the management of the flow of goods, information and other resources, including energy and people, between the point of origin and the point of consumption in order to meet the requirements of consumers (frequently, and originally, military organizations). Logistics involve the integration of information, transportation, inventory, warehousing, material-handling, and packaging.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Logistyka jest terminem opisujácym proces planowania, realizowania i kontrolowania sprawnego i efektywnego ekonomicznie przepôywu surowców, materiaôów, wyrobów gotowych oraz odpowiedniej informacji z punktu pochodzenia do punktu konsumpcji w celu zaspokojenia wymagañ klienta[1]. Dziaôania logistyczne mogá obejmowaâ (choâ nie muszá siê do nich ograniczaâ): obsôugê klienta, prognozowanie popytu, przepôyw informacji, kontrolê zapasów, czynnoäci manipulacyjne, realizowanie zamówieñ, czynnoäci reparacyjne i zaopatrywanie w czêäci, lokalizacjê zakôadów produkcyjnych i skôadów, procesy zaopatrzeniowe, pakowanie, obsôugê zwrotów, gospodarowanie odpadami, transport i skôadowanie.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Amateurs talk tactics, dilettantes talk strategy, and professionals talk logistics." - General Omar Bradley
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Les Amateurs parlent de tactiques, les dilettentes parlent de Stratégie, et les professionnels parlent de logistique." - General Omar Bradley
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Amatorzy omawiajá taktykê, dyletanci omawiajá strategiê, a profesjonaliäci omawiajá logistykê." - General Omar Bradley

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Logistics[COLOR_REVERT] grants +1 trade route per city. It enables your cities to construct [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]International Ports[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Military Bases[COLOR_REVERT] and build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Pentagon[COLOR_REVERT] wonder.
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]logistique[COLOR_REVERT] ajoute une route commerciale par ville. Cette tech. permet de construire des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]ports internationaux[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]bases militaires[COLOR_REVERT] et de construire la merveille mondiale du [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Pentagone[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Machine Learning
TEXT.French: Machines cognitives
TEXT.Polish: Uczenie Maszynowe

TEXT.English: [TAB]Cognitive robotics is concerned with endowing robots with mammalian and human-like cognitive capabilities to enable the achievement of complex goals in complex environments. Cognitive robotics is focused on using animal cognition as a starting point for the development of robotic computational algorithms, as opposed to more traditional Artificial Intelligence techniques, which may or may not draw upon mammalian and human cognition as an inspiration for algorithm development. Robotic cognitive capabilities include perception processing, attention allocation, anticipation, planning, reasoning about other agents, and perhaps reasoning about their own mental states. Robotic cognition embodies the behaviour of intelligent agents in the physical world (or a virtual world, in the case of simulated CR). In the most ambitious version, this implies that the robot must also be able to act in this real world.[PARAGRAPH:2]Cognitive robotics involves the application and integration of various artificial intelligence disciplines but is primarily inspired by psychology and brain science research. On the other hand, the robot capabilities will be limited by the current state of the art in robotics: the mechanics and electronics of robots are still very inferior to what humans have available, especially in the areas of tactile and visual sensing, the smoothness and energy efficiency of motion (including walking and object manipulation with fingers), and the task-directed planning of actions.[PARAGRAPH:2]One of the learning techniques that are used for robots is learning by imitation: the robot, provided with all the sensors and physical hardware needed to perform a human task, is monitoring the human performing a task, and then the robot tries to imitate the same movements that the human performed in order to achieve the task. Using its sensors, the robot should be able to create a three-dimensional image of the environment, and to recognize the objects in that image. A major challenge is hence to interpret the scene, and to understand what objects are needed in the task and which are not.[PARAGRAPH:2]A more complex learning approach is autonomous knowledge acquisition: the robot now uses its sensors and its knowledge about the physical properties of the world, and is then left to explore the environment on its own. One of the terminologies of this behaviour is called motor babbling. Basically the whole idea of this approach is to let the robot discover its capabilities on its own.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Robotyka kognitywna (ang. cognitive robotics) zajmuje siê rozwojem i budowá robotów o wysokich zdolnoäciach kognitywnych, potrafiácych wykonaâ skomplikowane zadania w zôoëonym ärodowisku przy wykorzystaniu ograniczonych zasobów.Do robotycznych zdolnoäci kognitywnych zalicza siê przetwarzanie postrzegania, przydzielanie uwagi, przewidywanie, planowanie, äwiadomoäâ istnienia innych obiektów, rozumowanie stanów mentalnych innych obiektów. Kognitywistyka robotyczna wyraëa postêpowanie obiektów inteligentnych w äwiecie fizycznym (lub w äwiecie wirtualnym - w przypadku symulacji kognitywistyki robotycznej).

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Making realistic robots is going to polarize the market, if you will. You will have some people who love it and some people who will really be disturbed." - David Hanson
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Faire des robots réalistes va 'polariser' le marché, si vous voulez. Il aura les gens qui vont adoer, et ceux qui vont vraiment être dérangés." - David Hanson
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]Robot nie moëe skrzywdziâ istoty ludzkiej lub pozwoliâ, by staôa siê jej krzywda. Robot musi wypeôniaâ rozkazy istoty ludzkiej, o ile nie pogwaôci tym samym Pierwszego Prawa. Robot musi chroniâ sam siebie, o ile nie pogwaôci tym samym Pierwszego lub Drugiego Prawa" - Trzy Prawa Robotyki

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Machine Learning[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to train [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Constructor Ships[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Global Hawks[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]robotique cognitive[COLOR_REVERT] permet de recruter des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]constructeurs de bateaux[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Global Hawks[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Machine Tools
TEXT.French: Machines-outils
TEXT.Polish: Narzêdzia Mechaniczne

TEXT.English: [TAB]One of the most important steps in the move toward industrialization was the ability to precisely shape or "machine" solid metal into a desired form. Through mechanical, chemical, and other means, machine tools mold and shape raw materials into precision parts for complex machinery. The first machine tool, a horizontal boring device, was produced in the late 1700's. The development of measuring devices accurate to within a millionth of an inch allowed for the mass production of items with interchangeable parts. The technology of the 20th century has produced computer-controlled machine tools that can be adapted to a wide variety of applications. The speed and accuracy of these machines allows for the economical mass production of extremely complex products.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Obrabiarka to maszyna do mechanicznej obróbki przedmiotów w celu nadania im okreälonych ksztaôtów, wymiarów i wykoñczenia powierzchni. Obróbka realizowana jest za pomocá narzêdzi.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"When a machine begins to run without human aid, it is time to scrap it - whether it be a factory or a government" - Alexander Chase
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Quand une machine commence à fonctionner sans l'aide de l'homme, il est temps de le mettre au rebut - qu'il s'agisse d'une usine ou d'un gouvernement" - Alexander Chase
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Kaëdy wynalazek mechaniczny jest éródôem irytacji. Ludzkoäâ charakteryzuje siê gôêboká i odwieczná nieufnoäciá wobec maszyn. Psychologowie nazywajá to instynktowná reakcjá ëycia na pseudoëycie. - Anonim

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Machine Tools[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Canneries[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Drydocks[COLOR_REVERT] and improves the food production of [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Farms[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]machines-outils[COLOR_REVERT] permettent la construction d'une [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]conserverie[COLOR_REVERT] et d'une [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]cale sèche[COLOR_REVERT]. Les [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]fermes[COLOR_REVERT] produisent plus de nourriture.

TEXT.English: Magnetic Levitation
TEXT.French: Lévitation magnétique
TEXT.Polish: Lewitacja Magnetyczna

TEXT.English: [TAB]Magnetic levitation, maglev, or magnetic suspension is a method by which an object is suspended with no support other than magnetic fields. The electromagnetic force is used to counteract the effects of the gravitational force.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Pole magnetyczne umoëliwia prawdziwá lewitacjê, tj. bez mechanicznego kontaktu z lewitujácym obiektem. W zaleënoäci od ôadunku lub bieguna magnetycznego ciaôa wzajemnie siê przyciágajá lub odpychajá równowaëác w ten sposób siôê ciêëkoäci. Istotnym praktycznym problemem jest tu jednak fakt, ëe nie istnieje statyczny stabilny ukôad siô magnetycznych czy elektrostatycznych umoëliwiajácy lewitacjê, co jest treäciá twierdzenia Earnshawa, które stwierdza, ëe siôy odpychania zaleëne od odlegôoäci jako odwrotnoäâ kwadratu odlegôoäci tworzá niestabilne ukôady równowagi. Istnieje jednak mimo to kilka metod uzyskania stabilnej lewitacji przy uëyciu pola magnetycznego (czy elektrostatycznego).

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Magnetic levitation, maglev (noun) - high-speed rail technology; train is suspended on a magnetic cushion above a magnetized track and so travels free of friction"
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Lévitation Magnétique ou MagLev (nom) - Technologie ferroviaire à grande vitesse; le Train est suspendu sur un coussin magnétique au-dessus d'une rail magnétisée et donc se déplace librement sans frottement"
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Oto moja nauka: kto chce siê kiedyä nauczyâ lataâ, musi siê najpierw nauczyâ staâ, chodziâ, biegaâ, skakaâ, wspinaâ i tañczyâ; latajác nie nauczyâ siê w lot lataâ!" - Fryderyk Nietzsche

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Magnetic Levitation[COLOR_REVERT] enables construction of the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Maglev[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]lévitation magnétique[COLOR_REVERT] permet la construction du [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]maglev[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Manufacturing
TEXT.French: Fabrication de masse
TEXT.Polish: Produkcja Przemysôowa

TEXT.English: [TAB]Manufacturing is the use of tools and labour to make things for use or sale. The term may refer to a vast range of human activity, from handicraft to high tech, but is most commonly applied to industrial production, in which raw materials are transformed into finished goods on a large scale.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Produkcja jest uëyciem narzêdzi i pracowników, by wytworzyâ rzeczy dla uëytku lub sprzedaëy. Pojêcie moëe odnosiâ siê do ludzkiej aktywnoäci, od rzemiosôa do wyokiej technologii, ale przewaënie odnosi siê do produkcji przemysôowej, w której surowce przeksztaôcane sá w gotowe dobra na duëá skalê.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"A manufacturing district... sends out, as it were, suckers into all its neighbourhood." - Henry Hallam
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Un district de fabrication ... envoie, pour ainsi dire, des pistons dans tous ses environs." - Henry Hallam
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Nie naleëy lekcewaëyâ drobnostek, bo od nich zaleëy doskonaôoäâ." - Michaô Anioô

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Manufacturing[COLOR_REVERT] allows cities to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Manufacturing Plants[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Food Processing Plants[COLOR_REVERT] and train [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Jeeps[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Modern Infantry[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]fabrication de masse[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]complexe industriel[COLOR_REVERT] et une [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]usine agro-alimentaire[COLOR_REVERT]. Les villes peuvent recruter de l'[COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]infanterie moderne[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Jeeps[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Marxism
TEXT.French: Marxisme
TEXT.Polish: Marksizm

TEXT.English: [TAB]Marxism, economic and political philosophy named for Karl Marx. It is also known as scientific (as opposed to utopian) socialism. Marxism has had a profound impact on contemporary culture; modern communism is based on it, and most modern socialist theories derive from. It has also had tremendous effect on academia, influencing disciplines from economics to philosophy and literary history. [PARAGRAPH:2]Although no one treatise by Marx and his coworker Friedrich Engels covers all aspects of Marxism, the Communist Manifesto suggests many of its premises, and the monumental Das Kapital develops many of them most rigorously. Many elements of the Marxist system were drawn from earlier economic and historical thought, notably that of Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel, the comte de Saint-Simon, J. C. L. de Sismondi, David Ricardo, Charles Fourier, and Louis Blanc; but Marxist analysis as fully developed by Marx and Engels was unquestionably original. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Marxist philosophical method is dialectical materialism, a reversal of the dialectical idealism of Hegel. Dialectical materialism presumes the primacy of economic determinants in history. Through dialectical materialism was developed the fundamental Marxist premise that the history of society is the inexorable "history of class struggle." According to this premise, a specific class could rule only so long as it best represented the economically productive forces of society; when it became outmoded it would be destroyed and replaced. From this continuing dynamic process a classless society would eventually emerge. In modern capitalist society, the bourgeois (capitalist) class had destroyed and replaced the unproductive feudal nobility and had performed the economically creative task of establishing the new industrial order. The stage was thus set for the final struggle between the bourgeoisie, which had completed its historic role, and the proletariat, composed of the industrial workers, or makers of goods, which had become the true productive class.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Marksizm - w wáskim tego sôowa znaczeniu äwiatopoglád wywodzácy siê z pism Karola Marksa, czasami bôêdnie utoësamiany z materializmem dialektycznym. Teoria Marksa, nazwana przezeñ "materializmem historycznym", a przez Engelsa "socjalizmem naukowym" lub "materializmem dialektycznym", opiera siê na heglowskiej tezie, ëe historia przejawia siê w dialektyce - äcieraniu siê przeciwstawnych siô. Hegel byô filozofem idealistycznym i uwaëaô, ëe äwiat materialny jest äwiatem pozorów, natomiast rzeczywistoäâ jest idealna. Marks zaadaptowaô na potrzeby swojego systemu pojêcie dialektyki, odrzuciô jednak idealizm Hegla. Kontynuowaô tu materialistyczne idee Ludwika Feuerbacha. Podobnie jak Hegel i inni filozofowie, Marks odróëniaô pozory od rzeczywistoäci, jednak jego zdaniem tylko uwarunkowane historycznie i spoôecznie ideologie uniemoëliwiajá ludziom jasny oglád warunków materialnych w jakich ëyjá. Waëny wpôyw na poglády Marksa wywarôo dzieôo Engelsa Poôoëenie klasy robotniczej w Anglii w 1844 roku (1845), które nasunêôo Marksowi koncepcjê walki klasowej i poglád, ëe klasa robotnicza jest siôá spoôeczná, która dokona rewolucji. Marks rozwaëaô problem alienacji - dokonujác kolejnego zapoëyczenia od Hegla dokonaô jego reinterpretacji w duchu materializmu. Wedôug Marksa sytuacja, gdy ktoä rezygnuje z wôasnej siôy roboczej - wôasnej zdolnoäci przeksztaôcania äwiata - jest równoznaczne z alienacjá swojej natury. Marks opisaô formê alienacji jako fetyszyzm towarowy - jego zdaniem ludzie nabierajá przekonania, ëe rzeczy, które wytwarzajá, oraz narzêdzia produkcji majá samoistná wartoäâ, a nie wôoëona w produkty siôa robocza i wtedy sprowadzajá stosunki spoôeczne do wymiany handlowej.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"From each according to his abilities, to each according to his needs." - Karl Marx
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"De chacun selon ses capacités, à chacun selon ses besoins." - Karl Marx
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Kaëdy wedôug swych zdolnoäci, kaëdemu wedôug jego potrzeb." - Karol Marks

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Marxism[COLOR_REVERT] allows cities to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Police Stations[COLOR_REVERT] and enables the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Communalism[COLOR_REVERT] civic.
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]marxisme[COLOR_REVERT] permet la construction d'un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]poste de police[COLOR_REVERT] et active la doctrine du [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]communalisme[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Mass Transit
TEXT.French: Transports en commun
TEXT.Polish: Transport Masowy

TEXT.English: [TAB]Public transport, public transportation, public transit or mass transit comprise all transport systems in which the passengers do not travel in their own vehicles. While the above terms are generally taken to include rail and bus services, wider definitions might include scheduled airline services, ferries, taxicab services etc. — any system that transports members of the general public. -- Wikipedia
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Transport miejski – sfera dziaôalnoäci gospodarczej polegajácej na wykonywaniu usôug przewozowych na terenie miasta oraz obszarach podmiejskich. Problematyka transportu miejskiego dotyka w gôównej mierze zagadnieñ transportu pasaëerskiego, wiêc termin ten bywa stosowany zamiennie z terminem komunikacja miejska[1]. Ze wzglêdu na wykorzystywane ärodki transportu wyróëniâ moëna miejski transport szynowy, miejski transport drogowy, miejski transport wodny.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Beyond highways and roads, we need more money for mass transit, intercity passenger rail and freight rail. We have a long way to go to bridge the funding gaps." - Bill Lipinski
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Au-delà des routes et autoroutes, nous avons besoin de plus d'argent pour le transport en commun, des voyageurs ferroviaires interurbains et du fret ferroviaire. Nous avons un long chemin à parcourir pour combler les déficits de financement." - Bill Lipinski
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Jedyny sposób, jaki odkryôem, aby zdáëyâ na pociág, to spóéniâ siê na poprzedni." - Gilbert Keith Chesterton

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Mass Transit[COLOR_REVERT] allows cities to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Public Transportation[COLOR_REVERT] and workers to build [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Highways[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]transport de masse[COLOR_REVERT] permet aux villes de déployer un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]transport public[COLOR_REVERT] et aux ouvriers de déployer des [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]autoroutes[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Matchlock
TEXT.French: Mèche
TEXT.Polish: Zamek Lontowy

TEXT.English: [TAB]The first hand guns that were used were very simple affairs, and were very slow to reload, had a very short range and were very heavy, as well as being inaccurate. The one major advantage that hand guns offered was that virtually no training was required to be proficient in their use, as compared to the amount of time that training to use a longbow required. To ignite the gunpowder in these simple guns, a burning taper (or match) was applied to a hole in the gun where gunpowder would be poured. Although this ensured that gun would fire, it added to the slowness of the firearm, as well as rendering the gun useless in wet weather. So although it was a useful tool on the battlefield, it was clear that there were many areas where advances would be made.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Zamek lontowy to zamek rêcznej broni palnej odprzodowej, w którym zapalenie prochu nastêpuje od palácego siê lontu. Lont zamocowany byô w uchwycie, który po naciäniêciu déwigni (spustu) opadaô na panewkê, powodujác zapalenie siê podsypanego tam prochu, a nastêpnie poprzez zapaô, odpalenie prochu w lufie. Zamek lontowy byô pierwszym typem zamka do broni palnej, powstaô w poôowie XV wieku i uëywany byô do poczátku XVII wieku. Wczeäniej, odpalanie broni byôo wykonywane za pomocá lontu przystawianego rêcznie; zamek lontowy automatyzowaô tá czynnoäâ, pozwalajác na wycelowanie broni. Byô prosty w konstrukcji, posiadaô jednak niedogodnoäci, jak koniecznoäâ wczeäniejszego zapalenia lontu oraz wraëliwoäâ na zôá pogodê. Jedynie czêäciowo zostaô wyparty przez zamek koôowy, a ostatecznie wyparty przez zamek skaôkowy. Zamek lontowy posiadaô m.in. muszkiet. W Europie zamki lontowe stosowane byôy wyôácznie w broni dôugiej. W Japonii konstruowano równieë pistolety z tym zamkiem. Broni z zamkiem lontowym uëywano tam do poôowy XIX w.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"History teaches that all conquerors who have allowed their subject races to carry arms have prepared their own downfall by doing so." - Adolf Hitler
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"L'histoire nous enseigne que tous les conquérants qui ont permis à leurs races soumises à porter les armes ont préparé leur propre ruine en faisant cela." - Adolf Hitler
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Im wiêcej dany kraj produkuje broni, tym mniej bezpieczny siê staje - ten, kto ma broñ, stanowi cel ataku." - Albert Einstein

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Matchlock[COLOR_REVERT] allows cities to train [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Arquebusiers[COLOR_REVERT] and enables the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Pinch I[COLOR_REVERT] promotion.
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]mèche[COLOR_REVERT] permet aux villes de recruter des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]arquebusiers[COLOR_REVERT] et active la promotion [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]tenaille I[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Mechanized Warfare
TEXT.Polish: Wojna Zmechanizowana

TEXT.English: [TAB]Mechanized warfare or tank warfare is the use of armoured fighting vehicles in modern warfare. It is a major component of modern methods of war. The premise of mechanized warfare rests on the ability of troops to penetrate conventional infantry-held defensive lines through use of manoeuvre of vehicles that offer protection from infantry weapons, and are able to defeat enemy supporting artillery with their own weapons included in the design, commonly a high velocity gun and machine guns.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Wojna mechaniczna nie byôa pomysôem niemieckich sztabowców, ale wôaänie oni zastosowali já na duëá skalê. Szybko jednak przerosôa ona moëliwoäci niemieckiego przemysôu. Do sprawnego zaopatrywania armii zabrakôo Niemcom samochodów i paliwa. W 1940 roku niemieckie wojska miaôy 120 tys. samochodów ciêëarowych, we Francji zdobyôy drugie tyle francuskich i brytyjskich.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"The best way to avoid warfare is if no one shows up." - Justin Sane
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"La meilleure façon d'éviter la guerre est si personne ne se présente." - Justin Sane
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Moi ëoônierze mogá zjeäâ swoje paski, ale moje czoôgi potrzebujá paliwa." - George Patton

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Mechanized Warfare[COLOR_REVERT] allows training [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Bazookas[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Light Tanks[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Tanks[COLOR_REVERT], and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Heavy Tanks[COLOR_REVERT] on land, and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Cruisers[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Heavy Cruisers[COLOR_REVERT], and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Battleships[COLOR_REVERT] to rule the seas.
TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]infanterie mécanisée[COLOR_REVERT] permet de recruter des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]bazookas[COLOR_REVERT], des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]chars légers[COLOR_REVERT], des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]chars[COLOR_REVERT], et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]chars lourds[COLOR_REVERT] sur terre, et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]croiseurs[COLOR_REVERT], des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]croiseurs lourds[COLOR_REVERT], et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]cuirassés[COLOR_REVERT] pour diriger les océans.

TEXT.English: Megacorporations
TEXT.French: Multinationales
TEXT.Polish: Megakorporacje

TEXT.English: "Greed, for lack of a better word, is good." - Gordon Gekko
TEXT.French: L'avarice, bien qu'il n'y ait de meilleur mot, est bonne - Gordon Gekko

TEXT.English: In cyberpunk and other science fiction stories, a megacorporation is an incredibly large corporation, always multi-national in size and frequently a monopoly or near-monopoly over one or more industries. Megacorporations always command vast wealth and assets, often including military forces that rival national armies. In some stories, megacorporations are the de facto government in certain places. In other stories, megacorporations are the only government, often operating in a kind of revived feudalism.

[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Megacorporations[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Global Stock Exchange[COLOR_REVERT] Wonder and the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Zurich-Orbital[COLOR_REVERT] Project. The first civilization to discover this technology receives a free [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Great Merchant[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]multinationales[COLOR_REVERT] vous permettent de construire la [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]bourse des valeurs mondialisée[COLOR_REVERT] (merveille) et le projet "[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Zurich-Orbital[COLOR_REVERT]". La première civilisation à découvrir cette technologie reçoit un [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]marchand illustre[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Megastructure Engineering
TEXT.French: Ingénierie des méga-structures
TEXT.Polish: Inëynieria Ekstremalna

TEXT.English: [TAB]Megastructure engineering is a form of exploratory engineering concerned with the construction of structures on an enormous scale. Typically these structures are at least 1,000 kilometers in length—in other words, at least 1 megameter, hence the name. Such large-scale structures are termed megastructures.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Inëynieria Ekstremalna jest formá inëynierii badawczej skoncentrowanej na budowaniu struktur o niewyobraëalnych rozmiarach. Typowe struktury majá okoôo 1 kilometr w dôugoäci innymi sôowy 1 mega-metr. Tak wielkie struktury okreälane sá jako megastruktury

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"We shape our buildings, thereafter they shape us. - Winston Churchill
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Nous façonnons nos bâtiments, par la suite, ils nous façonnent. - Winston Churchill
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Ksztaôtujemy budynki, nastêpnie one ksztaôtujá nas. - Winston Churchill

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Megastructure Engineering[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to construct [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Fusion Carriers[COLOR_REVERT] and build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Arcologies[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]ingénierie des superstructures[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]carrières à fusion[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]arcologies[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Mercantilism
TEXT.French: Mercantilisme
TEXT.Polish: Kupiectwo

TEXT.English: [TAB]Mercantilism, economic system of the major trading nations during the 16th, 17th, and 18th cent., based on the premise that national wealth and power were best served by increasing exports and collecting precious metals in return. It superseded the medieval feudal organization in Western Europe, especially in Holland, France, and England. The period 1500-1800 was one of religious and commercial wars, and large revenues were needed to maintain armies and pay the growing costs of civil government. [PARAGRAPH:2]Mercantilist nations were impressed by the fact that the precious metals, especially gold, were in universal demand as the ready means of obtaining other commodities; hence they tended to identify money with wealth. As the best means of acquiring bullion, foreign trade was favored above domestic trade, and manufacturing or processing, which provided the goods for foreign trade, was favored at the expense of the extractive industries (e.g., agriculture). [PARAGRAPH:2]State action, an essential feature of the mercantile system, was used to accomplish its purposes. Under a mercantilist policy a nation sought to sell more than it bought so as to accumulate bullion. Besides bullion, raw materials for domestic manufacturers were also sought, and duties were levied on the importation of such goods in order to provide revenue for the government. The state exercised much control over economic life, chiefly through corporations and trading companies. Production was carefully regulated with the object of securing goods of high quality and low cost, thus enabling the nation to hold its place in foreign markets. Treaties were made to obtain exclusive trading privileges, and the commerce of colonies was exploited for the benefit of the mother country. In England mercantilist policies were effective in creating a skilled industrial population and a large shipping industry. Through a series of Navigation Acts England finally destroyed the commerce of Holland, its chief rival. As the classical economists were later to point out, however, even a successful mercantilist policy was not likely to be beneficial, because it produced an oversupply of money and, with it, serious inflation. Mercantilist ideas did not decline until the coming of the Industrial Revolution and of laissez-faire. Henry VIII, Elizabeth I, and Oliver Cromwell conformed their policies to mercantilism. In France its chief exponent was Jean Baptiste Colbert.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Merkantylizm lub ustrój merkantylny – system pogládów ekonomiczno-politycznych, który pojawiô siê we wczesnym okresie nowoëytnoäci, wywodzácy siê z bulionizmu – teorii mówiácej, ëe posiadanie metali szlachetnych równa siê bogactwu.Termin merkantylizm zostaô ukuty w 1776 r. przez sôynnego ekonomistê Adama Smitha, który wywiódô go z ôaciñskiego sôowa mercari, oznaczajácego "handlowaâ", "prowadziâ handel", które z kolei pochodzi od sôowa merx oznaczajácego "towar". Poczátkowo uëywany byô wyôácznie przez swoich krytyków, do których zaliczaô siê teë Adam Smith.Wczeäniej termin merkantylizm pojawiô siê w 1664 r. w O zasadach merkantylizmu Jeana Baptiste Colberta.Ostatnim merkantylistá brytyjskim byô James Denham-Steuart (1712-1780).

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"A country that has no mines of its own must undoubtedly draw its gold and silver from foreign countries, in the same manner as one that has no vineyards of its own must draw its wines" - Adam Smith "The Wealth of Nations"
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Un pays qui n'a pas de mines doit sans aucun doute importer son or et son argent en provenance de pays étrangers, de la même manière que celui qui n'a pas ses propres vignes doivent importer ses vins" - Adam Smith "Le Bien-être des Nations"
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"W gruncie rzeczy okazuje siê, ëe pilnowanie pieniêdzy jest bardziej kôopotliwe nië ich zdobycie." - Michel de Montaigne

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Mercantilism[COLOR_REVERT] enables the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Mercantile[COLOR_REVERT] civic and the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Central Bank[COLOR_REVERT] National Wonder.
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]mercantilisme[COLOR_REVERT] active la doctrine [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]mercantilisme[COLOR_REVERT] et permet de construire la merveille nationale [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]banque centrale[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Mesh Networks
TEXT.French: Réseaux maillés
TEXT.Polish: Sieci Kratowe

TEXT.English: [TAB]Mesh networking is a way to route data, voice and instructions between nodes. It allows for continuous connections and reconfiguration around broken or blocked paths by “hopping” from node to node until the destination is reached. A mesh network whose nodes are all connected to each other is a fully connected network. Mesh networks differ from other networks in that the component parts can all connect to each other via multiple hops, and they generally are not mobile. Mesh networks can be seen as one type of ad hoc network. Mobile ad-hoc networking (MANet), and mesh networking are therefore closely related, but mobile ad hoc networks also have to deal with the problems introduced by the mobility of the nodes. -- Wikipedia
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Sieâ kratowa (ang. Mesh Network) – metoda trasowania danych, która daje moëliwoäâ ustanawiania staôych poôáczeñ w sieci zbudowanej z wielu, poôáczonych miêdzy sobá wêzôów. Jeäli nie wszystkie wêzôy mogá wymieniaâ siê bezpoärednio danymi miêdzy sobá, sá przesyôane przez sásiadów, czyli podobnie jak w sieciach P2P. Sieci tego typu potrafiá równieë dokonaâ automatycznej zmiany konfiguracji oraz naprawy w przypadku awarii niektórych wêzôów lub zmiany ich poôoëenia.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Describing the Internet as the Network of Networks is like calling the Space Shuttle, a thing that flies." - John Lester
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Décrivant l'Internet comme le réseau des réseaux est comme appeler la navette spatiale, 'une chose qui vole'." - John Lester
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Nie ma nic potêëniejszego nië idea, której czas nadszedô." - Don Tapscott

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Mesh Networks[COLOR_REVERT] enables cities to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Advanced Quality Control[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]réseaux maillés[COLOR_REVERT] permettent de construire le bâtiment de [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]contrôle qualité avancé[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Metallurgy
TEXT.French: Métallurgie
TEXT.Polish: Metalurgia

TEXT.English: [TAB]Metallurgy is the study of the properties of metals and the methods used to separate metal deposits from metal-bearing ores. Through the course of history, artisans have switched the materials from which they constructed weapons and tools to harder, more durable metals as they were discovered. However, metallurgy as a science wasn't studied in earnest until the powers of Europe began to compete against one another in an attempt to design better and more effective weapons starting around the 14th century. Constant improvements in metallurgy led to the discovery of new metals and alloys that were stronger, lighter and cheaper. As a result of this race for military dominance, Europeans produced some of the most advanced weaponry in the world during this time period.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Metalurgia jest nauká, która bada i opisuje sposoby otrzymywania metali oraz metody przeróbki otrzymanych metali w celu otrzymania odpowiednich wôasnoäci. Gôówne dziaôy to: metalurgia ëelaza i metalurgia metali nieëelaznych. Podstawowe procesy metalurgiczne to: przeróbka rudy, wzbogacanie rudy, proces hutniczy, rafinacja

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"The purest ore is produced from the hottest furnace, and the brightest thunderbolt is elicited from the darkest storm" - Charles Caleb Colton
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Le minerai le plus pur est produit par la fournaise la plus chaude, et l'éclair le plus brillant est visible dans la plus sombre de tempête" - Charles Caleb Colton
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Najczystsza ruda jest wytwarzana z najgorêtszego pieca a najjaäniejszy piorun tworzy siê z najciemniejszej burzy" - Charles Caleb Colton

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Metallurgy[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Foundry[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Star Fort[COLOR_REVERT] buildings and train [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Brigantine[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Sloop[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]métallurgie[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire une [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]fonderie[COLOR_REVERT], un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]fort en étoile[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]corvettes[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]brigantines[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Metamaterials
TEXT.French: Méta-matériaux
TEXT.Polish: Metamateriaôy

TEXT.English: [TAB]A metamaterial (or meta material) is a material which gains its properties from its structure rather than directly from its composition. To distinguish metamaterials from other composite materials, the metamaterial label is usually used for a material which has unusual properties. The term was coined in 1999 by Rodger M. Walser of the University of Texas at Austin. He defined metamaterials as: Macroscopic composites having a manmade, three-dimensional, periodic cellular architecture designed to produce an optimized combination, not available in nature, of two or more responses to specific excitation.[PARAGRAPH:2]Electromagnetics researchers often use the term quite narrowly for materials which exhibit negative refraction W.E. Kock developed the first metamaterials in the late 1940s with metal-lens antennae and metallic delay lenses.[PARAGRAPH:2]Metamaterials are of particular importance in electromagnetism (especially optics and photonics). They show promise for optical and microwave applications such as new types of beam steerers, modulators, band-pass filters, lenses, microwave couplers, and antenna radomes.[PARAGRAPH:2]A metamaterial affects electromagnetic waves by having structural features smaller than the wavelength of the electromagnetic radiation it interacts with. For instance, if a metamaterial is to behave as a homogeneous material accurately described by an effective refractive index, its features must be much smaller than the wavelength. For visible light, whose wavelength is less than one micrometre typically (560 nanometres for sunlight), the structures are generally half this size or smaller; i.e., less than 280 nanometres. For microwave radiation, the structures need only be on the order of one decimetre. Microwave frequency metamaterials are usually manmade, constructed as arrays of electrically conductive elements (such as loops of wire) which have suitable inductive and capacitive characteristics.[PARAGRAPH:2]Metamaterials usually consist of periodic structures, and thus have many similarities with photonic crystals and frequency selective surfaces. However, these are usually considered distinct from metamaterials, as their features are of similar size to the wavelength at which they function, and thus cannot be approximated as a homogeneous material.[PARAGRAPH:2]Metamaterials may be a possible basis for building a cloaking device. Such a device typically involves surrounding the object to be cloaked with a shell which affects the passage of light near it. On 14 February 2005, Andrea Alu and Nader Engheta at the University of Pennsylvania issued a research paper which claimed that plasmons could be used to cancel out visible light or radiation coming from an object. This 'plasmonic cover' would work by suppressing light scattering by resonating with illuminated light, which could render objects "nearly invisible to an observer." The plasmonic screen would have to be tuned to the object being hidden, and would only suppress a specific wavelength - an object made invisible in red light would still be visible in multiwavelength daylight.[PARAGRAPH:2]Metamaterials have been proposed for designing agile antennae. Research at the National Institute of Standards and Technology has demonstrated that thin metamaterial films can greatly reduce the size of resonating circuits that generate microwaves, potentially enabling even smaller cell phones and other microwave devices. It has been theorized that metamaterials could be built to bend matter around them because of the subatomic properties of matter. Such a matter cloak could for example bend a bullet around a person rather than absorb the impact as traditional bulletproof vests do.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Metamateriaô - materiaô którego wôasnoäci zaleëá od jego struktury w skali wiêkszej nië czásteczkowa, a nie jedynie od struktury czásteczkowej. Terminem tym w szczególnoäci okreäla siê materiaôy o wôasnoäciach nie wystêpujácych w naturalnie powstajácych materiaôach, np. tzw materiaôy lewoskrêtne. Majá one szczególne znaczenie w optyce i fotonice, gdzie ich wôasnoäci umoëliwiajá wytwarzanie nieklasycznych typów soczewek, anten, modulatorów i filtrów. Aby wpôywaâ na falê elektromagnetyczná, metamateriaô musi zawieraâ struktury o wielkoäci porównywalnej z dôugoäciá tej fali. Aby byô dla tej fali jednorodny i wpôyw na falê moëna byôo opisaâ za pomocá wspóôczynnika zaôamania, struktury te muszá byâ znacznie mniejsze od dôugoäci fali. Dla äwiatôa widzialnego (o dôugoäciach fali rzêdu 400-700 nm) uëywa siê metamateriaôów o strukturach wewnêtrznych rozmiaru rzêdu 250 nm. Dla mikrofal uëywa siê struktur o rozmiarach centymetrów. Przykôadem metamateriaôu dla äwiatôa widzialnego jest opal, w którym maôe kulki krystobalitu wywoôujá charakterystyczná grê barw. Metamateriaôy dla mikrofal sá wytwarzane sztucznie z drucianych pêtli i kratownic o odpowiedniej indukcyjnoäci i pojemnoäci elektrycznej. Materiaôy w których warstwy o róënych wspóôczynnikach zaôamania sá rozmieszczone okresowo nazywa siê krysztaôami fotonicznymi.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Inventing is a combination of brains and materials. The more brains you use, the less material you need." - Charles F. Kettering
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Inventer, c'est une combinaison de matière grise et de matériaux. Plus vous utilisez de matière grise, moins vous avez besoin de matériel." - Charles F. Kettering
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Jesteämy z tego samego materiaôu co nasze sny." - William Shakespeare

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Metamaterials[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Naval Yard[COLOR_REVERT] building and the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Command Center[COLOR_REVERT] improvement.
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]méta-matériaux[COLOR_REVERT] permettent de construire une [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]base navale[COLOR_REVERT] et l'aménagement de[COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]centre de commandement[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Meteorology
TEXT.French: Météorologie
TEXT.Polish: Meteorologia

TEXT.English: “The icy layers of the upper atmosphere contain conundrums enough to be worthy of humanity's greatest efforts.” - Hugo Emil Hergesell
TEXT.French: “Les couches de glace de la haute atmosphère contiennent des énigmes dignes des plus grands efforts de l'humanité.” - Hugo Emil Hergesell

TEXT.English: Meteorology is the interdisciplinary scientific study of the atmosphere that focuses on weather processes and forecasting (in contrast with climatology). Studies in the field stretch back millennia, though significant progress in meteorology did not occur until the eighteenth century. The nineteenth century saw breakthroughs occur after observing networks developed across several countries. Breakthroughs in weather forecasting were achieved in the latter half of the twentieth century, after the development of the computer. [NEWLINE] [TAB] Meteorological phenomena are observable weather events which illuminate and are explained by the science of meteorology. Those events are bound by the variables that exist in Earth's atmosphere. They are temperature, air pressure, water vapor, and the gradients and interactions of each variable, and how they change in time. The majority of Earth's observed weather is located in the troposphere. Different spatial scales are studied to determine how systems on local, region, and global levels impact weather and climatology. Meteorology, climatology, atmospheric physics, and atmospheric chemistry are sub-disciplines of the atmospheric sciences. Meteorology and hydrology compose the interdisciplinary field of hydrometeorology. Interactions between Earth's atmosphere and the oceans are part of coupled ocean-atmosphere studies. Meteorology has application in many diverse fields such as the military, energy production, transport, agriculture and construction.
[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Meteorology[COLOR_REVERT] improves the operational range of all your Air units by 1. It also allows construction of the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]National Weather Service[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]météorologie[COLOR_REVERT] améliore la portée opérationnelle de toutes vos unités aériennes de 1. Cela permet l'instauration d'un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]centre météorologique national[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Micromechanics
TEXT.French: Micro-mécanique
TEXT.Polish: Mikromechanika

TEXT.English: [TAB]Micromechanics is the analysis of composite or heterogeneous materials on the level of the individual phases that constitute these materials. [PARAGRAPH:2]Heterogeneous materials, such as composites, solid foams and polycrystals, consist of clearly distinguishable constituents (or phases) that show different mechanical and physical material properties. [PARAGRAPH:2]Given the material properties (or the nonlinear response) of the constituents, one important goal of micromechanics consists in predicting the properties (or the nonlinear response) of the heterogeneous material on the basis of the geometries and properties of the individual phases, a task known as homogenization. The benefit of homogenization is that the behavior of a heterogeneous material can be determined without resorting to testing it. Such tests may be expensive and may involve a large number of permutations (e.g., in the case of composites, constituent material combinations, fiber/particle volume fractions, fiber/particle arrangements, and processing histories). Furthermore, continuum micromechanics can predict the full multi-axial properties and response of inhomogeneous materials, which often are anisotropic. Such properties are often difficult to measure experimentally, but they are required, e.g., for structural analysis involving composites. Of course, to rely on micromechanics, the particular micromechanics theory must be validated through comparison to experimental data. [PARAGRAPH:2]The second main task of continuum micromechanics is localization, which aims at evaluating the local (stress and strain) fields in the phases for given macroscopic load states, phase properties and phase geometries. Such knowledge is especially important in understanding and describing material damage and failure. [PARAGRAPH:2]As implied by its name, continuum micromechanics is based on the methods of continuum mechanics rather than atomistic approaches such as molecular dynamics. In addition to the mechanical responses of inhomogeneous materials their thermal conduction behavior and related problems can be studied with the analytical and numerical methods of continuum micromechanics.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Mikromechanika, mikrotechnika, dziaô techniki zajmujácy siê projektowaniem, wytwarzaniem i eksploatacjá mikromechanizmów — urzádzeñ mech. lub elektromech. o bardzo maôych wymiarach (nawet poniëej kilku µm).

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Golfers are forever working on mechanics. My tennis swing hasn't changed in 10 years." - Pete Sampras
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Les golfeurs sont toujours en train de travailler des mécaniques. Mon swing de tennis n'a pas changé en 10 ans." - Pete Sampras
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"640 KB pamiêci operacyjnej powinno kaëdemu wystarczyâ." - Bill Gates

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Micromechanics[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]NLOS Cannon[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]micro-mécanique[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire le [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]canon NLOS[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Microprocessor
TEXT.French: Micro-processeur
TEXT.Polish: Mikroprocesor

TEXT.English: [TAB]A microprocessor incorporates most or all of the functions of a central processing unit (CPU) on a single integrated circuit (IC).
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Mikroprocesor to ukôad cyfrowy wykonany jako pojedynczy ukôad scalony o wielkim stopniu integracji zdolny do wykonywania operacji cyfrowych wedôug dostarczonego ciágu instrukcji. Mikroprocesor (w skrócie µP) ôáczy funkcje centralnej jednostki obliczeniowej (CPU) w pojedynczym póôprzewodnikowym ukôadzie scalonym. Pierwszy mikroprocesor dziaôaô w oparciu o sôowa 4-bitowe, dziêki czemu tranzystory tworzáce jego obwody logiczne mogôy zmieäciâ siê w jednym ukôadzie. Mikroprocesor umoëliwiô rozwój mikrokomputerów w poôowie lat 70. dwudziestego wieku. Przed tym okresem, elektroniczne CPU byôy konstruowane z zajmujácych wiele miejsca indywidualnych urzádzeñ przeôáczajácych, z których kaëde byôo odpowiednikiem zaledwie kilku tranzystorów. Poprzez zintegrowanie procesora w jeden lub kilka obwodów scalonych o coraz wyëszej skali integracji (zawierajácych odpowiednik tysiêcy lub milionów tranzystorów), stosunek moëliwoäci do ceny procesora znaczáco wzrósô. Od poôowy lat siedemdziesiátych, dziêki intensywnemu rozwojowi ukôadów scalonych, mikroprocesor staô siê najbardziej rozpowszechnioná formá CPU, prawie caôkowicie zastêpujác wszystkie inne..

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"They put over 100 million gates/transistors on a tiny piece of silicon. On that piece of silicon there are more lines than there are on a roadmap of London - and they work. There are very very few errors in a microprocessor." -Alan Cox
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Ils ont mis plus de 100 millions de portes/transistors sur un minuscule morceau de silicium. Sur ce morceau de silicium, il y a plus de lignes que sur un plan de Londres - et ils fonctionnent. Il y a très très peu d'erreurs dans un microprocesseur." -Alan Cox

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Microprocessor[COLOR_REVERT] allows cities to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Solar Plants[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]micro-processeur[COLOR_REVERT] permet aux villes de construire des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]centrales solaires[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Military Robotics
TEXT.French: Robotique à usage militaire
TEXT.Polish: Robotyka Wojskowa

TEXT.English: [TAB]Military robots are autonomous or remote-controlled devices designed for military applications. [PARAGRAPH:2]There are many advantages in robotic technology in warfare however, as outlined by Major Kenneth Rose of the US Army's Training and Doctrine Command: "Machines don't get tired. They don't close their eyes. They don't hide under trees when it rains and they don't talk to their buddies ... A human's attention to detail on guard duty drops dramatically in the first 30 minutes ... Machines know no fear."
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Roboty w sôuëbie prawa. Najczêstszym zastosowaniem w tej dziedzinie jest rozbrajanie bomb. Roboty produkowane do tego celu majá postaâ bardzo stabilnej ruchomej platformy, na której zamocowana jest kamera i silne éródôo äwiatôa. Robot taki, kontrolowany zdalnie przez operatora, jest w stanie rozbroiâ bombê lub przy pomocy manipulatora przenieäâ já w miejsce gdzie detonacja nie wyrzádzi nikomu szkody. Jednym z takich robotów produkowanych seryjnie jest Mini-Andros. Innym ciekawym robotem jest Papero - niewielki gadajácy robot , który pomaga zagranicznym turystom jako tôumacz na lotnisku Narita pod Tokio. Z kolei Artemis to robot patrolujácy japoñskie centrum handlowe i wszczynajácy alarm (lub przekazuje informacje drogá bezprzewodowá na posterunek), gdy zauwaëy coä podejrzanego. Bear to robot - sanitariusz do celów militarnych.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"The danger of the future is that men may become robots. True enough, robots do not rebel. But given man’s nature, robots cannot live and remain sane, they become "Golems," they will destroy their world and themselves because they cannot stand any longer the boredom of a meaningless life." - Erich Fromm
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Le danger de l'avenir est que les hommes peuvent devenir des robots. Certes, les robots ne se révoltent pas. Mais étant donné la nature humaine, les robots ne peuvent pas vivre et rester sains d'esprit, ils deviennent des "Golems," ils vont détruire leur monde et eux-mêmes parce qu'ils ne peuvent plus tenir l'ennui d'une vie dénuée de sens." - Erich Fromm
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Staôo siê przeraéliwie oczywiste, ëe technologie wyprzedziôy juë nasze czôowieczeñstwo." - Albert Einstein

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Military Robotics[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to train [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Walker Droid[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Littoral Combat Ship[COLOR_REVERT], and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Precision Attack Missile[COLOR_REVERT]. It also allows building [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Anti-Missile Batteries[COLOR_REVERT] and enables the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Unmanned Warfare[COLOR_REVERT] civic.
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]robots militaires[COLOR_REVERT] permettent de construire des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]droïdes marcheurs[COLOR_REVERT], des[COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]vaisseaux de combat côtier[COLOR_REVERT], et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]missiles de précision[COLOR_REVERT]. La technologie permet de bâtir des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]batteries anti-missile[COLOR_REVERT] et d'activer la doctrine [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]armée droïde[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Mind Uploading
TEXT.French: Téléversement de la pensée
TEXT.Polish: Superinteligencja

TEXT.English: [TAB]Mind uploading, whole brain emulation or mind transfer refers to the hypothetical process of scanning and mapping a biological brain in detail and copying its state into a computer system or another computational device, for example an artificial neural network in hardware. The computer runs a simulation model so faithful to the original that it will behave in essentially the same way as the original brain, or for all practical purposes, indistinguishable. [PARAGRAPH:2]Whole brain emulation is discussed as a logical endpoint of the topical computational neuroscience and neuroinformatics fields, both about brain simulation for medical research purposes. It is discussed in artificial intelligence research publications as an approach to strong AI. Among futurists and within the transhumanist philosophy it is an important proposed life extension technology, originally suggested in biomedical literature in 1971. It is a central conceptual feature of numerous science fiction novels and films. Whole brain simulation is considered by some scientists as a theoretical and futurustic but possible technology. Substantial mainstream research and development are being done in relevant areas including development of faster computers, animal brain mapping and simulation, and information extraction from dynamically functioning brains. [PARAGRAPH:2]The human brain contains about 100 billion nerve cells called neurons, each individually linked to other neurons by way of connectors called axons and dendrites. Signals at the junctures (synapses) of these connections are transmitted by the release and detection of chemicals known as neurotransmitters. It is established neuroscience consensus that the human mind is a largely an emergent property of the information processing of this neural network.[PARAGRAPH:2]Importantly, many leading neuroscientists have stated they believe important functions performed by the mind, such as learning, memory, and consciousness, are due to purely physical and electrochemical processes in the brain and are governed by applicable laws.[PARAGRAPH:2]The concept of mind uploading is based on this mechanistic view of the mind, and also relies on certain assumptions about the nature of human consciousness and the philosophy of artificial intelligence. It assumes that strong AI machine intelligence is not only possible, but is very similar to or indistinguishable from human intelligence, and denies the vitalist view of human life and consciousness.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]W nauce umysô jest zdefiniowany jako oärodek caôej, äwiadomej i nieäwiadomej psychiki czôowieka i jego myälenia. Wg paradygmatu nauki, umysô jest wynikiem struktury biologicznej, procesów chemicznych zachodzácych w naszym mózgu i jego interakcji ze äwiatem zewnêtrznym czôowieka. Jest tak skomplikowany ze wzglêdu na zôoëonoäâ tych procesów. Studiowaniem i modelowaniem wôasnoäci umysôu zajmuje siê psychologia, filozofia, kognitywistyka i dziaô informatyki zajmujácy siê Sztuczná Inteligencjá, np. ksiáëka "Artificial Minds" (Sztuczne Umysôy), Stan Franklin, 1998 (ang) gdzie pojêcie umysô jest äciäle zwiázane z pojêciem inteligencji i jej bardzo uproszczonymi komputerowymi symulacjami. Obecnie, dziêki "wybuchowemu" rozwojowi technologii komputerowych, problem syntetycznego uniwersalnego umysôu (jako formalnego autonomicznego systemu samo-äwiadomego i posiadajácego atrybuty inteligencji), staô siê teë dziedziná nowych badañ systemowych.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"The human mind is our fundamental resource." - John F. Kennedy
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"L'esprit humain est notre ressource fondamentale." - John F. Kennedy
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Wyobraénia jest waëniejsza od wiedzy, poniewaë wiedza jest ograniczona." - Albert Einstein

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Mind Uploading[COLOR_REVERT] allows construction of the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Mind Storage[COLOR_REVERT] National Wonder.
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]téléversement de la pensée[COLOR_REVERT] permet la construction d'une merveille national d'[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]entrepôt de mémoire[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Modern Art
TEXT.French: Art moderne
TEXT.Polish: Nowoczesna Sztuka

TEXT.English: "Most painting in the European tradition was painting the mask. Modern art rejected all that. Our subject matter was the person behind the mask." - Robert Motherwell
TEXT.French: La plupart des peintures de tradition européenne furent de peindre le masque. L'art moderne a rejetté tout ça. Notre sujet fut la personne derrière le masque. - Robert Motherwell

TEXT.English: Modern art is a general term for artworks produced from the 1860's to the 1970's that chose to reject traditional forms and embrace the experimental. Movements in modern art included Impressionism, Cubism, Expressionism, Futurism, and Surrealism. Dozens of different movements sprang up in different places and times.

[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Modern Art[COLOR_REVERT] increases the culture production of your [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Theatres[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Art Galleries[COLOR_REVERT], and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Artist Guilds[COLOR_REVERT]. It allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Bauhaus School[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Cristo Redentor[COLOR_REVERT] wonders.
TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]art moderne[COLOR_REVERT] améliore la production de culture de vos [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]théatres[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]galleries d'art[COLOR_REVERT], et de la [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]guilde des artistes[COLOR_REVERT]. Il permet de construire les merveilles de l'[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]école de Bauhaus[COLOR_REVERT] et du [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Christ Rédempteur[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Modern Health Care
TEXT.French: Sécurité sociale
TEXT.Polish: Nowoczesna Opieka Zdrowotna

TEXT.English: [TAB]Health care systems vary around the world, reflecting customs and history. What all Health care has in common is the the treatment and management of illness, as well as the preservation of health through services offered by the medical, dental, pharmaceutical, clinical laboratory sciences, nursing, and allied health professions. Health care embraces all the goods and services designed to promote health, including preventive, curative and palliative interventions, whether directed to individuals or to populations.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]System opieki zdrowotnej, system zdrowotny definiowany jest jako spójna caôoäâ, której liczne, powiázane miêdzy sobá czêäci wspólnie oddziaôywajác wpôywajá pozytywnie na stan zdrowia populacji. Jest on wyodrêbnioná caôoäciá zôoëoná z wielu róënorodnych elementów, które powiázane sá róënorodnymi wiêziami (czyli miêdzy którymi zachodzá róënorodne relacje) i który realizuje cele zwiázane ze zdrowiem. System zdrowotny moëna równieë zdefiniowaâ jako zorganizowany i skoordynowany zespóô dziaôañ, którego celem jest realizacja äwiadczeñ i usôug profilaktyczno – leczniczych i rehabilitacyjnych majácych na celu zabezpieczenie i poprawê stanu zdrowia jednostki i zbiorowoäci.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Listen, if you're having trouble finding a vein for an IV, please don't page me. If you're desperate, we're lucky: this is a city hospital, there are plenty of heroin addicts who are quite adept at this." - J.D. "Scrubs"

TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Tym, kto szkodzi ludziom, nie sá zagraniczne firmy farmaceutyczne - tylko zbrodniarze (tak: ludobójcy) z Ministerstwa „Zdrowia” i „Opieki Spoôecznej” - narzucajácy ceny i zakazujácy sprzedaëy konkurencyjnych, tañszych leków." - Janusz Korwin-Mikke

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Modern Health Care[COLOR_REVERT] allows construction of the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Centers for Disease Control[COLOR_REVERT] and the [COLOR_PROJECT_TEXT]Penicillin[COLOR_REVERT] project.
