TEXT.English: Naval Cannon
TEXT.French: Canonnerie navale
TEXT.Polish: Dziaôo Okrêtowe

TEXT.English: [TAB]Naval artillery in the Age of Sail encompasses the period of roughly 1571-1863: when large, sail-powered wooden naval warships dominated the high seas, mounting a bewildering variety of different types and sizes of cannon as their main armament. By modern standards, these cannon were extremely inefficient, difficult to load, and short ranged. These characteristics, along with the handling and seamanship of the ships that mounted them, defined the environment in which the Naval tactics in the Age of Sail developed. [PARAGRAPH:2]Firing a naval cannon required a great amount of labour and manpower. Cannon used gunpowder as the propellant, whose bulk had to be kept in a special storage area below deck for safety. A typical broadside of a Royal Navy ship of the late 18th century could be fired 2-3 times in approximately 5 minutes, depending on the training of the crew, a well trained one being essential to the simple yet detailed process of preparing to fire. Ironically, the British Admiralty did not see fit to provide additional powder to captains to train their crews, generally only allowing 1/3 of the powder loaded onto the ship to be fired in the first six months of a typical voyage, barring hostile action. Instead of live fire practice, most captains exercised their crews by "running" the guns in and out — performing all the steps associated with firing but for the actual discharge. Some wealthy captains — those who had made money capturing prizes or from wealthy families - were known to purchase powder with their own funds to enable their crews to fire real discharges at real targets.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Dziaôo okrêtowe to dziaôo stosowane na okrêcie. Najczêäciej sá to konstrukcje zaprojektowane specjalnie w tym celu, ale zdarzajá siê teë dziaôa ládowe przystosowywane do montowania na pokôadach. Dziaôa takie majá specjalná podstawê morská. Dziaôa okrêtowe w dawnych czasach byôy montowane w ambrazurach, nastêpnie w kazamatach a obecnie w wieëach. Na mniejszych okrêtach spotyka siê montowanie dziaô bezpoärednio na pokôadzie bez wieëy. Takie montowanie wystêpowaôo na wiêkszoäci okrêtach podwodnych.Kalibry XX-wiecznych dziaô morskich wynoszá zwykle od 70 mm do 457 mm, zaä morskich dziaô przeciwlotniczych od 20 mm do 130 mm. Czêsto stosuje siê teë dziaôa uniwersalne, czyli dziaôa mogáce zwalczaâ cele nawodne (naziemne) i cele powietrzne. Pierwsze dziaôa okrêtowe pojawiôy siê w okolicach XIV wieku.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"The cannon will not suffer any other sound to be heard for miles and for years around it." - Ralph Waldo Emerson
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Le canon ne supportera aucun autre bruit à des kilomètres et des années autour de lui." - Ralph Waldo Emerson
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Polityk odpowiedzialny jest za statek a nie za fale." - Abraham Lincoln

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Naval Cannon[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to train [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Galleon[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Frigate[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Privateer[COLOR_REVERT] units and improves the output of [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Whaling Boats[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]canon naval[COLOR_REVERT] permet la construction de [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]galions[COLOR_REVERT], de [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]corsaires[COLOR_REVERT], de [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]frégates[COLOR_REVERT] et améliore le rendement des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]baleiniers[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Naval Tactics
TEXT.French: Tactiques navales
TEXT.Polish: Taktyka Morska

TEXT.English: [TAB]Naval tactics in the Age of Sail were primarily determined by the sailing and fighting qualities of the sailing warships of the time. Three factors, in particular, constrained what a sailing admiral could order his fleet to do.[PARAGRAPH:2]The first constraint was that, like all sailing vessels, sailing warships cannot sail directly into the wind. Most could sail not much closer than 70 degrees off the wind. This limited the maneuverability of a fleet during battles at close quarters.[PARAGRAPH:2]The second constraint was that the ships of the time carried their guns in two large batteries, one on each broadside, with only a few mounted to fire directly ahead or astern. The sailing warship was immensely powerful on its sides, but very weak on its bow and stern. The sides of the ship were built with strong timbers, but the stern, in particular, was fragile with a flimsy structure round the large windows of the officers’ cabins. The bows and, particularly, the sterns of the ship were vulnerable to raking fire. Raking another ship by firing the length of a ship from either the bow or stern caused tremendous damage, because a single shot would fly down the length of the decks, while the ship being raked could not return fire with her broadsides.[PARAGRAPH:2]The third constraint was the difficulty of communicating at sea. Written communication was almost impossible in a moving fleet, while hailing was extremely difficult above the noise of wind and weather. So admirals were forced to rely on a pre-arranged set of signal flags hoisted aboard the admiral's flagship. In the smoke of battle, these were often hard or impossible to see. -- Wikipedia
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Taktyka (gr. taktiká ) - teoria i praktyka posôugiwania siê jednostkami wojskowymi dla osiágniêcia zamierzonego celu. Taktyka jest najniëszym poziomem sztuki wojennej. Wyëszymi szczeblami sztuki wojennej sá: operacja i strategia.Taktyka dotyczy reguô uëycia stosunkowo niewielkich jednostek wojskowych zwanych zwiázkami taktycznymi. Jest sztuká osiágania zwyciêstwa (czy ogólniej: zamierzonych celów) w konkretnych warunkach. Przyjmuje siê teë, ëe taktyka dotyczy ograniczonej przestrzeni (np. do XX w. do terenu, który moëna objáâ wzrokiem) i czasu (rzêdu doby).Taktyka (w odróënieniu od sztuki operacyjnej i strategii) jest silnie zwiázana i zaleëna od zmian organizacyjnych i technicznych w wojsku. Przykôadowo kawaleria, której podstawowym sposobem uëycia (taktyká) przez wieki byôa szarëa wraz z wprowadzeniem karabinu maszynowego i szybkostrzelnej artylerii zaczêôa uëywaâ koni jedynie do szybkiego przemieszczania siê a do walki kawalerzyäci zsiadali z koni, wykonujác szarëê jedynie w wyjátkowych, sprzyjajácych okolicznoäciach. Nawet drobna zmiana w wyposaëeniu moëe skutkowaâ istotná zmianá sposobu walki (taktyki). Bardzo skuteczna taktyka wilczego stada polegajáca na grupowym ataku okrêtów podwodnych w nocy z wynurzenia musiaôa zostaâ porzucona po wprowadzeniu radaru.Taktyka moëe byâ teë specyficzna dla warunków terenowych lub pogodowych. Zdarza siê, ëe w sposób walki (taktyka) jest opracowywany na uëytek jednej bitwy, jak np. w przypadku ataku na Eben Emael.W innym ujêciu,- taktyka to bezpoärednia walka zbrojna, majáca na celu bezpoärednie zniszczenie (zgôadzenie, definitywne rozbicie) siô i ärodków walki, bez wzglêdu na ich wielkoäâ (skalê). Taktyka prowadzona jest w dwóch podstawowych rodzajach: natarciu i oporze, przy czym najczêäciej prowadzone sá one w formie pozycyjnej. Manewr w taktyce, zwôaszcza majácy na celu okráëenie (osaczenie) przeciwnika, jest bardzo rzadko stosowany. Najczêstszym manewrem taktycznym jest rotacja (luzowanie) jednostek tak w natarciu, jak i oporze.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"It follows than as certain as that night succeeds the day, that without a decisive naval force we can do nothing definitive, and with it, everything honorable and glorious." - President George Washington
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Il s'ensuit aussi certainement que la nuit succède au jour, que sans une force navale décisive nous ne pouvons faire rien de définitif, et avec elle, tout est honorable et glorieux." - Président George Washington
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Tak jak ta noc odnosi sukces nad dniem, tak my bez silnej marynarki nie moëemy zrobiâ niczego rozstrzygajácego i razem z tym, wszystkiego honorowego i chwalebnego." - President George Washington

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Naval Tactics[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to construct [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Man'O'War[COLOR_REVERT] and build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Naval Academy[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]tactiques navales[COLOR_REVERT] permettent de construire un [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Man'O'War[COLOR_REVERT] et une [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]académie navale[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Naval Warfare
TEXT.Spanish: Combate Naval

TEXT.English: [TAB][BOLD]Naval Warfare[\BOLD] is combat in and on seas, oceans, or any other major bodies of water such as large lakes and wide rivers.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]Mankind has fought battles on the sea for more than 3,000 years. Land warfare would seem, initially, to be irrelevant and entirely removed from warfare on the open ocean, though this is not necessarily true. Land navigation, until the advent of extensive railroads was extremely dependent upon river systems and canals. The latter were crucial in the development of the modern world in the United Kingdom, the Low Countries and northern Germany, for they enabled the bulk movement of goods and raw materials without which the industrial revolution would not have occurred. Prior to 1750, things moved by barge or sea, or not much at all. Thus armies, with their exorbitant needs for food, ammunition and fodder, were tied to the river valleys throughout the ages.[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:1]The many sea battles through history also provide a reliable source of shipwrecks for underwater archaeology. A major example, albeit not very commonly known, is the exploration of the wrecks of various battleships in the Pacific Ocean, namely Japanese warships that sank during the Battle of Midway.
[SPACE]"A good Navy is not a provocation to war. It is the surest guaranty of peace." - President Theodore Roosevelt
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Une bonne armée navale n'est pas une provocation à la Guerre. C'est la meilleure garantie de Paix." - President Theodore Roosevelt
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Dobra flota nie jest prowokacjá do wojny. To jest najpewniejsza gwarancja pokoju." - President Theodore Roosevelt

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Naval Warfare[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]War Galley[COLOR_REVERT] and enables the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Coastal Assault[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Coastal Guard[COLOR_REVERT] promotions.
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]navigation à voile[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]galères de guerre[COLOR_REVERT] et de distribuer les promotions [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]assaut côtier[COLOR_REVERT] et [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]garde-côte[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Navigation
TEXT.Polish: Nawigacja

TEXT.English: [TAB]In the early days of seafaring, sailors operated solely through a process known as "piloting", in which the position and course of the ship was determined by referring to geographical landmarks. The need to stay in view of the shore severely limited the extent of sea voyages. Through experience, sailors learned to apply the science of astronomy to their profession, noting the positions and movement of particular stars. They realized that even when the shore was out of sight, they could steer by certain reliable stars. This crude, yet practical application of astronomy allowed the adventurous to sail into the unknown with a reasonable chance of finding their way. As a result, ship building technology quickly improved, producing larger, more stable ships designed for longer voyages.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Nawigacja to dziaô wiedzy zajmujácy siê okreälaniem bieëácego poôoëenia oraz drogi do celu dla statków, pojazdów i innych przemieszczajácych siê obiektów.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Though pleas'd to see the dolphins play, I mind my compass and my way." - Matthew Green
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Bien qu'heureux de voir les dauphins jouer, Je m'occupe de ma boussole et mon chemin." - Matthew Green
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Chociaë chciaôbym zobaczyâ jak delfiny grajá, myälê caôy czas o moim kompasie i mojej drodze." - Matthew Green

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Navigation[COLOR_REVERT] increases the movement of all of your naval units by 1 and allows you to trade across [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Ocean[COLOR_REVERT] squares. It enables you to build [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Colonists[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Frigates[COLOR_REVERT] and the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Magellan's Voyage[COLOR_REVERT] Wonder.
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]navigation[COLOR_REVERT] augmente le mouvement de toutes les unités navales de 1 et vous permet de commerce à travers les cases d'[COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]océan[COLOR_REVERT]. Cela vous permet de recruter des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]colonisateurs[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]frégates[COLOR_REVERT] ainsi que la merveille mondiale du [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]voyage de Magellan[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Neural Networks
TEXT.French: Réseaux de neurones
TEXT.Polish: Sieci Neuronowe

TEXT.English: [TAB]Traditionally, the term neural network had been used to refer to a network or circuit of biological neurons. The modern usage of the term often refers to artificial neural networks, which are composed of artificial neurons or nodes. Thus the term has two distinct usages: [PARAGRAPH:2]1. Biological neural networks are made up of real biological neurons that are connected or functionally related in the peripheral nervous system or the central nervous system. In the field of neuroscience, they are often identified as groups of neurons that perform a specific physiological function in laboratory analysis. [PARAGRAPH:2]2. Artificial neural networks are made up of interconnecting artificial neurons (programming constructs that mimic the properties of biological neurons). Artificial neural networks may either be used to gain an understanding of biological neural networks, or for solving artificial intelligence problems without necessarily creating a model of a real biological system. The real, biological nervous system is highly complex and includes some features that may seem superfluous based on an understanding of artificial networks. [PARAGRAPH:2]In general a biological neural network is composed of a group or groups of chemically connected or functionally associated neurons. A single neuron may be connected to many other neurons and the total number of neurons and connections in a network may be extensive. Connections, called synapses, are usually formed from axons to dendrites, though dendrodendritic microcircuits and other connections are possible. Apart from the electrical signaling, there are other forms of signaling that arise from neurotransmitter diffusion, which have an effect on electrical signaling. As such, neural networks are extremely complex.[PARAGRAPH:2]Artificial intelligence and cognitive modeling try to simulate some properties of neural networks. While similar in their techniques, the former has the aim of solving particular tasks, while the latter aims to build mathematical models of biological neural systems. [PARAGRAPH:2]In the artificial intelligence field, artificial neural networks have been applied successfully to speech recognition, image analysis and adaptive control, in order to construct software agents (in computer and video games) or autonomous robots. Most of the currently employed artificial neural networks for artificial intelligence are based on statistical estimation, optimization and control theory.[PARAGRAPH:2]The cognitive modelling field involves the physical or mathematical modeling of the behaviour of neural systems; ranging from the individual neural level (e.g. modelling the spike response curves of neurons to a stimulus), through the neural cluster level (e.g. modelling the release and effects of dopamine in the basal ganglia) to the complete organism (e.g. behavioural modelling of the organism's response to stimuli). [PARAGRAPH:2]Neural networks, as used in artificial intelligence, have traditionally been viewed as simplified models of neural processing in the brain, even though the relation between this model and brain biological architecture is debated. A subject of current research in theoretical neuroscience is the question surrounding the degree of complexity and the properties that individual neural elements should have to reproduce something resembling animal intelligence. Historically, computers evolved from the von Neumann architecture, which is based on sequential processing and execution of explicit instructions. On the other hand, the origins of neural networks are based on efforts to model information processing in biological systems, which may rely largely on parallel processing as well as implicit instructions based on recognition of patterns of 'sensory' input from external sources. In other words, at its very heart a neural network is a complex statistical processor (as opposed to being tasked to sequentially process and execute). [PARAGRAPH:2]In modern software implementations of artificial neural networks the approach inspired by biology has more or less been abandoned for a more practical approach based on statistics and signal processing. In some of these systems neural networks, or parts of neural networks (such as artificial neurons) are used as components in larger systems that combine both adaptive and non-adaptive elements. [PARAGRAPH:2]The utility of artificial neural network models lies in the fact that they can be used to infer a function from observations and also to use it. This is particularly useful in applications where the complexity of the data or task makes the design of such a function by hand impractical. [PARAGRAPH:1]The tasks to which artificial neural networks are applied tend to fall within the following broad categories:[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Function approximation, or regression analysis, including time series prediction and modelling.[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Classification, including pattern and sequence recognition, novelty detection and sequential decision making.[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Data processing, including filtering, clustering, blind signal separation and compression.[PARAGRAPH:2]Application areas include system identification and control (vehicle control, process control), game-playing and decision making (backgammon, chess, racing), pattern recognition (radar systems, face identification, object recognition, etc.), sequence recognition (gesture, speech, handwritten text recognition), medical diagnosis, financial applications, data mining (or knowledge discovery in databases, "KDD"), visualization and e-mail spam filtering.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Sieâ neuronowa (sztuczna sieâ neuronowa) – ogólna nazwa struktur matematycznych i ich programowych lub sprzêtowych modeli, realizujácych obliczenia lub przetwarzanie sygnaôów poprzez rzêdy elementów, zwanych sztucznymi neuronami, wykonujácych pewná podstawowá operacjê na swoim wejäciu. Oryginalná inspiracjá takiej struktury byôa budowa naturalnych neuronów oraz ukôadów nerwowych, w szczególnoäci mózgu.Czasem nazwá sztuczne sieci neuronowe okreäla siê interdyscyplinarná dziedzinê wiedzy zajmujácá siê konstrukcjá, trenowaniem i badaniem moëliwoäci tego rodzaju sieci.Wspóôczeänie nie ma wátpliwoäci, ëe sztuczne sieci neuronowe nie stanowiá dobrego modelu mózgu, choâ róëne ich postaci wykazujá cechy charakterystyczne dla biologicznych ukôadów neuronowych: zdolnoäâ do uogólniania wiedzy, uaktualniania kosztem wczeäniej poznanych wzorców, dawanie mylnych odpowiedzi po przepeônieniu. Mimo uproszczonej budowy sztuczne sieci neuronowe stosuje siê czasem do modelowania schorzeñ mózgu.Sztuczne sieci neuronowe znajdujá zastosowanie w rozpoznawaniu i klasyfikacji wzorców (przydzielaniu wzorcom kategorii), predykcji szeregów czasowych, analizie danych statystycznych, odszumianiu i kompresji obrazu i déwiêku oraz w zagadnieniach sterowania i automatyzacji.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"If you just have a single problem to solve, then fine, go ahead and use a neural network. But if you want to do science and understand how to choose architectures, or how to go to a new problem, you have to understand what different architectures can and cannot do." - Marvin Minsky
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Si vous avez juste un seul problème à résoudre, alors tout va bien, aller de l'avant et utilisez un réseau de neurones. Mais si vous voulez faire de la science et comprendre comment choisir les architectures, ou comment passer à un nouveau problème, vous devez comprendre ce que les différentes architectures peuvent et ne peuvent pas faire." - Marvin Minsky
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Niektórzy ludzie majá umysô tak otwarty, ëe mózg im wycieka." - Flannery O'Connor

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Neural Networks[COLOR_REVERT] is required for further advances in robotic technology.
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]réseaux de neurones[COLOR_REVERT] sont requis pour avancer dans les technologies robotiques

TEXT.English: Nuclear Power
TEXT.French: Energie nucléaire
TEXT.Polish: Energia Atomowa

TEXT.English: [TAB]In addition to its potential for destruction, the energy released in nuclear fission was seen as a potential source of controlled power generation. By 1944, large-scale nuclear reactors were in operation for the production of plutonium, although the energy produced by these reactors was not used. Following World War II, increased efforts were turned toward the extensive use of nuclear power to produce electricity. [PARAGRAPH:2]Nuclear power plants use the radiant energy of a controlled nuclear reaction to heat water, converting it to steam to spin turbines that generate electricity. The major drawback to nuclear fission is the lack of a safe means of disposal for the waste produced by the reaction, which retains its lethal radioactivity for hundreds of years. Another hazard is the possibility of a malfunction in the reactor that could lead to a meltdown of the core. Despite massive safety precautions, human error and equipment failures can lead to devastating accidents such as the explosion at Chernobyl in 1986, in which at least 30 people were killed and thousands lost their homes and face possible long-term illness after exposure to near-lethal doses of radiation. Because of growing public concern, the development of new nuclear power plants has slowed as scientists search for viable solutions to these problems.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Energia jádrowa to energia wydzielana podczas przemian jádrowych. Uwalnianie siê energii podczas tych przemian zwiázane jest z róënicami w energii wiázania poszczególnych jáder atomowych.Jádra ëelaza (56Fe) sá najbardziej stabilnymi ze wszystkich jáder, co oznacza najwiêkszá energiê wiázania w przeliczeniu na jeden nukleon. Jádra masywniejsze od jáder ëelaza majá stopniowo coraz mniejszá energiê wiázania na nukleon. Dlatego rozszczepiajác ciêëkie jádro na mniejsze fragmenty, uzyskuje siê energiê. Podobnie dzieje siê podczas ôáczenia jáder lëejszych od jádra ëelaza. Róënice w energiach wiázania i, co za tym idzie, wydzielana energia sá tak duëe, ëe nastêpuje mierzalny spadek masy produktów takich reakcji jádrowych (czêäâ masy zamienia siê na energiê). Zmiana masy ma miejsce równieë podczas endotermicznych reakcji chemicznych gwaôtownego utleniania (spalania) tradycyjnych paliw, ale jest ona w tym przypadku nieporównanie mniejsza. Reakcje jádrowe w przeliczeniu na jednostkê masy - sá okoôo milion razy bardziej efektywne od reakcji chemicznych.Reakcja syntezy jádrowej jest gôównym éródôem energii emitowanej przez ciaôa niebieskie. Jest ona éródôem promieniowania Sôoñca i innych gwiazd. Z kolei we wnêtrzu Ziemi, znajduje siê pewna iloäâ ciêëkich pierwiastków promieniotwórczych ulegajácych ciágôemu rozpadowi. Energia ta, poza energiá pozostaôá po formowaniu siê Ziemi, moëe byâ éródôem wzrostu temperatury ziemi wraz z gôêbokoäciá.Reakcja rozszczepienia ciêëkich jáder moëe byâ kontrolowana i jest wykorzystywana w energetyce w elektrowniach jádrowych. Najczêäciej stosowanym surowcem jest uran-235. Wytwarzana w ten sposób energia wewnêtrzna jest wykorzystywana do napêdzania turbin generatorów energii elektrycznej. Obecnie ok. 7% energii zuëywanej przez ludzkoäâ w tym 15,7% energii elektrycznej jest produkowanej z energii jáder atomowych. W Stanach Zjednoczonych ok. 20%, a we Francji aë 80% energii elektrycznej pochodzi z elektrowni jádrowych.Stosowany jest równieë napêd atomowy (okrêty podwodne, lotniskowce). Energia rozpadu promieniotwórczego sôuëy równieë do zasilania aparatury pomiarowej sond kosmicznych (szczególnie tych, które penetrujá peryferyjne obszary Ukôadu Sôonecznego).Od lat piêâdziesiátych XX w. trwajá prace nad kontrolowanym przeprowadzaniem reakcji fuzji lekkich jáder atomowych. Mimo wielu prób, do tej pory nie udaôo siê zbudowaâ instalacji pozwalajácej uzyskiwaâ uëyteczná energiê w sposób ciágôy i stabilny na drodze fuzji jádrowej.

TEXT.English: [TAB]"A nuclear power reactor is just a fancy way of boiling water" - Leslie Dewan

[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Nuclear Power[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to construct [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Supercarrier[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Attack Submarine[COLOR_REVERT], and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Missile Submarine[COLOR_REVERT] and build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Nuclear Plant[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]puissance nucléaire[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Super-porte-avions[COLOR_REVERT], des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]sous-marins d'attaque[COLOR_REVERT], et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]sous-marins à missile[COLOR_REVERT] et de construire une [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]centrale nucléaire[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Oil Painting
TEXT.French: Peinture à l'huile
TEXT.Polish: Malarstwo Olejne

TEXT.English: [TAB]Oil painting is the process of painting with pigments that bound with medium of drying oil - especially in early modern Europe, linseed oil. Often an oil, such as linseed was boiled with a resin such as pine resin or even frankincense, these were called 'varnishes' and were prized for their body and gloss. Other oils occasionally used include poppyseed oil, walnut oil, and safflower oil. These oils give various properties to the oil paint, such as less yellowing or different drying times. Certain differences are also visible in the sheen of the paints depending on the oil. Painters often use different oils in the same painting depending on specific pigments and effects desired. The paints themselves also develop a particular feel depending on the media.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Malarstwo olejne jest najbardziej rozpowszechnioná techniká malarská.Polega ono na pokrywaniu naprêëonego i zagruntowanego pôótna, gôadkiej deski, lub innego podobrazia farbami, w skôad których wchodzi olej lniany lub rzadziej inne roälinne oleje schnáce (konopny, makowy) i odpowiednie pigmenty. Sporadycznie stosowany byô teë wosk, który peôniô funkcjê stabilizatora spowalniajácego oddzielanie siê oleju lnianego od pigmentów. Zasadniczo receptura produkowania tych farb nie ulegôa zmianie przez ponad 300 lat, aë do poczátków XX wieku. Pierwszá waëná zmianá byôo rozpoczêcie "pakowania" w tuby oôowiano-cynowe (co umoëliwiôo bezproblemowe przenoszenie farb w plener - to rozwiázanie technologiczne znaczáco wpôynêôo na rozwój impresjonizmu), a nastêpnie aluminiowe. W toku dalszego rozwoju w celu zmniejszenia ceny farb stopniowo zastápiono wiêkszoäâ pigmentów naturalnych pigmentami syntetycznymi (proces ten zapoczátkowano w XIX wieku, a zakoñczono w latach 50. XX wieku). Pod koniec XX wieku dokonano przeôomu technologicznego, tworzác farby olejne wodorozcieñczalne. Malarstwo olejne jest bardzo kosztowná techniká malarská, ale daje bardzo duëá swobodê w doborze i mieszaniu barw, uzyskiwania efektu matu lub bôysku, efektów póôprzezroczystoäci i przenikania barw, oraz tworzeniu zôoëonych faktur. Malarstwo olejne po opanowaniu podstaw warsztatu jest stosunkowo ôatwá i wdziêczná techniká. Umoëliwia ono wielokrotne retuszowanie przez nakôadanie kolejnych warstw farby na obraz. Obrazy olejne cechuje teë duëa trwaôoäâ.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"No one is an artist unless he carries his picture in his head before painting it, and is sure of his method and composition." - Claude Monet
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Personne n'est un artiste à moins qu'il ne porte son image dans sa tête avant de la peindre, et qu'il est sûr de sa méthode et de la composition." - Claude Monet
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Dobry malarz musi namalowaâ dwie rzeczy: czôowieka oraz istotê jego duszy." - Leonardo da Vinci

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Oil Painting[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Painter's Studio[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Leonardo's Workshop[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]peinture à l'huile[COLOR_REVERT] permet la construction de l'[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]atelier du peintre[COLOR_REVERT] et l'[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]atelier de Léonard[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Orbital Flight
TEXT.French: Vol orbital
TEXT.Polish: Lot Orbitalny

TEXT.English: [TAB]An orbital spaceflight (or orbital flight) is a spaceflight in which a spacecraft is placed on a trajectory where it could remain in space for at least one orbit. To do this around the Earth, it must be on a free trajectory which has an altitude at perigee (altitude at closest approach) above 100 kilometers (62 mi) (this is, by at least one convention, the boundary of space). To remain in orbit at this altitude requires an orbital speed of ~7.8 km/s. Orbital speed is slower for higher orbits, but attaining them requires higher delta-v.[PARAGRAPH:2]The expression "orbital spaceflight" is mostly used to distinguish from sub-orbital spaceflights, which are flights where apogee of a spacecraft reaches space but perigee is too low.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Lot orbitalny jest lotem kosmicznym w czasie którego pojazd kosmiczny jest umieszczony na trajektorii, na której moëe pozostaâ w przestrzeni kosmicznej przynajmniej na jedno okráëenie orbity. Aby mogôo byâ to dokonane wokóô Ziemi, pojazd musi byâ na swobodnej trajektorii, której puôap w perygeum (puôap w momencie najwiêkszego zbliëenia) powyëej 100 km (ze wzglêdu na definicjê granicy przestrzeni kosmicznej).

TEXT.English: "Think of it as Apollo on steroids, ... Unless the U.S. wants to get out of manned spaceflight completely, this is the vehicle we need to be building." -Michael Griffin
TEXT.French: "Pensez-y comme Apollo dopé aux stéroïdes, ... À moins que les Etats-Unis veulent sortir complètement des projets de vols spatiaux habités, c'est le véhicule que nous devons construire." -Michael Griffin
TEXT.Polish: "Naleëy stworzyâ statki i ëaglowce, poruszane niebieská bryzá. Wtedy nie zabraknie ämiaôków, którym niestraszna pustka kosmosu." - Jan Kepler

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Orbital Flight[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Orbital Fighter[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Orbital Bomber[COLOR_REVERT] and your cities can now build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Spaceports[COLOR_REVERT] and the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Orbital Hotel[COLOR_REVERT] National Wonder.
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]vol orbital[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]chasseurs orbitaux[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]bombardiers orbitaux[COLOR_REVERT]. Vos villes peuvent construire des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]ports spatiaux[COLOR_REVERT] et la merveille nationale de l'[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]hôtel orbital[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Organic Chemistry
TEXT.French: Chimie organique
TEXT.Polish: Chemia Organiczna

TEXT.English: [TAB]Organic chemistry is a specific discipline within chemistry which involves the scientific study of the structure, properties, composition, reactions, and preparation (by synthesis or by other means) of chemical compounds consisting primarily of carbon and hydrogen, which may contain any number of other elements, including nitrogen, oxygen, halogens as well as phosphorus, silicon and sulfur. -- Wikipedia
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Chemia organiczna - pierwotnie oznaczaôa dziaô chemii zajmujácej siê systematyká zwiázków chemicznych, które, jak wierzono, nie mogá byâ otrzymane na drodze syntezy laboratoryjnej, a jedynie przez ëywe organizmy. Póéniej okazaôo siê jednak, ëe niemal wszystkie zwiázki chemiczne produkowane przez organizmy ëywe da siê teë sztucznie zsyntezowaâ. Udaôo siê nawet zsyntezowaâ wiele zwiázków, które w naturze nie wystêpujá, ale których wôasnoäci sá zbliëone do tych produkowanych przez organizmy ëywe. Z drugiej strony okazaôo siê, ëe wszystkie te zwiázki zawierajá wêgiel czterowartoäciowy (pomijajác dwutlenek wêgla i cyjanki, bêdáce zw. nieorganicznymi), stád obecnie definicja chemii organicznej to chemia wszystkich tych zwiázków wêgla, którymi nie zajmowaôa siê wczeäniej tradycyjna chemia nieorganiczna.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Organic chemistry is the study of organs; inorganic chemistry is the study of the insides of organs." - Max Shulman
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"La chimie organique est l'étude des organes, la chimie inorganique est l'étude de l'intérieur des organes." - Max Shulman
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"O szyderstwie chemii äwiadczy fakt, ëe to, co dziêki niej miaôo moc przyciágania, z czasem zaczyna odpychaâ." - Lidia Jasiñska

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Organic Chemistry[COLOR_REVERT] increases the production of [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Workshops[COLOR_REVERT] and is necessary to found [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Standard Ethanol[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]chimie organique[COLOR_REVERT] augmente la production des [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]ateliers[COLOR_REVERT] et est nécessaire pour fonder [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Éthanol standard[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Organic Cities
TEXT.French: Villes organiques
TEXT.Polish: Organiczne Miasta

TEXT.English: [TAB][TAB]Organic cities are urban areas that majorly consist of renewable resources such as wood grown at a plantation or grown on the spot. They emit a minimal amount of greenhouse gases and use clean power sources such as fusion or anti-matter. Organic cities are designed with features such as mandatory rooftop gardens and enhanced bio-fluorescent lighting dervied from jellyfish, and play a major role in reducing the small amount of carbon dioxide they do emit.
[SPACE]"Organic buildings are the strength and lightness of the spiders' spinning, buildings qualified by light, bred by native character to environment, married to the ground." - Frank Lloyd Wright
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Les bâtiments organiques ont la force et la légèreté des fils d'araignée, ce sont des bâtiments alimentés par la lumière, élevés de par leur origine a respecter l'environnement, mariés à la terre." - Frank Lloyd Wright
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"To piêkne gdy czôowiek jest dumny ze swego miasta, lecz jeszcze piêkniej, gdy miasto moëe byâ z niego dumne." - Abraham Lincoln

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Organic Cities[COLOR_REVERT] grants +2 health in all cities and increases the food production of [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Cottages[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Hamlets[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Villages[COLOR_REVERT], and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Towns[COLOR_REVERT].
Papacy
TEXT.French: Papauté
TEXT.Polish: Papiestwo

TEXT.English: [TAB]The office of the pope is called the Papacy, and his ecclesiastical jurisdiction the "Holy See" or "Apostolic See". The pope is also head of state of Vatican City, a sovereign city-state entirely enclaved by the city of Rome. [PARAGRAPH:2]Early popes helped to spread Christianity and resolve doctrinal disputes. After the conversion of the rulers of the Roman Empire (the conversion of the populace was already advanced even before the Edict of Milan, 313), the Roman emperors became the popes' secular allies until, with the loss of the emperors' power in the west, Pope Stephen II was forced in the 8th century to appeal to the Franks for help, beginning a period of close interaction with the rulers of the west. For centuries, the forged Donation of Constantine also provided the basis for the papacy's claim of political supremacy over the entire former Western Roman Empire. In medieval times, popes played powerful roles in Western Europe, often struggling with monarchs for power over wide-ranging affairs of church and state, crowning emperors (Charlemagne was the first emperor crowned by a pope) and regulating disputes among secular rulers.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Papieë (Ojciec Äwiêty[1]) (ôac. Pontifex Maximus, wô. papa, gr. pappas, forma funkcjonujáca w jêzyku polskim pochodzi od czeskiego papež) – biskup Rzymu, gôowa Koäcioôa rzymskokatolickiego, katolickich Koäcioôów wschodnich, Stolicy Apostolskiej oraz pañstwa Watykan. Obecnym papieëem jest Benedykt XVI.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"The Papacy is not other than the Ghost of the deceased Roman Empire, sitting crowned upon the grave thereof." - Thomas Hobbes
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"La papauté n'est autre que le fantôme du défunt Empire romain, Son trône perché sur la tombe de celui-ci." - Thomas Hobbes
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Papieë? Ile ma on dywizji?" - Józef Stalin

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Papacy[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Apostolic Palace[COLOR_REVERT] and adopt the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]State Church[COLOR_REVERT] civic.
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]papauté[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire le [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]palais apostolique[COLOR_REVERT] et d'adopter la doctrine [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]église d'état[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Personal Robots
TEXT.French: Robots personnels
TEXT.Polish: Osobiste Roboty

TEXT.English: [TAB]A personal robot is one whose human interface and design make it useful for individuals. This is by contrast to industrial robots which are generally configured and operated by robotics specialists. A personal robot is one that enables an individual to automate the repetitive or menial part of home or work life making them more productive.[APRAGRAPH:2]Similar to the way that the transition from mainframe computers to the personal computers revolutionized personal productivity, the transition from industrial robotics to personal robotics is changing productivity in home and work settings. [PARAGRAPH:3]Turning a robot like ASIMO or into a universally applicable personal robot or artificial servant is mainly a programming task. As of 2011 vast improvements in motion planning, computer vision (esp. scene recognition), natural language processing, and automated reasoning are indispensable to make this a possibility.

[SPACE]"Let's start with the three fundamental Rules of Robotics.... We have: one, a robot may not injure a human being, or, through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm. Two, a robot must obey the orders given it by human beings except where such orders would conflict with the First Law. And three, a robot must protect its own existence as long as such protection does not conflict with the First or Second Laws." - Isaac Asimov
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Commençons par les trois règles fondamentales de la robotique .... Nous avons: Un, un robot ne peut blesser un être humain ou, par son inaction, permettre qu'un être humain soit exposé au danger. Deux, un robot doit obéir aux ordres donnés par les êtres humains, sauf si de tels ordres sont en contradiction avec la Première Loi. Et trois, un robot doit protéger sa propre existence tant que cette protection n'entre pas en conflit avec la Première ou la Seconde loi." - Isaac Asimov
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Sztuczna inteligencja jest niczym przy prawdziwej gôupocie." - Elbert Hubbard

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Personal Robots[COLOR_REVERT] increases the production of [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Cottages[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Hamlets[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Villages[COLOR_REVERT], and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Towns[COLOR_REVERT] and grants +1 happiness in all cities.
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]robots personnels[COLOR_REVERT] augmentent la production des [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]cottages[COLOR_REVERT], des[COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]hameaux[COLOR_REVERT], des [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]villages[COLOR_REVERT], et des [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]villes[COLOR_REVERT] et procure +1 de bonheur dans toutes les villes.

TEXT.English: Perspective
TEXT.French: Perspective
TEXT.Polish: Perspektywa

TEXT.English: [TAB]Perspective (from Latin perspicere, to see through) in the graphic arts, such as drawing, is an approximate representation, on a flat surface (such as paper), of an image as it is perceived by the eye. [PARAGRAPH:2]Before perspective, paintings and drawings typically sized objects and characters according to their spiritual or thematic importance, not with distance. Especially in Medieval art, art was meant to be read as a group of symbols, rather than seen as a coherent picture. The only method to show distance was by overlapping characters. Overlapping alone made poor drawings of architecture; medieval paintings of cities are a hodgepodge of lines in every direction. With the exception of dice, heraldry typically ignores perspective in the treatment of charges, though sometimes in later centuries charges are specified as in perspective. [PARAGRAPH:2]Perspective perhaps first entered mainstream artistic use around the 5th century B.C. in ancient Greece in the subject of skenographia: using a flat panel on a stage to give the illusion of depth. The philosophers Anaxagoras and Democritus worked out geometric theories of perspective for use with skenographia. Alcibiades had paintings in his house designed based on skenographia, thus this art was not confined merely to the stage. Euclid's Optics introduced a mathematical theory of perspective; however, there is some debate over the extent to which Euclid's perspective coincides with a modern mathematical definition of perspective. [PARAGRAPH:2]A clearly modern optical basis of perspective was given in 1021, when Alhazen, an Iraqi physicist and mathematician, in his Book of Optics, explained that light projects conically into the eye. This was, theoretically, enough to translate objects convincingly onto a painting, but Alhalzen was concerned only with optics, not with painting. Conical translations are mathematically difficult, so a drawing constructed using them would be incredibly time consuming. [PARAGRAPH:2]In about 1415, Filippo Brunelleschi demonstrated the geometrical method of perspective, used today by artists, by painting the outlines of various Florentine buildings onto a mirror. When the building's outline was continued, he noticed that all of the lines converged on the horizon line. According to Vasari, he then set up a demonstration of his painting of the Baptistry in the incomplete doorway of the Duomo. He had the viewer look through a small hole on the back of the painting, facing the Baptistry. He would then set up a mirror, facing the viewer, which reflected his painting. To the viewer, the painting of the Baptistry and the Baptistry itself were nearly indistinguishable. [PARAGRAPH:2]Soon after, nearly every artist in Florence used geometrical perspective in their paintings, notably Donatello, who started sculpting elaborate checkerboard floors into the simple manger portrayed in the birth of Christ. Although hardly historically accurate, these checkerboard floors obeyed the primary laws of geometrical perspective: all lines converged to a vanishing point, and the rate at which the horizontal lines receded into the distance was graphically determined. This became an integral part of Quattrocento art. Not only was perspective a way of showing depth, it was also a new method of composing a painting. Paintings began to show a single, unified scene, rather than a combination of several.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Perspektywa — okreälenie stosowane w architekturze, malarstwie, fotografii i innych sztukach wizualnych oznaczajáce sposób oddania trójwymiarowych obiektów i przestrzeni na pôaszczyénie. Istnieje kilka rodzajów perspektywy: linearna (zbieëna, geometryczna), barwna (malarska), powietrzna, odwrócona.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Only the artist, not the fool, discovers that which nature hides." - Filippo Brunelleschi
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Seul l'artiste, pas le fou, découvre ce que cache la nature." - Filippo Brunelleschi
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Tylko artysta, nie gôupiec, odkrywa to co natura ukrywa." - Filippo Brunelleschi

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Perspective[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Sistine Chapel[COLOR_REVERT] and the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Castle Garden[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]perspective[COLOR_REVERT] active la construction de la [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]chapelle sixtine[COLOR_REVERT] et au [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]jardin du château[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Photography
TEXT.Polish: Fotografia

TEXT.English: [TAB]Photography is the process of recording pictures by means of capturing light on a light-sensitive medium, such as a film or electronic sensor. Light patterns reflected or emitted from objects expose a sensitive silver halide based chemical or electronic medium during a timed exposure, usually through a photographic lens in a device known as a camera that also stores the resulting information chemically or electronically.[PARAGRAPH:2]Photography is the result of combining several technical discoveries. Long before the first photographs were made, Ibn al-Haytham (Alhazen) (965–1040) invented the camera obscura and pinhole camera, Albertus Magnus (1193–1280) discovered silver nitrate, and Georges Fabricius (1516–1571) discovered silver chloride. Daniel Barbaro described a diaphragm in 1568. Wilhelm Homberg described how light darkened some chemicals (photochemical effect) in 1694. The fiction book Giphantie (by the French Thiphaigne de La Roche, 1729-1774) described what can be interpreted as photography.[PARAGRAPH:2]Photography as a usable process goes back to the 1820s with the development of chemical photography. The first permanent photograph was an image produced in 1826 by the French inventor Nicephore Niepce. -- Wikipedia
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Fotografia to zbiór wielu róënych technik, których celem jest zarejestrowanie trwaôego, pojedynczego obrazu za pomocá äwiatôa. Potoczne znaczenie zakôada wykorzystanie ukôadu optycznego, choâ nie jest to konieczne - fotografia otworkowa, rayografia. Fotografia, powstaôa w XIX wieku, korzystaôa z wynalazków znanych juë wczeäniej. Podstawowy instrument do tworzenia obrazu, camera obscura, byô stosowany juë od XVI wieku przez malarzy. W 1826 lub 1827 powstaôa pierwsza fotografia stworzona przez Francuza Josepha-Nicephore'a Niepce'a na wypolerowanej pôycie metalowej. Rok 1839 uznaje siê za wôaäciwá datê wynalezienia fotografii. Francuz, Louis Jacques Daguerre, zademonstrowaô Akademii Francuskiej zdjêcie fotograficzne otrzymane na warstewce jodku srebra, powstaôej w wyniku dziaôania pary jodu na wypolerowaná pôytê miedzianá pokrytá srebrem. Technika fotografii rozwijaôa siê od tego momentu bardzo szybko. Juë wkrótce pôytki srebrne lub arkusze papieru zastápiono pôytkami szklanymi powleczonymi warstwá äwiatôoczuôá. Pôytki te preparowano tuë przed wykonaniem zdjêcia, co wymagaôo przenoänej ciemni fotograficznej, w której moëna byôo dokonaâ tego zabiegu. W 1861 udaôo siê uzyskaâ pierwszá trwaôá fotografiê barwná fizykowi Jamesowi Clerkowi Maxwellowi. W 1907 Bracia Lumiere wprowadzili na rynek pierwsze pôyty do fotografii barwnej, Autochrome. Byôy one wyprodukowane na bazie barwionej skrobi ziemniaczanej. 1935 zostaô wprowadzony do sprzedaëy pierwszy wspóôczesny, trójwarstwowy film barwny, Kodachrome. Wiêkszoäâ wspóôczesnych filmów barwnych, oprócz Kodachrome, wykorzystuje technologiê stworzoná dla filmu Agfacolor w 1936. Od 1963 jest dostêpny natychmiastowy materiaô kolorowy firmy Polaroid. Fotografia pojawiôa siê na ziemiach polskich juë w roku 1839, kiedy to Kurier Warszawski wydrukowaô ogôoszenie firmy FRAGET oferujácej aparaty do dagerotypii. Rok póéniej w Poznaniu i w Warszawie pojawiôy siê ilustrowane broszury poäwiêcone dagerotypii.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Not everybody trusts paintings but people believe photographs." - Ansel Adams
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Tout le monde ne fait pas confiance aux peintures, mais les gens croient les photos." - Ansel Adams
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Nie kaëdy ufa obrazá ale ludzie wierzá w fotografie." - Ansel Adams

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Photography[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to train [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Agents[COLOR_REVERT] and build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Photographer's Studio[COLOR_REVERT]. The first civilization to discover this technology receives a free [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Great Artist[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]philosophie[COLOR_REVERT] permet de recruter des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]agents[COLOR_REVERT] et de construire l'[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]atelier du photographe[COLOR_REVERT]. La première civilisation à découvrir cette technologie reçoit un [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]artiste illustre[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Planetary Economics
TEXT.Polish: Ekonomia Planetarna

TEXT.English: [TAB]

[SPACE]"Some people think that our planet is suffering from a fever. Now scientists are telling us that Mars is experiencing its own planetary warming: Martian warming. This has led some people, not necessarily scientists, to wonder if Mars and Jupiter, non signatories to the Kyoto Treaty, are actually inhabited by alien SUV-driving industrialists." - Fred Thompson
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Certains pensent que notre planète est atteint d'une fièvre. Maintenant, les scientifiques nous disent que Mars connaît sa propre réchauffement planétaire: le réchauffement de Mars. Cette situation a conduit certaines personnes, pas nécessairement scientifiques, à se demander si de Mars et de Jupiter, non signataires du Traité de Kyoto, sont en réalité habité par des aliens industriels." - Fred Thompson
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Naprawdê niezwykôá siôá banku centralnego jest to, ëe moëe tworzyâ pieniádz, a w koñcu potêga tworzenia to równieë potêga niszczenia." - Paul Volcker

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Planetary Economics[COLOR_REVERT] allows workers to build [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Hybrid Forests[COLOR_REVERT] and increases the yields of [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Hybrid Forests[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Geothermal Factories[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]économie planétaire[COLOR_REVERT] permet aux ouvriers de construire des [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]forêts hybrides[COLOR_REVERT] et d'augmenter la production des [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]usines géothermiques[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Plastic Electronics
TEXT.French: Electronique plastique
TEXT.Polish: Elektronika Polimerowa

TEXT.English: [TAB]Plastic electronics, organic electronics or polymer electronics, is a branch of electronics that deals with conductive polymers, plastics, or small molecules. It is called 'organic' electronics because the polymers and small molecules are carbon-based, like the molecules of living things. This is as opposed to traditional electronics (or metal electronics) which relies on inorganic conductors such as copper or silicon. [PARAGRAPH:2]Technology for plastic electronics on thin and flexible plastic substrates was developed at Cambridge University’s Cavendish Laboratory in the 1990s. In 2000, Plastic Logic was spun out of Cavendish Laboratory to develop a broad range of products using the plastic electronics technology.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Przedstawiono przeglád wykorzystania materiaôów organicznych w optoelektronice. W ostatnich latach widoczne sá znaczne postêpy w tym wzglêdzie zarówno naukowe, jak i aplikacyjne. Stwarza to realne podstawy, aby sádziâ, ëe powstaje nowa liczáca siê gaôáé nauki powiázana z interesujácymi zastosowaniami, które w zakresie ciekôych krysztaôów(CK) sá realizowane od dawna. Najnowsze publikacje pokazujá niewátpliwe perspektywy inëynierii materiaôowej w badaniach oraz zastosowaniu staôych póôprzewodników organicznych. Omówiono ostatnie osiágniêcia w konstrukcji displejów CK, fotoogniw, ogniw sôonecznych, emiterów LED, laserów oraz elementów mikroelektronicznych, zwôaszcza cienkowarstwowych tranzystorów.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"We've become a plastic society." - Bill Janklow
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Nous sommes devenus une société de plastique." - Bill Janklow
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Czôowieku co ci szkodzi wrzuciâ papier do papieru, plastik do plastiku? Dla ciebie to nic, dla Ziemi tak wiele..." - Anonim

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Plastic Electronics[COLOR_REVERT] allows construction of [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Hypermarkets[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]électronique plastique[COLOR_REVERT] permet la construction des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]hypermarchés[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Political Philosophy
TEXT.French: Philosophie politique
TEXT.Polish: Filozofia Polityczna

TEXT.English: [TAB]Political philosophy is the study of fundamental questions about the state, government, politics, liberty, justice, property, rights, law and the enforcement of a legal code by authority: what they are, why (or even if) they are needed, what makes a government legitimate, what rights and freedoms it should protect and why, what form it should take and why, what the law is, and what duties citizens owe to a legitimate government, if any, and when it may be legitimately overthrown—if ever. In a vernacular sense, the term "political philosophy" often refers to a general view, or specific ethic, belief or attitude, about politics that does not necessarily belong to the technical discipline of philosophy.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Filozofia polityczna - dziaô filozofii praktycznej stanowiácy krytyczná refleksjê nad ëyciem politycznym i pañstwem: zwôaszcza istotá polityki, naturá, pochodzeniem i prawomocnoäciá wôadzy, pochodzeniem, zmiennoäciá i wartoäciá moralná ustrojów pañstwowych. Jako refleksja krytyczna filozofia polityczna analizuje podstawowe pojêcia zwiázane z ëyciem politycznym, takie jak pokój, wolnoäâ, sprawiedliwoäâ czy postêp. Jako refleksja twórcza zmierza do oceny ëycia politycznego i budowy postulatów ustrojowych: dlatego teë niejednokrotnie miaôa znaczny wpôyw na historyczny rozwój ëycia politycznego i spoôecznego.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"When the prince needs to be deceitful, though, he must not appear that way. Indeed he must always exhibit five virtues in particular: mercy, honesty, humaneness, uprightness, and religiousness" - Niccolo Machiavelli
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Quand le prince a besoin d'être trompeur, pourtant, il ne doit pas apparaître de cette façon. En effet, il doit toujours présenter cinq vertus, en particulier: la miséricorde, l'honnêteté, d'humanité, la droiture, et la religiosité" - Niccolo Machiavelli
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Politykê uwaëa siê za drugi najstarszy zawód äwiata. Doszedôem do wniosku, ëe jest bardzo podobny do pierwszego." - Ronald Reagan

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Political Philosophy[COLOR_REVERT] allows construction of the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]House of Parliament[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Porcelain Tower[COLOR_REVERT] and enables you to make [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Defensive Pacts[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]philosophie politique[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire le [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]parlement[COLOR_REVERT] et la [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]tour de porcelaine[COLOR_REVERT] et active les [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]pactes défensifs[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Poultry Farming
TEXT.Spanish: Avicultura

TEXT.English: [TAB][BOLD]Poultry Farming[\BOLD] is the practice of raising poultry, such as chickens, turkeys, ducks, and geese, as a subcategory of animal husbandry, for the purpose of farming meat or eggs for food. The vast majority of poultry are farmed using modern farming techniques. According to the Worldwatch Institute, 74 percent of the world's poultry meat, and 68 percent of eggs are produced this way.
Powered Exoskeleton
TEXT.French: Exo-squelettes
TEXT.Polish: Wspomagany Egzoszkielet

TEXT.English: [TAB]Humans have long used armour as an artificial exoskeleton for protection, especially in combat. Exoskeletal machines (also called powered exoskeletons) are also starting to be used for medical and industrial purposes, while powered human exoskeletons are a feature of science fiction writing, but are currently moving into prototype stage.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Wspomagany Egzoszkielet mocowany na zewnetrzna powloke ciala, której celem jest wzmocnienie sily miesni uzytkownika. Egzoszkielet moze wzmacniac wszystkie partie miesni lub tylko niektóre (np. sztuczne ramie). Poruszanie sie w egzoszkielecie zalezy od kilku czynników (wlasciwego dopasowania egzoszkieletu, odpowiedniego oprogramowania komputera sterujacego, mozliwosci sterowania nim osoby z niego korzystajacej). Za ruch urzadzenia odpowiedzialny jest zazwyczaj system silowników elektrycznych, pneumatycznych lub hydraulicznych (rzadko przekladni mechanicznych) mocowanych w jednolitej oslonie (kombinezonie). Aktywne egzoszkielety sa zasilane przy pomocy róznego rodzaju silników lub energia z akumulatorów. Ruch jest nadzorowany zazwyczaj poprzez sterownik w postaci komputera. Dodatkowo moga wystepowac czujniki zyroskopowe (informujace system o stanie równowagi w jakim znajduje sie dana osoba i wprowadzajace do systemu ewentualne korekty majace na celu przywrócenie równowagi). Tematyka egzoszkieletów jest poruszana w literaturze, filmach, czy w grach komputerowych, jak równiez jest tematem projektów badawczych prowadzonych w rzeczywistosci. Pierwsze próby stworzenia egzoszkieletu siegaja lat 60' dwudziestego wieku, kiedy to firma General Electric prowadzila badania zwiazane z projektem Hardiman. Jednakze próby te, podobnie jak inne zakonczyly sie niepowodzeniem (w projekcie Hardiman ukonczono jedynie ramie). Za przyczyne podaje sie brak mozliwosci technicznych niezbednych do ich realizacji w owym czasie. Obecnie prace nad egzoszkieletem sa znacznie bardziej zaawansowane, o czym moze swiadczyc np. projekt BLEEX.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Robotic exoskeletons that try to decode the electrical activity of muscles can get confused - sensing limb movement is more reliable." - Honda representative
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Les exosquelette robotisé qui tentent de décoder l'activité électrique des muscles peuvent se confondre - la détection de mouvement des membres est plus fiable." - Représentant Honda
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Moje ciaôo ma zostaâ spalone, ëeby ludzie nie czcili moich koäci." - Albert Einstein

TEXT.English: Propaganda
TEXT.French: Propagande
TEXT.Polish: Propaganda

TEXT.English: "The engineering of consent is the very essence of the democratic process, the freedom to persuade and suggest." - Edward Bernays
TEXT.French: L'ingénierie du consenti est l'essence même du processus démocratique, la liberté de persuader et de suggérer. - Edward Bernays

TEXT.English: Propaganda is the art of communicating information in a way to influence its intended audience. Propaganda relies on selective reporting of facts, appeals to emotion, and repetition through multiple forms of media to sway a community to a particular point of view. Modern propaganda techniques were developed in the early 20th century, especially during World War I as governments used propaganda to keep their citizens in favor of the war despite the casualties incurred. Later, both the Communists in the Soviet Union and the Fascists in Nazi Germany refined propaganda techniques and used them quite extensively.

[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Propaganda[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Advertising Agency[COLOR_REVERT] building and the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Propaganda Net[COLOR_REVERT] National Wonder.
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]propagande[COLOR_REVERT] vous permet de construire l'[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]agence de publicité[COLOR_REVERT] et la merveille nationale "[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]réseau de propagande[COLOR_REVERT]".

TEXT.English: Psychology
TEXT.Polish: Psychologia

TEXT.English: [TAB]Psychology is the systematic study of human and animal behavior. The subject covers many areas including the roles of instinct, heredity, environment and culture. [PARAGRAPH:2]Wilhelm Wundt in Leipzig, Germany founded the first psychology laboratory in 1879. Well known psychologists include Sigmund Freud, Carl Jung, Hans Eynsenck and Gustav Fechner.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Psychologia jest nauká empiryczná, zajmujácá siê badaniem mechanizmów i praw rzádzácych zjawiskami psychicznymi oraz zachowaniami czôowieka. Psychologia bada równieë wpôyw zjawisk psychicznych na interakcje miêdzyludzkie oraz interakcjê z otoczeniem. W zasadzie psychologia dotyczy ludzi, ale mówi siê o psychologii zwierzát (czyli zoopsychologii), chociaë zachowaniem siê zwierzát zajmuje siê takëe dziedzina biologii - etologia. Nauki z których czerpie psychologia to gôównie socjologia, antropologia, filozofia i biologia, ale dziêki wypracowaniu wôasnych metod eksperymentalnych psychologia jest nauká samodzielná. Psychologia zaliczana jest do nauk spoôecznych, takëe do nauk humanistycznych. Ostatnio jest takëe zaliczana do nauk behawioralnych (nauk o zachowaniu) razem z socjologiá, etologiá, antropologiá kulturowá, kryminologiá, niektórymi dziaôami medycyny (psychiatriá, medycyná behawioralná). Termin psychologia pochodzi z jêzyka greckiego i dosôownie oznacza "naukê o duszy". Nazwa ta jednak nie byôa znana ani uëywana przez staroëytnych greków (stosowano wtedy gr. zwrot ???? ?????). Nazwa "psychologia" zostaôa sztucznie utworzona dopiero w XVI wieku. Wilhelm Volkmann stwierdziô, ëe po raz pierwszy zastosowaô já Melanchton, jednak w 1987 roku André Lalande po przestudiowaniu dzieô Melanchtona stwierdza, ëe nazwa "psychologia" nie zostaôa tam uëyta ani razu. Przyczyná tej pomyôki popeônionej przez Volkmanna byôo dziewiêtnastowieczne wydanie dzieô Melanchtona, w którym Cardus G. Bretschneider w sôowie wstêpnym napisaô: "Ta ksiêga Melanchtona, pierwszego poäród znanych Niemców, traktuje o psychologii ". Tak wiêc sôowo psychologia nie zostaôo uëyte przez Melanchtona, ale przez dziewiêtnastowiecznego redaktora jego dzieô.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Like the physical, the psychical is not necessarily in reality what it appears to us to be." - Sigmund Freud
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Comme le physique, le psychique n'est pas nécessairement dans la réalité ce qu'il nous semble être." - Sigmund Freud
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Tak jak coä fizycznego, coä duchowego niekoniecznie jest tym czym nam siê wydaje." - Sigmund Freud

TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]psychologie[COLOR_REVERT] permet la construction d'un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]parc d'attraction[COLOR_REVERT] et d'une [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]agence de sécurité[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Public Health
TEXT.French: Santé publique
TEXT.Polish: Publiczna Sôuëba Zdrowia

TEXT.English: [TAB]Sanitation is the hygienic means of preventing human contact from the hazards of wastes to promote health. Hazards can be either physical, microbiological, biological or chemical agents of disease. Wastes that can cause health problems are human and animal feces, solid wastes, domestic wastewater (sewage, sullage, greywater), industrial wastes, and agricultural wastes and now appliances in disuse wastes like cars, computers,household appliances, electronic appliances(bulbs, regulators) Hygienic means of prevention can be by using engineering solutions (e.g. sewerage and wastewater treatment), simple technologies (e.g.latrines, septic tanks), or even by personal hygiene practices (e.g. simple handwashing with soap).
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Instalacja wodna lub instalacja wodociágowa (wodociág) - ukôad poôáczonych przewodów, armatury i urzádzeñ, sôuëácy do zaopatrywania budynku w zimná i ciepôá wodê, speôniajácy wymagania jakoäciowe (okreälone w przepisach) warunków, jakim powinna odpowiadaâ woda do spoëycia przez ludzi..

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"When you consider the contributions that plumbing and sanitation make to the quality of all of our lives, then much of the other things that we do just seem so much less significant. My goal is for us to provide top quality plumbing products, with fair, low prices, with the best service, sent to the most people that we can." - Vic
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Quand vous considérez que les apports de la plomberie et de l'assainissement à la qualité de nos vies, alors la plupart des autres choses que nous faisons nous semblent tout simplement beaucoup moins importante. Mon objectif est d'offrir des produits de plomberie top qualité, avec des prix équitables, bas, avec le meilleur service, et pour autant de gens que nous le pouvons." - Vic
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Fekalia Humana Obiekta Est - Kupa ludzka rzecz." - Anonim

TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]assanissement moderne[COLOR_REVERT] permet aux villes de construire des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]stations d'épuration[COLOR_REVERT] et d'adopter la doctrine [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]subventionnés[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Public Schooling
TEXT.French: École publique
TEXT.Polish: Publiczna Edukacja

TEXT.English: [TAB]Compulsory education is education which children are required by law to receive and governments to provide. The compulsiveness is an aspect of public education. Homeschooling is typically an alternative to going to government-accredited public schools.[PARAGRAPH:2]Compulsory education at the primary level was affirmed as a human right in the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Many of the world's countries now have compulsory education through at least the primary stage, often extending to the secondary education.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Obowiázek szkolny lub przymus szkolny – obowiázek poddania siê procesowi edukacji powszechnej, zazwyczaj do ukoñczenia okreälonego roku ëycia (np. peônoletnoäci) lub w ramach okreälonego poziomu ksztaôcenia (np. ukoñczenie poziomu podstawowego).

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Rarely is the questioned asked: Is our children learning?" - George W. Bush
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"On se pose rarement la question : Est-ce que nos Enfants apprennent ?" - George W. Bush
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Rzadko kiedy pytamy: Czy nasz dzieci siê uczá?" - George W. Bush

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Public Schooling[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Schools[COLOR_REVERT] and enables the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Atheist[COLOR_REVERT] civic.

TEXT.English: Quantum Computing
TEXT.French: Informatique quantique
TEXT.Polish: Komputer Kwantowy

TEXT.English: [TAB]A quantum computer is a device for computation that makes direct use of quantum mechanical phenomena, such as superposition and entanglement, to perform operations on data. The basic principle behind quantum computation is that quantum properties can be used to represent data and perform operations on these data.[PARAGRAPH:2]A classical computer has a memory made up of bits, where each bit holds either a one or a zero. A quantum computer maintains a sequence of qubits. A single qubit can hold a one, a zero, or, crucially, any quantum superposition of these; moreover, a pair of qubits can be in any quantum superposition of 4 states, and three qubits in any superposition of 8. A quantum computer operates by manipulating those qubits with a fixed sequence of quantum logic gates. The sequence of gates to be applied is called a quantum algorithm. An example of an implementation of qubits for a quantum computer could start with the use of particles with two spin states: "down" and "up". But in fact any system possessing an observable quantity A which is conserved under time evolution and such that A has at least two discrete and sufficiently spaced consecutive eigenvalues, is a suitable candidate for implementing a qubit. This is true because any such system can be mapped onto an effective spin-1/2 system.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Komputer kwantowy to ukôad fizyczny do opisu którego wymagana jest mechanika kwantowa, zaprojektowany tak, aby wynik ewolucji tego ukôadu reprezentowaô rozwiázanie okreälonego problemu obliczeniowego. Komputer kwantowy, mimo ëe wykorzystywaôby inne wôaäciwoäci fizyczne nië klasyczne komputery, nie umoëliwiaôby rozwiázywania nowej klasy problemów. Kaëdy problem rozwiázywalny przez komputer kwantowy moëe zostaâ rozwiázany przez komputer klasyczny. Jednak dziêki specyficznym wôasnoäciom komputerów kwantowych pewne problemy moëna byôoby rozwiázaâ znacznie szybciej, co w praktyce znacznie poszerzyôoby zakres problemów do jakich mogá byâ uëyte komputery. Klasycznym przykôadem jest tutaj algorytm faktoryzacji Shora, sôuëácy do rozbijania liczb na czynniki pierwsze. Wykonanie podobnego algorytmu dla kilkudziesiêcio-cyfrowych liczb na wspóôczesnych komputerach przekroczyôoby äredniá dôugoäâ ëycia czôowieka, a dla liczb jeszcze wiêkszych - czas istnienia wszechäwiata. Na komputerach kwantowych moëliwe byôoby wykonanie tych operacji w bardziej realnym okresie. W najczêäciej spotykanym modelu obliczeñ kwantowych stan ukôadu kwantowego reprezentowany jest za pomocá wektora w skoñczeniewymiarowej przestrzeni Hilberta (kubit). Natomiast przeprowadzane operacje sá opisywane za pomocá macierzy unitarnych. Idea kwantowego komputera teë ma swoje sôabe strony. Najpowaëniejsza z nich nazywa siê dekoherencjá. Polega ona na tym, ëe stany kwantowe bêdáce superpozycjami stanów stacjonarnych sá nadzwyczaj nietrwaôe. Pod wpôywem oddziaôywania czynników zewnêtrznych ukôad "wypada" ze stanu superpozycji i "przeskakuje" do jednego ze stanów stacjonarnych. Dokonuje siê to w ciágu drobnego uôamka sekundy. Nawet najmniejszy kontakt z otoczeniem moëe wpôynáâ na wynik pomiaru. Jednym z testowanych sposobów na rozwiázanie tego problemu jest przetrzymywanie atomów w puôapkach magnetycznych i sterowanie nimi za pomocá impulsów äwiatôa laserowego.
