TEXT.English: Quantum Physics
TEXT.Polish: Fizyka Kwantowa

TEXT.English: [TAB]In the world of Physics, to describe most events that are seen in the world, especially those to do with the movement of objects the oldest and still to most people the most useful is Newtonian mechanics, invented by Newton. At the start of the 20th Century, Einstein reviewed the laws as they stood and Einsteinian Mechanics was borne. Einstein also made the theories behind Quantum physics, which describes the very odd behavior of matter at a subatomic level. Although the laws that are present can seem to be the stuff of science fiction, they have predicted accurately events that occur in the real world, and have helped in the production in modern computers and other miniature components.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Fizyka Kwantowa to nauka pisujáca zjawiska mikroäwiata (czásteczki, atomy, jádra atomowe, czástki elementarne). Jej cechá charakterystyczná jest to, ëe opisywane zjawiska na ogóô nie podlegajá bezpoäredniej percepcji czôowieka. Fizyka kwantowa rozwinêôa siê w XX w., jej rozwój zapoczátkowaô kryzys w fizyce przeôomu XIX i XX w. wywoôany odkryciami zjawiska promieniotwórczoäci naturalnej, promieniowania Roentgena (rentgenowskie promieniowanie), trudnoäciami ze skonstruowaniem modelu atomu i wytôumaczeniem pewnych zjawisk dotyczácych emisji fal elektromagnetycznych (efekt fotoelektryczny, promieniowanie ciaôa doskonale czarnego). W 1900 M. Planck zaproponowaô wyjaänienie widma promieniowania ciaôa doskonale czarnego oparte na zaôoëeniu, ëe emisja fal elektromagnetycznych odbywa siê porcjami (kwantami) o energii E=h?. Korzystajác z analogicznego zaôoëenia dotyczácego absorpcji promieniowania A. Einstein wyjaäniô (1904) efekt fotoelektryczny. Doprowadziôo to do sformuôowania hipotezy dualistycznej natury promieniowania. W 1913 N. Bohr przedstawiô kwantowy model atomu wodoru (Bohra model atomu) zawierajácy postulat skwantowania momentu pêdu elektronów w atomie, a w 1923 sformuôowaô tzw. zasadê korespondencji przedstawiajácá prawa klasycznej fizyki jako graniczne przybliëenia rzeczywistych (kwantowych) praw przyrody. W 1924 L. de Broglie zapostulowaô istnienie falowych wôasnoäci materii (de Broglie fale), eksperymentalne potwierdzenie tej tezy otrzymano w 1927 (C.J. Davisson). Dalszy rozwój fizyki kwantowej polegaô na sformuôowaniu postulatywnych zasad ilustrujácych sens fizyczny fizyki kwantowej: w 1927 W. Heisenberg podaô zasadê nieoznaczonoäci (Heisenberga zasada nieoznaczonoäci), w 1928 N. Bohr wprowadziô zasadê komplementarnoäci. Pod koniec lat 20. pojawiôy siê niezaleëne od siebie matematyczne sformuôowania mechaniki kwantowej (Heisenberga obraz, Schrödingera obraz) oparte na koncepcji operatorów dziaôajácych na funkcje falowe. Pierwsze caôoäciowe matematyczne ujêcie mechaniki kwantowej podaô P.A.M. Dirac (w dziele The Principles of Quantum Mechanics, 1958). Kolejny etap rozwoju fizyki kwantowej polegaô na skwantowaniu pól fizycznych (elektrodynamika kwantowa, chromodynamika kwantowa).

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"If anybody says he can think about quantum physics without getting giddy, that only shows he has not understood the first thing about them." - Niels Bohr
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Si quelqu'un dit qu'il ne peut penser à la physique quantique sans attraper le vertige, cela montre seulement qu'il n'en a pas compris une seule mot." - Niels Bohr
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Jeäli teoria kwantowa nie wywarôa na tobie wstrzásajácego wraëenia, nie zrozumiesz jej." - Niels Bohr

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Quantum Physics[COLOR_REVERT] reveals the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Uranium[COLOR_REVERT] resource.
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]physique quantique[COLOR_REVERT] révèle l'[COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]uranium[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Quantum Teleportation
TEXT.French: Téléportation quantique
TEXT.Polish: Teleportacja Kwantowa

TEXT.English: [TAB]Quantum teleportation, or entanglement-assisted teleportation, is a technique used to transfer information on a quantum level, usually from one particle (or series of particles) to another particle (or series of particles) in another location via quantum entanglement. It does not transport energy or matter, nor does it allow communication of information at superluminal (faster than light) speed. Neither does it concern rearranging the particles of a macroscopic object to copy the form of another object. Therefore it is quite distinct from the teleportation common in science fiction in which a macroscopic object is recreated at another location. Its distinguishing feature is that it can transmit the information present in a quantum superposition, useful for quantum communication and computation. [PARAGRAPH:2]More precisely, quantum teleportation is a quantum protocol by which a qubit a (the basic unit of quantum information) can be transmitted exactly (in principle) from one location to another. The prerequisites are a conventional communication channel capable of transmitting two classical bits (i.e. one of four states), and an entangled pair (b,c) of qubits, with b at the origin and c at the destination. (So whereas b and c are intimately related, a is entirely independent of them other than being initially colocated with b.) The protocol has three steps: measure a and b jointly to yield two classical bits; transmit the two bits to the other end of the channel (the only potentially time-consuming step, due to speed-of-light considerations); and use the two bits to select one of four ways of recovering c. The upshot of this protocol is to permute the original arrangement ((a,b),c) to ((b′,c′),a), that is, a moves to where c was and the previously separated qubits of the Bell pair turn into a new Bell pair (b′,c′) at the origin.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Teleportacja kwantowa – w kwantowej teorii informacji technika pozwalajáca na przeniesienie stanu kwantowego na dowolná odlegôoäâ z wykorzystaniem stanu splátanego, co umoëliwia transmisjê klasycznej informacji.Informacja nie moëe byâ w ten sposób transmitowana z prêdkoäciá nadäwietlná. Teleportacja kwantowa jest uëyteczna w komunikacji kwantowej oraz podczas obliczeñ kwantowych.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"A philosopher once said, 'It is necessary for the very existence of science that the same conditions always produce the same results.' Well, they don't!" -Richard P. Feynman
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Un philosophe a dit un jour: «Il est nécessaire pour l'existence même de la science que les mêmes conditions produisent toujours les mêmes résultats." Eh bien, ce n'est pas le cas!" -Richard P. Feynman
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Teleportuj mnie!" - z filmu "Star Trek"

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Quantum Teleportation[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Quantum Lab[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]téléportation quantique[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire le [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]laboratoire quantique[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Radar
TEXT.French: Radar
TEXT.Polish: Radar

TEXT.English: [TAB]Radar is a device for locating objects by means of transmitted and reflected high frequency radio waves; it is used mainly for direction finding and navigation. Radar, which stands for RAdio Direction And Ranging, was developed by the British in World War II to detect incoming German fighters and bombers.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Urzádzenie sôuëáce do wykrywania - za pomocá fal radiowych - obiektów powietrznych, nawodnych oraz ládowych takich jak: samoloty, ämigôowce, rakiety, statki (równieë chmury oraz obiekty terenowe), pozwalajáce na okreälenie kierunku, odlegôoäci a takëe wielkoäci obiektu, a w radarach dopplerowskich takëe, do pomiarów prêdkoäci wykrywanego obiektu. Do wykrywania obiektów wykorzystuje siê zjawisko odbicia fal radiowych (najczêäciej w tym celu wykorzystuje siê pasmo mikrofal) od wykrywanych obiektów lub fal wysyôane przez te obiekty. W radarze aktywnym nadajnik radaru emituje wiázkê promieniowania oäwietlajácá badany obszar, sygnaô odbija siê od obiektu i odbierany w odbiorniku znajdujácym siê zazwyczaj w tym samym miejscu co nadajnik. Radar pasywny nie emituje promieniowania, a jedynie odbiera promieniowanie wysyôane najczêäciej w celach komunikacyjnych przez samoloty, a w astronomii przez obiekty kosmiczne. Docierajácy do odbiornika sygnaô jest bardzo sôaby, dlatego trzeba konstruowaâ odpowiednie anteny i odbiorniki umoëliwiajáce okreälenie kierunku, natêëenia fali i jej inne parametry. Urzádzenia radarowe majá obecnie wiele zastosowañ, m.in. w meteorologii do wykrywania chmur burzowych, kontroli ruchu lotniczego, morskiego, prêdkoäci poruszajácych siê pojazdów przez policjê oraz w wojsku. Wykorzystuje siê je równieë do tworzenia obrazów o wysokiej rozróënialnoäci stosujác technikê syntezowania apertury (SAR - ang. synthetic aperture radar). Poprzednikiem tej technologii byô pokôadowy radar obserwacji bocznej SLAR.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"We tend to pay attention to that which is the most current on our radar screen." - Warren Rudman
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Nous avons tendance à accorder de l'attention à ce qui est le plus récent sur notre écran radar." - Warren Rudman
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Czekamy na sygnaô Czekamy na sygnaô Czekamy na sygnaô Z Centrali Centrala nas Ocali" - Brygada Kryzys piosenka "Centrala"

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Radar[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Radar Station[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Radio Telescope[COLOR_REVERT] and enables the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Sentry II[COLOR_REVERT] promotion.
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]radar[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire une [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]station radar[COLOR_REVERT] et un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]radio-téléscope[COLOR_REVERT] et active la promotion [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]sentinelle II[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Railgun
TEXT.French: Canon électrique
TEXT.Polish: Broñ Kinetyczna

TEXT.English: [TAB]A railgun is a purely electrical gun that accelerates a conductive projectile along a pair of metal rails using the same principles as the homopolar motor. Railguns use two sliding or rolling contacts that permit a large electric current to pass through the projectile. This current interacts with the strong magnetic fields generated by the rails and this accelerates the projectile. The U.S. Navy has tested a railgun that accelerates a 7 pound projectile to seven times the speed of sound. [PARAGRAPH:2]Railguns are being pursued as weapons with projectiles that do not contain explosives, but are given extremely high velocities: 3500 m/s (11,500 ft/s, approximately Mach 10 at sea level) or more (for comparison, the M16 rifle has a muzzle speed of 930 m/s, or 3,000 ft/s), which would make their kinetic energy equal or superior to the energy yield of an explosive-filled shell of greater mass. This would allow more ammunition to be carried and eliminate the hazards of carrying explosives in a tank or naval weapons platform. Also, by firing at higher velocities railguns have greater range, less bullet drop and less wind drift, bypassing the inherent cost and physical limitations of conventional firearms - "the limits of gas expansion prohibit launching an unassisted projectile to velocities greater than about 1.5 km/s and ranges of more than 50 miles [80 km] from a practical conventional gun system."[PARAGRAPH:2]If it were possible to apply the technology as a rapid-fire automatic weapon, a railgun would have further advantages in increased rate of fire. The feed mechanisms of a conventional firearm must move to accommodate the propellant charge as well as the ammunition round, while a railgun would only need to accommodate the projectile. Furthermore, a railgun would not have to extract a spent cartridge case from the breech, meaning that a fresh round could be cycled almost immediately after the previous round has been shot.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Broñ kinetyczna rodzaj broni sôuëácej do niszczenia celu przez gwaôtowne dostarczenie mu energii kinetycznej. Pocisk kinetyczny moëe posiadaâ wôasny napêd rakietowy, bádé teë dziêki sile bezwôadnoäci korzystaâ z prêdkoäci nadanej mu przez rakietê noäná, wôasny silnik rakietowy wykorzystujác jedynie do wykonania manewrów niezbêdnych do naprowadzenia na cel. Klasycznymi przykôadami pocisku kinetycznego, sá jednak kamieñ, katapulta, strzaôa, czy pocisk pistoletowy. Zasadê dziaôania broni kinetycznej, wykorzystuje równieë tzw. Electromagnetic Railgun[1]. Ze wzglêdu na niezbêdná do bezpoäredniego trafienia w cel precyzjê naprowadzania, pocisk kinetyczny wyposaëony jest zwykle w szereg zaawansowanych urzádzeñ naprowadzajácych, bardzo precyzyjnych sensorów podczerwieni oraz urzádzeñ optycznych lub radarowych. Podstawowymi cechami charakterystycznymi broni kinetycznych, sá niezbêdna dla uzyskania wôaäciwej wielkoäci energii kinetycznej olbrzymia prêdkoäâ - siêgajáca nawet kilkunastu kilometrów na sekundê - oraz brak wybuchowego ôadunku bojowego. Wspóôczeänie, broñ tego rodzaju czêsto wykorzystywana jest w systemach obrony antybalistycznej oraz przeciwrakietowej.

TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Nie wiem jaka broñ bêdzie uëyta w trzeciej wojnie äwiatowej, ale czwarta bêdzie na kije i kamienie." - Albert Einstein

TEXT.English: Rapid Prototyping
TEXT.French: Prototypage rapide
TEXT.Polish: Szybkie Wyk. Prototypów

TEXT.English: [TAB]Rapid prototyping is the automatic construction of physical objects using solid freeform fabrication. The first techniques for rapid prototyping became available in the late 1980s and were used to produce models and prototype parts. Today, they are used for a much wider range of applications and are even used to manufacture production quality parts in relatively small numbers. Some sculptors use the technology to produce complex shapes for fine arts exhibitions.[PARAGRAPH:2]Rapid prototyping takes virtual designs from computer aided design (CAD) or animation modeling software, transforms them into thin, virtual, horizontal cross-sections and then creates each cross-section in physical space, one after the next until the model is finished. It is a WYSIWYG process where the virtual model and the physical model correspond almost identically.[PARAGRAPH:2]With additive fabrication, the machine reads in data from a CAD drawing and lays down successive layers of liquid, powder, or sheet material, and in this way builds up the model from a series of cross sections. These layers, which correspond to the virtual cross section from the CAD model, are joined together or fused automatically to create the final shape. The primary advantage to additive fabrication is its ability to create almost any shape or geometric feature.[PARAGRAPH:2]The standard data interface between CAD software and the machines is the STL file format. An STL file approximates the shape of a part or assembly using triangular facets. Smaller facets produce a higher quality surface.[PARAGRAPH:2]The word "rapid" is relative: construction of a model with contemporary methods can take from several hours to several days, depending on the method used and the size and complexity of the model. Additive systems for rapid prototyping can typically produce models in a few hours, although it can vary widely depending on the type of machine being used and the size and number of models being produced simultaneously.[PARAGRAPH:2]Some solid freeform fabrication techniques use two materials in the course of constructing parts. The first material is the part material and the second is the support material (to support overhanging features during construction). The support material is later removed by heat or dissolved away with a solvent or water.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Rapid Prototyping (Szybkie Wykonywanie Prototypów) - okreälenie zbioru metod sôuëácych do szybkiej, precyzyjnej i powtarzalnej produkcji elementów w technologii addytywnej (np. z wykorzystaniem stereolitografii lub drukowania przestrzennego), zwykle przy sterowaniu komputerowym.Pierwsze rozwiázania typu rapid prototyping staôy siê dostêpne w latach 80. XX wieku.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Prototyping is a big deal right now. Même Les clients demandent des prototypes. Mais le problème ... c'est que le prototypage n'est pas une panacée."

TEXT.English: Realism
TEXT.French: Réalisme
TEXT.Polish: Realizm

TEXT.English: [TAB]Realism in the visual arts and literature is the depiction of subjects as they appear in everyday life, without embellishment or interpretation. The term is also used to describe works of art which, in revealing a truth, may emphasize the ugly or sordid. Realism also refers to a mid-19th century cultural movement with its roots in France, where it was a very popular art form around the mid to late 1800s. It came about with the introduction of photography - a new visual source that created a desire for people to produce things that look “objectively real”. Realism was heavily against romanticism, a genre dominating French literature and artwork in the late 18th and early 19th century. Undistorted by personal bias, Realism believed in the ideology of objective reality and revolted against exaggerated emotionalism. Truth and accuracy became the goals of many Realists.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Realizm - pojêcie wieloznaczne, zmieniajáce sens w zaleënoäci od kontekstu. Ogólnie jest to silna wiara w obiektywne (realne) istnienie zewnêtrznego äwiata w formie zgodnej z tym, jaki przedstawia siê on ludzkim zmysôom i rozumowi oraz odrzucanie wszelkich koncepcji sugerujácych subiektywnoäâ jego istnienia lub zaprzeczajácych jego substancjalnoäci.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Art is a lie that makes us realize truth." - Pablo Picasso
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"L'art est un mensonge qui nous fait comprendre la vérité." - Pablo Picasso
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Aby realizm nie byô sôowem pozbawionym sensu, wszyscy ludzie musieliby mieâ jednaki umysô i jednaki sposób pojmowania." - Eugene Delacroix

TEXT.English: Recycling
TEXT.French: Recyclage
TEXT.Polish: Recykling

TEXT.English: [TAB]Recycling is the reprocessing of materials into new products. Recycling generally prevents the waste of potentially useful materials, reduces the consumption of raw materials and reduces energy usage, and hence greenhouse gas emissions, compared to virgin production.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Recykling - jedna z kompleksowych metod ochrony ärodowiska naturalnego. Jej celem jest ograniczenie zuëycia surowców naturalnych oraz zmniejszenie iloäci odpadów. Zasadá dziaôania recyklingu jest maksymalizacja ponownego wykorzystania tych samych materiaôów, z uwzglêdnieniem minimalizacji nakôadów na ich przetworzenie, przez co chronione sá surowce naturalne, które sôuëá do ich wytworzenia oraz surowce sôuëáce do ich póéniejszego przetworzenia. Recykling odbywa siê w dwóch obszarach: produkowania dóbr oraz póéniejszego powstawania z nich odpadów. Zaôoëenia recyklingu zakôadajá wymuszanie odpowiednich postaw producentów dóbr, sprzyjajácych produkcji materiaôów jak najbardziej odzyskiwalnych oraz tworzenie odpowiednich zachowañ u odbiorców tych dóbr.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"We live in a disposable society. It's easier to throw things out than to fix them. We even give it a name - we call it recycling." - Neil LaBute
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Nous vivons dans une société du jetable. Il est plus facile de jeter les choses que de les corriger. Nous avons même lui donner un nom - nous l'appelons le recyclage." - Neil LaBute
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Perôê wäród ämieci - trudno dostrzec, ale ämieâ wäród pereô - wiaâ od razu." - Wôadysôaw Grzeszczyk

TEXT.English: Refining
TEXT.French: Raffinage
TEXT.Polish: Rafinacja

TEXT.English: [TAB]When the demand for oil-based fuels for lighting and other purposes began to soar in the 19th century, scientists began searching for a way to make use of crude oil. This research led to techniques in which crude oil was broken down, or refined, into a number of different fuels, including kerosene and gasoline. As consumer demand continued to increase, commercial refineries were set up to purify crude oil. The new petroleum products produced as a result of the development and perfection of the refining process led to the use of oil-based fuels in many consumer and industrial applications. These include the use of gasoline to power automobiles, and the use of oil for heating and for the generation of electrical power.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Rafinacja - oczyszczanie substancji (np. tôuszczów, benzyn) w celu nadania im odpowiednich wôaäciwoäci, np. pozbawienia zabarwienia, poprawienia zapachu, zwiêkszenia trwaôoäci. Rafinacja moëe odbyâ siê za pomocá metod fizycznych (destylacja, ekstrakcja) lub chemicznych (dziaôanie kwasami, zasadami)

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"There's an ocean of oil under our feet, and no one can get to it but me." - Danial Day lewis as Danial Plainview in 'There Will Be Blood.'
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Il ya un océan de pétrole sous nos pieds, et personne ne peut arriver y accéder sauf moi." - Danial Day lewis dans 'There Will Be Blood.'
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Pod naszymi stopami znajduje siê ocean ropy naftowej i nikt moëe dostaâ siê do niej tylko ja." - Danial Day lewis jako Danial Plainview w filmie 'Aë poleje siê krew.'

Cela permet aussi de construire une [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]raffinerie de pétrôle[COLOR_REVERT] et une [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]usine de caoutchouc[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Regenerative Medicine
TEXT.French: Médicine régénératrice
TEXT.Polish: Medycyna Regeneracyjna

TEXT.English: [TAB]Medical researchers believe that stem cell treatments have the potential to change the face of human disease and alleviate suffering. A number of stem cell treatments already exist, although most are still experimental and/or costly, with the notable exception of bone marrow transplantation. In the future, medical researchers anticipate being able to use technologies derived from adult and embryonic stem cell research to treat cancer, Type 1 diabetes mellitus, spinal cord injuries, and muscle damage, amongst a number of other diseases and impairments.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Medycyna Regeneracyjna to jedna z najbardziej obiecujácych kierunków nauk medycznych w historii. Zajmuje siê ona odbudowá zniszczonych narzádów i tworzeniem w laboratorium nowych. Juë w obecnych czasach w laboratorium powstaôy zamienniki skóry, koäci i chrzástki. W kolejce czekajá nastêpne tkanki i narzády. Jeäli projekt siê powiedzie, cukrzyca, niewydolnoäâ serca, urazy rdzenia krêgowego – staná siê wyleczalne. Naukowcy próbujá na róëne sposoby osiágnáâ cele. Jeden kierunek to pobudzenie organizmu, by sam reperowaô uszkodzone tkanki. Drugi sposób to wszczepienie w narzád implantu, który pobudzi regeneracjê. Trzecia droga to transplantacja wyhodowanych w laboratorium tkanek do uszkodzonego organu.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"We have shown that regenerative medicine techniques can be used to generate functional bladders that are durable. This suggests that regenerative medicine may one day be a solution to the shortage of donor organs in this country for those needing transplants." - Anthony Atala

Ceci suggère que la médecine régénérative peut être un jour une solution à la pénurie de donneurs d'organes dans ce pays pour ceux qui ont besoin des greffes." - Anthony Atala
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Medycyna nie zna tajemnicy wyleczenia, ale zapewnia sobie umiejêtnoäâ przedôuëania choroby." - Marcel Proust

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Regenerative Medicine[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to train [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Genetic Soldiers[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]médecine régénérative[COLOR_REVERT] permet de recruter des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]soldats génétiques[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Repeating Weapons
TEXT.French: Armes semi-automatiques
TEXT.Polish: Broñ Automatyczna

TEXT.English: [TAB]A semi-automatic, or self-loading firearm is a gun that requires only a trigger pull for each round that is fired, unlike a single-action revolver, a pump-action firearm, a bolt-action firearm, or a lever-action firearm, which require the shooter to manually chamber each successive round. For example, to fire ten rounds in a semi-automatic firearm, the trigger would need to be pulled ten times (once for each round fired), in contrast to a fully automatic firearm, which can continue to fire as long as the trigger is held or until it runs out of ammunition.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Broñ póôautomatyczna - rodzaj broni palnej, w której czêäâ operacji cyklu pracy broni jest wykonywana kosztem energii gazów prochowych lub zewnêtrznych éródeô energii, a czêäâ rêcznie przez obsôugê.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"An average Zulu is any more than a match for an average Englishman in bodily capacity. But he flees from an English boy, because he fears the boy's revolver or those who will use it for him." - Mahatma Gandhi
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Un Zoulou moyen est un défi pour un Anglais de constitution moyenne. Mais il s'enfuit devant un Anglais, parce qu'il craint son revolver ou ceux qui vont l'utiliser pour lui." - Mahatma Gandhi
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Wyjäâ na ulicê, ëeby policja mogôa nas biâ paôkami? Bez sensu. Pójdê pod warunkiem, ëe dacie mi broñ." - Che Guevara

Cette tech. améliore le rendement des [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]camps[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Replacement Organs
TEXT.French: Remplacement d'organes
TEXT.Polish: Organy Zastêpcze

TEXT.English: [TAB]The idea that human organs could be cloned resulted in the best argument for therapeutic cloning, since this would end the need for organ donors and the waiting lists around the perpetual shortage of organs. Also, humans cloned from the recipient's DNA means that the recipient does would not need immunosuppressive drugs and no worries about organ rejection. However, this also brought up a list of ethical issues, most of which are around the practice of human cloning and gene manipulation, the largest being the disabled who could not afford such treatments would be considered some sort of out group.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Embrionalne komórki macierzyste (ang. Embryonic Stem Cell - ESC); komórki, które mogá daâ poczátek wszystkim moëliwym tkankom. Komórki macierzyste piêciodniowego pôodu mogá rozwináâ siê w dowolny typ komórek i teoretycznie zastápiâ uszkodzone komórki, których organizm nie jest w stanie odtworzyâ.Zanik komórek to przyczyna wielu róënych schorzeñ, na przykôad choroby Alzheimera i niewydolnoäci miêänia sercowego. Sztuczna hodowla wyspecjalizowanych komórek z komórek macierzystych oraz ich wszczepianie stanowiôyby przeôom w medycynie.Komórki macierzyste do tego celu moëna uzyskaâ z krwi pêpowinowej lub z wyhodowanych zarodków zwierzát lub ludzi. Juë teraz umiemy wykorzystaâ komórki macierzyste do leczenia choroby Parkinsona, cukrzycy i urazów krêgosôupa u myszy. W organizmie myszy, której wszczepiono komórki macierzyste, uzyskano komórki oka, nerwów, koäci i miêäni. W lutym 2004 uczeni z Seulu sklonowali ludzkie zarodki celem pobrania z nich komórek do uzyskania tkanek i organów dla chorych np. na cukrzycê lub chorobê Parkinsona. Embriony, z których majá byâ hodowane organy zastêpcze, w zaôoëeniu majá byâ genetyczná kopiá dawcy, co ma zapobiegaâ odrzutom przeszczepu.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"The use of fetuses as organ and tissue donors is a ticking time bomb of bioethics." -Arthur Caplan
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Tylko ëycie poäwiêcone innym warte jest przeëycia." - Albert Einstein

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Replacement Organs[COLOR_REVERT] increases health in all cities and allows you to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Medical Clinic[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]remplacement d'organes[COLOR_REVERT] augmente la santé dans toutes les villes et permet de construire des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]cliniques[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Representative Democracy
TEXT.French: Démocracie représentative
TEXT.Polish: Demokracja Przedstawicielska

TEXT.English: [TAB]Representative Democracy is a form of government founded on the principles of popular sovereignty by the people's representatives. The representatives form an independent ruling body (for an election period) charged with the responsibility of acting in the people's interest, but not as their proxy representatives—i.e., not necessarily always according to their wishes, but with enough authority to exercise swift and resolute initiative in the face of changing circumstances. It is often contrasted with direct democracy, where representatives are absent or are limited in power as proxy representatives. [PARAGRAPH:2]In many representative democracies (Canada, the USA, Britain, etc), representatives are most commonly chosen in elections by a plurality of those who are both eligible to cast votes and actually do so. A plurality means that a winning candidate has to win more votes than any other candidate in the race, but does not necessarily require a majority of the votes cast. While existing representative democracies hold such elections to choose representatives, in theory other methods, such as sortition (more closely aligned with direct democracy), could be used instead. Also, representatives sometimes hold the power to select other representatives, presidents, or other officers of government (indirect representation).
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Demokracja Przedstawicielska to rodzaj demokracji, gdzie decyzje podejmujá przedstawiciele spoôeczeñstwa wybrani w wyborach. Model ten jest zastosowany w wiêkszoäci pañstw demokratycznych, m.in. w Polsce.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Everybody counts in applying democracy. And there will never be a true democracy until every responsible and law-abiding adult in it, without regard to race, sex, color or creed has his or her own inalienable and unpurchasable voice in government." - Carrie Chapman Catt
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Tout le monde compte dans l'application de la démocratie. Et il n'y aura jamais de vraie démocratie tant que tous les adultes responsables et respectueux de la loi, sans distinction de race, de sexe, de couleur ou de croyance ne dispose de sa propre voix inaliénable et inachetable au sein du gouvernement." - Carrie Chapman Catt
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Demokracja jest wtedy, kiedy dwa wilki i owca gôosujá, co zjedzá na obiad. Wolnoäâ jest wtedy, kiedy dobrze uzbrojona owca podwaëa wynik gôosowania!" - Benjamin Franklin

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Representative Democracy[COLOR_REVERT] enables the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Democracy[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]President[COLOR_REVERT] civics.
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]démocratie représentative[COLOR_REVERT] active les docutrines [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]démocratie[COLOR_REVERT] et [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Président[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Ritualism
TEXT.French: Ritualisme
TEXT.Polish: Obrzêdy Rytualne

TEXT.English: [TAB]A ritual is a set of actions, often thought to have symbolic value, the performance of which is usually prescribed by a religion or by the traditions of a community.[PARAGRAPH:2]The purposes of rituals are varied; they include compliance with religious obligations or ideals, satisfaction of spiritual or emotional needs of the practitioners, strengthening of social bonds, demonstration of respect or submission, stating one's affiliation, obtaining social acceptance or approval for some event — or, sometimes, just for the pleasure of the ritual itself. [PARAGRAPH:2]Due to their symbolic nature, there are hardly any limits to the kind of actions that may be incorporated in a ritual. The rites of past and present societies have typically involved special gestures and words, recitation of fixed texts, performance of special music, songs or dances, processions, manipulation of certain objects, use of special dresses, consumption of special food, drink, or drugs, and much more. Religious rituals have also included animal sacrifice, human sacrifice, ritual suicide, and ritual murder. - Wikipedia
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Obrzêd religijny - system czynnoäci pozwalajácych, wedle danej wiary, uzyskaâ zamierzony przez wyznawców cel. Czêsto zawiera w sobie elementy magii.Obrzêdy w maôych spoôeczeñstwach trudno usystematyzowaâ i sprecyzowaâ, przede wszystkim z powodu wieloäci samych spoôeczeñstw. Obrzêdy bowiem, zaleëá od szeregu czynników, które dla rozjaänienia sprawy moëna nazwaâ warstwami.A zatem poczynajác od éródôa: warunki w plemieniu (liczba osób, miejsce bytowania, klimat, dostêpnoäâ poëywienia i wiele, wiele innych) ksztaôtujá a potem wrêcz narzucajá odpowiedniá etykê, która systematyzuje, reguluje i stabilizuje ëycie spoôeczne, co przekôada siê zaä na subiektywne pojmowanie äwiata (etyka bowiem, stanowi dla znajácego pojêcie, ale nie bêdácego biegôym w socjologii czy antropologii artefakt JEGO wôasnej tradycji - dziaôa to na zasadzie "Co zastaôem to pielêgnujê uwaëajác za prawidôowe i normalne") implikujáce daná teologiê, która z kolei implikuje okreälone obrzêdy.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Ritual will always mean throwing away something: destroying our corn or wine upon the altar of our gods." - Gilbert K. Chesterton
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Faire un rituel signifie toujours jeter quelque-chose: détruire notre maïs ou notre vin sur l'autel de nos dieux." - Gilbert K. Chesterton
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Rytuaô zawsze bêdzie znaczyô odrzucanie czegoä: niszczác nasze zboëe lub wino na oôtarzu naszych bogów." - Gilbert K. Chesterton

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Ritualism[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Monuments[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Lascaux Caves[COLOR_REVERT] (with [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Hunting[COLOR_REVERT]).
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]mysticisme[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]monuments[COLOR_REVERT] et les [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]grottes de Lascaux[COLOR_REVERT] (avec [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]chasse[COLOR_REVERT]).

TEXT.English: Rudder
TEXT.French: Gouvernail
TEXT.Polish: Ster

TEXT.English: "Those who are in love with practice without knowledge are like the sailor who gets into a ship without rudder or compass and who never can be certain whether he is going." - Leonardo da Vinci
TEXT.French: Ceux qui aiment la pratique sans possèder le savoir sont comme le marin qui possède un bateau sans gouvernail ou compas et qui ne peuvent jamais être certains d'où ils vont aller. - Léonard de Vinci

TEXT.English: A rudder is a device used to steer a vehicle operating in a medium (air or water) by direecting the fluid medium around the vehicle. The concept of the rudder evolved from the steering oar, a large oar used more to direct a vessel's movement than to propel it. Rudders evolved in different cultures, but the most important improvement was the European pintle-and-gudgeon rudder, affixing the rudder with iron hinges to a sturdy sternpost on the ship. This provided an excellent attachment and would be a major contributing factor to the Age of Discovery.

[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Rudder[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to train the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Cog[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Galleass[COLOR_REVERT] units. Along with [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Guilds[COLOR_REVERT], it will allow you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Hanseatic League[COLOR_REVERT] wonder.
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]gouvernail[COLOR_REVERT] vous permet de construire une [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]cogue[COLOR_REVERT] et une [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]galléasse[COLOR_REVERT]. Avec les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]guildes[COLOR_REVERT], cela vous permettra de construire la merveille de la [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]ligue hanséatique[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Sacrifice
TEXT.French: Sacrifice
TEXT.Polish: Poäwiêcenie

TEXT.English: [TAB]Sacrifice is commonly known as the practice of offering food or the lives of animals or people to the gods as an act of propitiation or worship. The practice of sacrifice is found in the oldest human records. The archaeological record contains human and animal corpses with sacrificial marks long before any written records of the practice. Sacrifices are a common theme in most religions, though the frequency of animal, and especially human, sacrifices are rare today. [PARAGRAPH:2]Animal sacrifice is the ritual killing of an animal as part of a religion. It is practiced by many religions as a means of appeasing a god or gods or changing the course of nature. Animal sacrifice has turned up in almost all cultures, from the Hebrews to the Greeks and Romans (particularly the purifying ceremony Lustratio) and from the Aztecs to the Yoruba. [PARAGRAPH:2]Human sacrifice was practiced by many ancient cultures. People would be ritually killed in a manner that was supposed to please or appease a god or spirit. Some of the best known ancient human sacrifices were those practiced by various Pre-Columbian civilizations of Mesoamerica. The Aztec were particularly noted for practicing this on an unusually large scale; a human sacrifice would be made every day to aid the sun in rising, the dedication of the great temple at Tenochtitlán was reportedly marked with the sacrificing of thousands, and there are multiple accounts of captured Conquistadores being sacrificed during the wars of the Spanish conquest of Mexico.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Ofiara to podstawowy, obok modlitwy, akt kultu religijnego, wystêpujácy we wszystkich religiach, poczáwszy od pierwotnych do najbardziej rozwiniêtych. Polega na skôadaniu darów bóstwu. Czêsto ôáczony z ucztá religijná.Celem ofiary jest wykonanie zobowiázania wobec bóstwa, przebôaganie i zapewnienie sobie przychylnoäci, pomocy lub zôagodzenie gniewu. Przedmiot ofiary byô uzaleëniony od trybu ëycia ludnoäci. W kulturze myäliwskiej i hodowlanej skôadano w ofierze przewaënie zwierzêta. W kulturze rolniczej obok zwierzát ofiarowano pôody ziemi, jak zboëe, mákê, placki, oliwê, wino, owoce, kwiaty. W wierzeniach Sôowian zwana obiatá, trzebá lub ëertwá.Ofiarê z czôowieka - formê mordu rytualnego praktykowano w wielu staroëytnych kulturach, zwôaszcza w Mezoameryce i na Bliskim Wschodzie.W religii chrzeäcijañskiej skôadanie ofiar zostaôo zastápione przez jednorazowá doskonaôá ofiarê Jezusa Chrystusa, który umarô na krzyëu za grzechy ludzkoäci. W katolicyzmie i prawosôawiu ofiara Chrystusa jest sakramentalnie uobecniana podczas Eucharystii.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"In hard core satanic groups they believe the best way to raise the energy are either the sexual act or by murdering something, either an animal or a person...an enormous amount of energy is released...with a human being there is even more energy released...if you want to raise the ultimate kind of power you sacrifice someone. The first is the baby as there is a huge amount of life energy, next is the virgin, and finally anybody." - Bill Schnoebelen
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Les groupes sataniques extrêmistes croient que la meilleure façon d'obtenir plus d'énergie est soit l'acte sexuel ou le meurtre de quelque chose, que ce soit un animal ou une personne ... une énorme quantité d'énergie est libérée ... avec un être humain, il y a encore plus d'énergie libérée ... Si vous voulez atteindre le stade ultime, vous sacrifiez une personne. Le premier est le bébé car il y a une énorme quantité d'énergie de vie, puis la Vierge, et enfin tout le monde." - Bill Schnoebelen
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Ofiara jest demonstracjá ku czci Boga." - Karl Barth

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Sacrifice[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Ceremonial Altar[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Chichen Itza[COLOR_REVERT] (with [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Masonry[COLOR_REVERT]).
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]culte sacrificiel[COLOR_REVERT] procure l'[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]autel de cérémonie[COLOR_REVERT] et permet la merveille du [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Chichén Itzá[COLOR_REVERT] (avec [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]maçonnerie[COLOR_REVERT]).

TEXT.English: Sanitation
TEXT.French: Assainissement
TEXT.Polish: Kanalizacja

TEXT.English: [TAB]The increased waste produced by growing populations over time eventually led to potential health hazards, often leading to outbreaks of waterborne diseases in these cramped dwellings. It then became necessary to come up with systems to dispose of garbage and human waste in a sanitary manner. Plumbing systems designed to remove wastewater from dwellings and public buildings became commonplace, as did sewage plants which treated the wastewater before it was dumped into local waterways. Landfills were established, and garbage was collected for sanitary disposal in dumps and landfills a safe distance from the general population. These measures led to a healthier environment, and allowed for further population growth.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Kanalizacja jest to system rur, koryt, kolektorów sôuëácy do odprowadzania äcieków sanitarnych (kanalizacja sanitarna), deszczowych (kanalizacja deszczowa) lub sanitarnych i deszczowych (kanalizacja ogólnospôawna).Rozróënia siê kanalizacjê wewnêtrzná i zewnêtrzná. W niektórych aglomeracjach miejskich o ciasnej zabudowie (np. Palma de Mallorca) stosowana bywa równieë kanalizacja do odprowadzania odpadów staôych (ämieci) w postaci rozdrobnionej.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"When I got out of high school they retired my jersey, but it was for hygiene and sanitary reasons" - George Carlin
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Quand je suis sorti de l'école secondaire, ils m'ont retiré mon maillot, mais c'était pour des raisons sanitaires et d'hygiènes" - George Carlin
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Cicha woda zawsze pôynie gôêboko." - Stephen King

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Sanitation[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Sewer System[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]assainissement[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]système d'égouts[COLOR_REVERT] dans vos villes.

TEXT.English: Screw Propeller
TEXT.French: Vis hélicoïdale
TEXT.Polish: Äruba Okrêtowa

TEXT.English: [TAB]The principle employed in using a screw propeller is used in sculling. It is part of the skill of propelling a Venetian gondola but was used in a less refined way in other parts of Europe and probably elsewhere. [PARAGRAPH:2]In sculling, a single blade is moved through an arc, from side to side taking care to keep presenting the blade to the water at the effective angle. The innovation introduced with the screw propeller was the extension of that arc through more than 360 degrees by attaching the blade to a rotating shaft. In practice, there has to be more than one blade so as to balance the forces involved. The exception is the Single-blade propeller system. [PARAGRAPH:2]The origin of the actual screw propeller starts, in the West, with Archimedes, who used a screw to lift water for irrigation and bailing boats, so famously that it became known as the Archimedes screw. It was probably an application of spiral movement in space (spirals were a special study of Archimedes) to a hollow segmented water-wheel used for irrigation by Egyptians for centuries. Leonardo da Vinci adopted the principle to drive his theoretical helicopter, sketches of which involved a large canvas screw overhead. [PARAGRAPH:2]In 1784, J. P. Paucton proposed a gyrocopter-like aircraft using similar screws for both lift and propulsion. At about the same time, James Watt proposed using screws to propel boats, although he did not use them for his steam engines. This was not his own invention, though; Toogood and Hays had patented it a century earlier, and it had become an uncommon use as a means of propelling boats since that time. [PARAGRAPH:2]By 1827 Robert Welch had invented a screw propeller which had multiple blades fastened around a conical base; this new method of propulsion allowed steam ships to travel at much greater speeds without using sails thereby making ocean travel faster. Propellers remained extremely inefficient and little-utilized until 1835, when Francis Pettit Smith discovered a new way of building propellers. Up to that time, propellers were literally screws, of considerable length. But during the testing of a boat propelled by one, the screw snapped off, leaving a fragment shaped much like a modern boat propeller. The boat moved faster with the broken propeller.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Äruba okrêtowa - rodzaj pêdnika o napêdzie mechanicznym, jeden ze sposobów napêdzania statku wodnego - przetwarza ruch obrotowy waôu ärubowego na siôê naporu poruszajácá statek. Spotykane sá äruby od trzech do piêciu ôopat (najczêäciej stosuje siê czteroôopatowe). Ponadto rozróënia siê äruby staôe (o staôym skoku) i nastawne. Äruby okrêtowe o skoku staôym stosowane sá w ukôadach napêdowych z silnikami nawrotnymi, gdzie prêdkoäâ i kierunek (naprzód/wstecz) poruszania siê jednostki regulowana jest prêdkoäciá obrotowá i kierunkiem obrotów gôównego silnika napêdowego statku. Äruba nastawna (tzw. o zmiennym skoku) ma moëliwoäâ ustawienia káta ôopat, dziêki czemu zachowujác jeden kierunek obrotów i staôá wartoäâ prêdkoäci obrotowej silnika gôównego, poprzez zmianê jedynie káta wychylenia ôopat, moëna pôynáâ do przodu lub wstecz ze zmienná prêdkoäciá, zaä w przypadku ustawienia ôopat äruby nastawnej w poôoëeniu neutralnym (zerowym) nie wytwarzajá one siôy naporu.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Have you ever considered a spiral oar?" - James Watt
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Avez-vous déjà considéré comme un aviron en spirale?" - James Watt
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Rozwaëyôeä kiedykolwiek spiralne wiosôo?" - James Watt

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Screw Propeller[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to construct [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Ironclad[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Modern Workboat[COLOR_REVERT] and is required to found [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Sid's Sushi Co[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]vis hélicoïdale[COLOR_REVERT] est requise pour construire des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]cuirassiers[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]bateaux-atelier modernes[COLOR_REVERT] et pour fonder [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Sid's Sushi Co[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Scriptures
TEXT.French: Textes sacrés
TEXT.Polish: Skrypty

TEXT.English: "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God." - The Bible, John 1:1
TEXT.French: Au commencement il y à le mot, et le mot fut avec Dieu, et le mot fut Dieu - La Bible, John 1:1

TEXT.English: Scriptures is a term used to refer to the holy writings of a religion. Writing was naturally used to record religious precepts, as priests were some of the most important persons in ancient civilizations. Some of the earliest religious texts are the Pyramid Texts of ancient Egypt, dating to 2400-2300 BCE. The first Hindu Vedas date to between 1500-1000 BCE and are still in use today. Many religions believe that their scriptures are divinely inspired or revealed, while scholars study them to understand how they were authored and how religions have evolved over time.
[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Scriptures[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Scriptorium[COLOR_REVERT] and allows the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Divine Cult[COLOR_REVERT] civic.
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]textes sacrés[COLOR_REVERT] vous permettent de bâtir un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]scriptorium[COLOR_REVERT] et permettent d'adopter la doctrine du [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]culte divin[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Sculpture
TEXT.Polish: Rzeébiarstwo

TEXT.English: [TAB]Carving stone into sculpture is an activity older than civilization itself. Prehistoric sculptures were usually human forms, such as the Venus of Willendorf and the faceless statues of the Cycladic cultures of ancient Greece. Later cultures devised animal, human-animal and abstract forms in stone. The earliest cultures used abrasive techniques, and modern technology employs pneumatic hammers and other devices. But for most of human history, sculptors used hammer and chisel as the basic tools for carving stone. - Wikipedia
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Rzeéba - jedna z dyscyplin zaliczanych do sztuk plastycznych. Odróënia já od malarstwa i grafiki trójwymiarowoäâ. Rzeéby sá gô. wykonane do ogládania dookólnego, a rzadziej np. do spogládania na nie z góry czy z doôu. Oprócz tych cech rzeéba moëe posiadaâ fakturê (w zaleënoäci od uëytego materiaôu) lub kolor (tzw. rzeéba polichromowana). Moëe byâ równieë klasyfikowana ze wzglêdu na swojá skalê (np. miniaturowa lub monumentalna). W dawnych wiekach uksztaôtowaôy siê niezwykle skomplikowane techniki tworzenia rzeéby.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]The best artist has that thought alone Which is contained within the marble shell; The sculptor's hand can only break the spell To free the figures slumbering in the stone. - Michelangelo
TEXT.French: [SPACE]Le meilleur artiste ne fait que découvrir tout seul ce qui est contenu dans l'essence du marbre; La main du sculpteur ne fait que rompre le charme pour libérer les figures qui sommeillent dans la pierre. - Michelangelo
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]Najlepszy artysta tak pomyälaô samotnie Który jest zawarty w skorupie marmuru; Rêka rzeébiarza moëe tylko przerwaâ czar, By uwolniâ ksztaôty drzemiáce w kamieniu. - Michelangelo

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Sculpture[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Sculptor's Workshop[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Moai Statues[COLOR_REVERT] (with [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Seafaring[COLOR_REVERT]) and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Abu Simbel[COLOR_REVERT] (with [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Priesthood[COLOR_REVERT]).
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]textes sacrés[COLOR_REVERT] vous permettent de bâtir un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]scriptorium[COLOR_REVERT], les [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]statues Moaï[COLOR_REVERT] (avec [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]voyage en mer[COLOR_REVERT]) et le [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]temple d'Abu Simbel[COLOR_REVERT] (avec [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]clergé[COLOR_REVERT]).

TEXT.English: Seafaring
TEXT.French: Voyage en mer
TEXT.Polish: Ëegluga Morska

TEXT.English: [TAB]In ancient times, mariners navigated by the guidance of the sun and stars and landmarks along the coast. The Phoenicians were probably the most daring of the ancient navigators. They built large ships and, traveling out of sight of land by day and by night, probably circumnavigated Africa. The Polynesians navigated from island to island with the help of guide stars, knowledge of which was passed from generation to generation. The Vikings used their longships to navigate from their homes in Norway and Denmark to the Islands of Iceland, Greenland and finally to Newfoundland (America).
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Ëegluga Morska jest jedna z form transportu wodnego. Oznacza w szczególnoäci przewóz statkami, w celach zarobkowych, pasaëerów i ladunków, przez wody morskie lub sródládowe. Do przewozu towarów uëywa sie wielu wyspecjalizowanych statków: masowców, drobnicowców, kontenerowców, tankowców oraz chemikaliowców. Przewozy pasaëerskie stanowiá znikomy odsetek ogólnego transportu ludzi, a to ze wzgledu na dlugi czas podrózy. Jedynie w niektórych regionach swiata, na przyklad na obszarach o silnie rozwinietej linii brzegowej lub w panstwach wyspiarskich, wazna role odgrywa komunikacja promowa.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"If the highest aim of a captain were to preserve his ship, he would keep it in port forever" - St. Thomas Aquinas
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Si le plus grand objectif pour un capitaine est de préserver son navire, il doit rester au port à jamais" - St. Thomas Aquinas
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Jeëeli najwyëszym celem kapitana byôoby ochranianie jego statku, trzymaôby go zawsze w porcie." - St. Thomas Aquinas

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Seafaring[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Harbor[COLOR_REVERT] and is also required to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Moai Statues[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]The Great Lighthouse[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]voyage en mer[COLOR_REVERT] permet la construction d'un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]port[COLOR_REVERT]. C'est un pré-requis pour les [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]statues Moaï[COLOR_REVERT] et le [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]grand phare[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Semiconductors
TEXT.French: Semi-conducteurs
TEXT.Polish: Póôprzewodniki

TEXT.English: [TAB]In electronics, an integrated circuit (also known as IC, microcircuit, microchip, silicon chip, or chip) is a miniaturized electronic circuit (consisting mainly of semiconductor devices, as well as passive components) that has been manufactured in the surface of a thin substrate of semiconductor material. -- Wikipedia
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Póôprzewodniki - najczêäciej substancje krystaliczne, których konduktywnoäâ (zwana teë konduktancjá wôaäciwá) jest rzêdu 10-8 do 106 S/m (simensa na metr), co plasuje je miêdzy przewodnikami a dielektrykami.Wartoäâ rezystancji póôprzewodnika maleje ze wzrostem temperatury. Póôprzewodniki posiadajá pasmo wzbronione miêdzy pasmem walencyjnym a pasmem przewodzenia w zakresie 0 - 5 eV (np. Ge 0,7 eV, Si 1,1 eV , GaAs 1,4 eV, GaN 3,4 eV). Koncentracje noäników ôadunku w póôprzewodnikach moëna zmieniaâ w bardzo szerokich granicach, zmieniajác temperaturê póôprzewodnika lub natêëenie padajácego na niego äwiatôa lub nawet przez äciskanie lub rozciáganie póôprzewodnika.W przemyäle elektronicznym najczêäciej stosowanymi materiaôami póôprzewodnikowymi sá pierwiastki grupy IV (np. krzem, german) oraz zwiázki pierwiastków grup III i V (np. arsenek galu, azotek galu, antymonek indu) lub II i VI (tellurek kadmu). Materiaôy póôprzewodnikowe sá wytwarzane w postaci monokrysztaôu, polikrysztaôu lub proszku.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"I think it's doing very well. I'm pleased to see the concentration on semiconductors. I think this will help." - Jack Kilby
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Je pense que c'est très bien. Je suis heureux de voir la concentration sur les semiconducteurs. Je pense que cela aidera." - Jack Kilby
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Evil one: – Boga nie interesuje technologia. Nie ma pojêcia o potêdze mikro-chipów czy rewolucji krzemowej. Spójrzcie jak spêdza czas. Czterdzieäci trzy gatunki papug! Sutki u mêëczyzn!" - z filmu "Time Bandits" Terr'ego Gilliama

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Semiconductors[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to construct [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Silicon Valley[COLOR_REVERT] and train [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Mobile Artillery[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Missile Destroyer[COLOR_REVERT], and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Modern Battleship[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]semi-conducteurs[COLOR_REVERT] permettent de bâtir la [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Silicon Valley[COLOR_REVERT] et d'entraîner des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]artilleries mobiles[COLOR_REVERT], des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]destroyers lance-missiles[COLOR_REVERT], et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]navires de guerre modernes[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Sentient Earth
TEXT.French: Terre sensible
TEXT.Polish: Äwiadoma Ziemia

TEXT.English: [TAB]Earth, our planet becomes self-aware!
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Ziemia, nasza planeta staje siê äwiadoma!

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Irrigation of the land with seawater desalinated by fusion power is ancient. It's called "rain". " - Michael McClary
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"L'irrigation de la terre avec l'eau de mer dessalinisée par fusion est ancienne. cela s'appelle "la pluie". " - Michael McClary
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Sôoñce podziwia wasze osiágniêcia, a ziemia przykrywa waszá ignorancjê." - John Milton

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Sentient Earth[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Hi-Tech Robot[COLOR_REVERT] and is one of the technologies required to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Ascension Gate[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La tech. '[COLOR_TECH_TEXT]terre sensible[COLOR_REVERT]' permet de construire des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]robots Hi-tech[COLOR_REVERT]. C'est un pré-requis pour la construction de la [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]porte ascensionnelle[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Shielding
TEXT.Polish: Pole Siôowe

TEXT.English: [TAB]Providing shielding for the great domed city arcologies has proven quite challenging. Early attempts relied on thick walls of heavy material; however, bitter experience proved that this material was incapable of fully resisting modern missiles and other armaments - and when it failed, the falling shielding material was at least as dangerous as the missiles themselves to the people below.[PARAGRAPH:2]More recent attempts have relied on much thinner material whose molecular bonds are artificially strengthened by energy fields. The shield material and generators are expensive, but they have proven to provide some protection against nuclear and non-nuclear attack.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Equiper les grandes arcologies pourvues de dômes avec des boucliers n'a pas été une mince affaire. Les premières tentatives ont abouti sur la construction de murs épais construits dans des matériaux lourds et solides. Malheureusement, l'expérience a montré que ces murs n'étaient pas capables de résister aux missiles modernes et qu'ils constituaient, en cas d'attaque, un danger supplémentaire pour les populations situées en dessous. [PARAGRAPH:2]Des essais plus récents ont reposé sur l'utilisation de matériaux plus fins et plus légers, dont la composition moléculaire était renforcée artificiellement par des champs de force. Ces matériaux et les générateurs qu'ils nécessitent sont très coûteux, mais ils sont efficaces contre les missiles, même nucléaires.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Entwicklung eines Schildes für die großen, mit Kuppeln versehenen städtischen Arkologien hat sich als recht kompliziert erwiesen. Für die ersten entsprechenden Versuche wurden dicke Platten aus schwerem Material verwendet, doch dann musste man die bittere Erfahrung machen, dass sie modernen Raketen oder anderen Panzerwaffen nicht standhalten konnten. Darüber hinaus stellten sich die herabfallenden Schildtrümmer als mindestens genauso gefährlich für die darunter befindlichen Menschen heraus wie die Geschosse selbst.[PARAGRAPH:2]Bei den jüngeren Versuchen probierte man daher dünnere Materialien aus, deren molekulare Verbindung durch Energiefelder künstlich verstärkt wird. Dieses Schildmaterial und die zugehörigen Generatoren sind zwar recht teuer, dafür bieten sie aber immerhin einen gewissen Schutz gegen atomare wie auch nicht atomare Angriffe.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Fornire di scudi le grandi cupole delle arcologie è stato abbastanza difficile. I primi tentativi si basavano su spessi strati di materiale pesante. Amare esperienze hanno però dimostrato come questo materiale fosse incapace di resistere appieno ai moderni missili e altre armi e, quando cedeva, per la gente che si trovava sotto, gli scudi che cadevano erano pericolosi quanto gli stessi missili.[PARAGRAPH:2]I tentativi più recenti si affidano a un materiale molto più sottile, i cui legami molecolari sono rinforzati artificialmente mediante dei campi energetici. Il materiale degli scudi e i generatori sono costosi, ma hanno provato di fornire adeguata protezione contro attacchi nucleari e no
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Proteger las grandes ciudades abovedadas que son las arcologías ha demostrado ser todo un desafío. Los primeros ataques contra las gruesas murallas de duro material aportaron, sin embargo, la amarga experiencia de que era incapaz de aguantar los misiles modernos y demás armamento y, al caer, el material era como mínimo igual de peligroso que los mismos misiles para las personas que estaban debajo.[PARAGRAPH:2]Iniciativas más recientes se han basado en materiales más delgados cuyas cadenas moleculares están fortalecidas artificialmente mediante campos de energía. El material protector y los generadores son caros, pero han demostrado ser eficaces contra los ataques, nucleares o n
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Zapewnienie ochrony dla wielkich miejskich arkologi byôo duëym wyzwaniem. Wczesne próby opierwaôy siê na grubych murach wykonanych z ciêëkiego materiaôu. Doäwiadczenie pokazaôo jednak, ëe ten materiaô jest niezdolny do zatrzymania wspóôczesnych pocisków - a kiedy zawiedzie, jest bardziej niebezpieczny od samego wroga i jego arsenaôu.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ostatnie próby bazujá jednak na duëo cieñszym materiale, którego wêzôy molekularne sá sztucznie utwardzane za pomocá pól energii. Materiaô ten, podobnie jak generatory, jest kosztowny, ale zapewnia pewne bezpieczeñstwo przed atakiem nuklearnym bádé konwencjonalnym.

TEXT.English: "We have traded the wind on our faces for a dubious security." - Kim Lau 0X2, Techno-Philosopher
TEXT.French: "Nous avons troqué le vent sur nos visages contre une sécurité toute relative." - Kim Lau 0X2, Techno-philosophe
TEXT.German: "Wir haben den Windhauch auf unserem Gesicht gegen ein zweifelhaftes Gefühl der Sicherheit eingetauscht." - Kim Lau 0X2, Techno-Philosoph
TEXT.Italian: "Abbiamo barattato il vento sul viso con una dubbia sicurezza." - Kim Lau 0X2, tecno-filosof
TEXT.Spanish: "Hemos cambiado el aire libre en nuestras caras por una seguridad dudosa." - Kim Lau 0X2, tecnofilósof
TEXT.Polish: "Wymieniliämy dotyk wiatru na naszych twarzach za wátpliwe bezpieczeñstwo." - Kim Lau 0X2, Technofilozof

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Shielding[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Arcology Shielding[COLOR_REVERT] and the [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Aquatic Forcefield[COLOR_REVERT] improvement.
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]bouclier[COLOR_REVERT] permet la construction d'un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]bouclier d'arcologie[COLOR_REVERT] et d'un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]champ de force aquatique[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Ship Building
TEXT.French: Fabrication de bâteaux
TEXT.Polish: Szkutnictwo

TEXT.English: [TAB]Ship Building describes a set of technologies which allowed the construction of the great seafaring vessels of the Age of Exploration. [PARAGRAPH:2]The invention of the stern rudder in the 12th century, plus the developments made in sailing during the Crusades (11th-13th centuries), allowed the use of sails to almost completely supercede the use of oars. Along with the invention of the compass (14th century), this made exploration across the oceans viable and led to rapid advances in the development of sailing ships.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Okrêtownictwo to gaôáé przemysôu i dziedzina nauki zajmujáca siê projektowaniem, budowá i remontami jednostek pôywajácych. Jako nauka zawiera przedmioty studiów mechanicznych oraz inne, zwiázane ze specyfiká zawodu, np. technologiê budowy, teoriê okrêtu, napêdy okrêtowe, konstrukcjê i projektowanie okrêtu, a takëe elementy nawigacji, budowy portów, handlu morskiego.W Polsce okrêtownictwo nauczane jest na dwóch wyëszych uczelniach: Politechnice Gdañskiej i Politechnice Szczeciñskiej, a takëe w liceach i technikach budowy okrêtów.

TEXT.English: "I must go down to the sea again, to the lonely sea and the sky; and all I ask is a tall ship and a star to steer her by." - John Masefield
TEXT.French: "Je dois prendre à la mer à nouveau, à la mer solitaire et le ciel, et tout ce que je demande, c'est un grand voilier et une étoile pour me guider." - John Masefield
TEXT.Polish: "Nie nalezy ani okretu przytwierdzac do jednej kotwicy, ani zycia opierac na jednej nadziei." - Epikur

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Ship Building[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to construct [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Triremes[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Siege Quinquiremes[COLOR_REVERT] and build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Shipyards[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]construction de bateaux[COLOR_REVERT] permet de construire des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]trirèmes[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]quinquérèmes de siège[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]cales sèches[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Siege Warfare
TEXT.French: Guerre de siège
TEXT.Polish: Machiny Oblêënicze

TEXT.English: [TAB]Generally speaking, siege warfare is a form of constant, low intensity conflict characterized by one party holding a strong, static defensive position. Consequently, an opportunity for negotiation between combatants is not uncommon, as proximity and fluctuating advantage can encourage diplomacy. A siege occurs when an attacker encounters a city or fortress that cannot be easily taken by a coup de main and refuses to surrender. Sieges involve surrounding the target and blocking the reinforcement or escape of troops or provision of supplies typically coupled with attempts to reduce the fortifications by means of siege engines, artillery bombardment, mining (also known as sapping), or the use of deception or treachery to bypass defenses. Failing a military outcome, sieges can often be decided by starvation, thirst or disease, which can afflict either the attacker or defender. [PARAGRAPH:2]Sieges probably predate the development of cities as large population centers. Ancient cities in the Middle East show archaeological evidence of having had fortified city walls. During the Warring States era of ancient China, there is both textual and archaeological evidence of prolonged sieges and siege machinery used against the defenders of city walls. Siege machinery was also a tradition of the ancient Greco-Roman world. During the Renaissance and the Early Modern period, siege warfare dominated the conduct of war in Europe. Leonardo da Vinci gained as much of his renown from the design of fortifications as from his artwork. [PARAGRAPH:2]Medieval campaigns were generally designed around a succession of sieges. In the Napoleonic era, increasing use of ever more powerful cannon reduced the value of fortifications. In modern times, trenches replaced walls, and bunkers replaced castles. In the 20th century, the significance of the classical siege declined. With the advent of mobile warfare, a single fortified stronghold is no longer as decisive as it once was. While traditional sieges do still occur, they are not as common as they once were due to changes in modes of battle, principally the ease by which huge volumes of destructive power can be directed onto a static target. Modern sieges are more commonly the result of smaller hostage, militant, or extreme resisting-arrest situations such as the Waco Siege.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]W notatnikach Leonarda znajduje siê szereg maszyn wojennych, m.in. czoôg który miotaô maôymi kamieniami, wprawiany w ruch przez dwóch mêëczyzn napêdzajácych waô korbowy. Pomimo tego, ëe rysunek wygládaô na caôkiem skoñczony, mechanika najwyraéniej nie byôa do koñca rozwiniêta. Model zbudowany wedôug projektu z 1484 mógô zaledwie z duëym wysiôkiem obracaâ siê w miejscu, ale nigdy nie poruszaô siê prosto. W filmie dokumentalnym BBC, druëyna wojskowych zbudowaôa tê maszynê. Okazaôo siê, ëe do prawidôowego dziaôania naleëy zmieniâ jeden z mechanizmów. Uwaëa siê, ëe da Vinci zostawiô ten bôád celowo, aby zapobiec wykorzystaniu tego projektu przez ludzi nieuprawnionych[1].

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Now even the American command is under siege. We are hitting it from the north, east, south and west. We chase them here and they chase us there. But at the end we are the people who are laying siege to them. And it is not them who are besieging us." - Mohammed Saeed al-Sahaf
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Maintenant, même le commandement américain est en état de siège. Nous les frappons du nord, de l'est, du sud et de l'ouest. Nous les chassons ici et ils nous chassent là-bas. Mais à la fin nous sommes ceux qui tiennent le siège. Et ce n'est pas eux qui nous assiège." - Mohammed Saeed al-Sahaf
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Szykuj broñ w czasie pokoju, wojna zawsze zaskakuje." - Anonim

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Siege Warfare[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to train [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Pikemen[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Catapults[COLOR_REVERT], and [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Siege Rams[COLOR_REVERT] and increases the strength of [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]War Elephants[COLOR_REVERT]. It also allows you to build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]High Walls[COLOR_REVERT] and [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]City Gatehouse[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]guerre de siège[COLOR_REVERT] permet la construction de [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]catapultes[COLOR_REVERT], de [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]piquies[COLOR_REVERT] et de [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]béliers de siège[COLOR_REVERT] et augmente la puissance des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]éléphants de siège[COLOR_REVERT]. Cela permet de construire des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]hauts remparts[COLOR_REVERT] et un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]corps de garde[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Skyroads
TEXT.French: Routes aériennes
TEXT.Polish: Korytarze Powietrzne

TEXT.English: [TAB]With the invention of flying cars and computer controlled vehicles the sky roads were the next step in 21st century vehicle revolution. Sky roads or sky highways rendered normal roads obsolete and in many cases city streets were demolished and turned into green parks.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Korytarze powietrzne to drogi lotnicze, wydzielone z przestrzeni powietrznej jako obszar przeznaczony do lotu statków powietrznych, w którym obowiázujá specjalne warunki lotu. Ôáczácy dwa punkty. Szerokoäâ korytarza powietrznego krajowego wynosi 10 NM, miêdzynarodowego 20 NM, podstawa dolna minimum 900 m, górna do 12 km.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"In the sky, there is no distinction of east and west; people create distinctions out of their own minds and then believe them to be true." - Buddha (563 - 483 BC)
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Dans le ciel, il n'ya pas de distinction entre Orient et Occident; les gens créént des distinctions de leur propre esprit et puis les prennent pour des vérités." - Buddha (563 - 483 BC)
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Droga do gwiazd nie jest ôatwa z ziemi." Seneka Môodszy

TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]routes aériennes[COLOR_REVERT] permettent de construire des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]chars tout-terrain[COLOR_REVERT] et des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]hélicoptères hybrides[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Slavery
TEXT.Polish: Niewolnictwo

TEXT.English: [TAB]Slavery is an institution based on a relationship of dominance and submission, whereby one person owns another and can exact from that person labor or other services. Slavery has been found among many groups of low material culture, as in the Malay Peninsula and among some Native Americans; it also has occurred in more highly developed societies, such as the southern United States.[PARAGRAPH:2]Although it is commonly held that slavery was rare among primitive pastoral peoples and that it appeared in full form only with the development of an agricultural economy, there are numerous instances that contradict this belief. Domestic slavery and sometimes concubine slavery appeared among the nomadic Arabs, among Native Americans primarily devoted to hunting, and among the seafaring Vikings. Some ascribe the beginnings of slavery to war and the consequent subjection of one group by another. Slavery as a result of debt, however, existed in very early times, and some African peoples have had the custom of putting up wives and children as hostages for an obligation; if the obligation was unfulfilled, the hostages became permanent slaves.[PARAGRAPH:2]The institution of slavery extends back beyond recorded history. References to it appear in the ancient Babylonian code of Hammurabi. Its form and nature varied greatly in ancient society. It seems to have been common in the Tigris-Euphrates civilizations and in ancient Persia. In ancient Egypt slave labor was used in building temples and pyramids. The institution was familiar to the ancient Hebrews, according to passages in the Bible. [PARAGRAPH:2]Slavery was an established institution in the Greece of Homer's time, and a large portion of the population of the Greek city-states in later days were of the servile class. There were domestic slaves, agricultural slaves, and artisans and workers. In Greece, although not quite as commonly as in Asia Minor, there were also public slaves, for example, those belonging to the temples. In general it is thought that slaves in the Greek city-states were relatively well treated, and there were laws protecting them against excessive cruelty or abuse. However, the slaves were regarded as property and had no rights in courts of law. Slaves could obtain their freedom by buying it, by being granted it in the owner's will, or as a reward for outstanding service.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Zjawisko spoôeczne, którego istotá jest stosunek zaleënoäci, polegajácy na tym, ië pewna grupa ludzi (niewolnicy) stanowi przedmiot wôasnoäci innych osób, grup ludzi (rodzina, plemiê itd.), lub instytucji (pañstwo, äwiátynia itp.), którzy mogá nimi swobodnie rozporzádzaâ. Niewolnictwo oznaczaâ moëe sytuacjá faktyczná lub prawná. W ujêciu prawnym jest ono instytucjá, sprowadzajácá siê do tego, ië niewolnik w äwietle prawa jest rzeczá, tj. przedmiotem praw rzeczowych innej osoby, i zgodnie z prawem moëe byâ zbywany, kupowany, uëyczany (poëyczany), darowany, zastawiany itd. W czasach obecnych, gdy niewolnictwo zostaôo zakazane we wszystkich prawodawstwach äwiata, niewolnictwo sprowadza siê do stanu, w którym niewolnik faktycznie znajduje siê w sytuacji przedmiotu, stanowiácego czyjáä wôasnoäâ, jednak ten stan rzeczy nie jest chroniony prawem, a wrêcz stanowi przestêpstwo.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Whenever I hear anyone arguing for slavery, I feel a strong impulse to see it tried on him personally." - Abraham Lincoln

TEXT.English: Smart Drugs
TEXT.French: Drogues intelligentes
TEXT.Polish: Inteligentne Leki

TEXT.English: [TAB]Smart drugs, also referred to as nootropics, memory enhancers, and cognitive enhancers, are drugs, nutraceuticals, brain food and functional foods that are purported to improve human cognitive abilities.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Leki nootropowe (ATC N06) - zróënicowana pod wzglêdem budowy chemicznej oraz mechanizmów dziaôania grupa leków, których cechá wspólná jest stymulowanie przemiany materii oärodkowego ukôadu nerwowego, co ma dawaâ w efekcie aktywizacjê takich procesów psychicznych jak poziom äwiadomoäci, zjawiska pamiêciowe. Leki nootropowe wolne sá od dziaôania typu amfetaminowego (wpôyw euforyzujácy, hamujácy apetyt). Do leków nootropowych naleëá: piracetam, centrofenoksyna, pirytynol, deanol oraz alfosceran choliny. Wskazaniami do podawania leków nootropowych sá zaburzenia äwiadomoäci pochodzenia metabolicznego, zespoôy organiczne, zatrucia, stany rekonwalescencji po przebytych urazach gôowy lub stanach zapalnych oärodkowego ukôadu nerwowego, upoäledzenie umysôowe.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"Half of the modern drugs could well be thrown out of the window, except that the birds might eat them." - Martin H. Fischer
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"La moitié des médicaments modernes pourraient bien être jeté par la fenêtre, sauf que les oiseaux pourraient les manger." - Martin H. Fischer
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]Nic lepiej nie maluje naszego upadku, nië widok apteki: wszelkie moëliwe leki na kaëdá naszá chorobê, ale ëadnego na owá jedyná, zasadniczá chorobê, z której ëaden ludzki wynalazek nie moëe nas uleczyâ." - Emil Cioran

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Smart Drugs[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to build the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Research Hospital[COLOR_REVERT] to provide [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Smart Medicine[COLOR_REVERT] resources. It also increases the gold production of [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Pharmacies[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]drogues intelligentes[COLOR_REVERT] permettent de construire un [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]hôpital de recherche[COLOR_REVERT] pour procurer la ressource [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]médecine intelligente[COLOR_REVERT]. Cela augmente le revenu des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]pharmacies[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Smart Dust
TEXT.French: Déchets intelligents
TEXT.Polish: Inteligentne Czásteczki

TEXT.English: [TAB]Smartdust is a network of tiny wireless microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) sensors, robots, or devices, installed with wireless communications, that can detect (for example) light, temperature, or vibration. The devices, or motes, are intended to be the size of a grain of sand, or even a dust particle. When clustered together, they would automatically create highly flexible, low-power networks with applications ranging from climate control systems to entertainment devices that interact with information appliances. A typical application scenario is scattering a hundred of these sensors around a building or around a hospital to monitor temperature or humidity, track patient movements, or inform of disasters, such as earthquakes. In the military, they can perform as a remote sensor chip to track enemy movements, detect poisonous gas or radioactivity.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Zintegrowane systemy o bardzo niskim poborze mocy zawierajáce: 1. Ukôad obliczeniowy 2. Ukôad komunikacji bezprzewodowej 3. Ukôad (ukôady) do interakcji z otoczeniem (czujniki, elementy mechaniczne)

TEXT.English: [SPACE]"But those concerns won't slow this storm. A Dust Age is upon us." - Matthew Boyle
TEXT.French: [SPACE]"Mais ces préoccupations ne vont pas ralentir cette tempête. Un âge de poussière est à nos portes." - Matthew Boyle
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Cóë za smutna epoka, w której ôatwiej jest rozbiâ atom nië zniszczyâ przesád." - Albert Einstein

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Smart Dust[COLOR_REVERT] enables you to build [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Nanite Spies[COLOR_REVERT] and the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Nanite Defuser[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Les [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]déchets intelligents[COLOR_REVERT] permettent les [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]espions nanites[COLOR_REVERT] et les [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]diffuseurs nanites[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Smithing
TEXT.French: Maréchal-ferrant
TEXT.Polish: Kowalstwo

TEXT.English: [TAB]A blacksmith is a person who creates objects from iron or steel by forging the metal; i.e., by using tools to hammer, bend, and cut. Blacksmiths produce things like wrought iron gates, grills, railings, light fixtures, furniture, sculpture, tools, agricultural implements, decorative and religious items, cooking utensils, horse shoes and weapons. Blacksmiths work with "black" metals, typically iron. The black color comes from fire scale, a layer of oxides that forms on the surface of the metal during heating. The term 'smith' originates from the word 'smite', which means 'to hit'. Thus, a blacksmith is a person who smites black metal. Blacksmiths work by heating pieces of wrought iron or steel until the metal becomes soft enough to be shaped with hand tools, such as a hammer, anvil and chisel. Heating is accomplished by the use of a forge fueled by propane, natural gas, coal, charcoal, or coke.
TEXT.Polish: [TAB]Kowalstwo - rzemiosôo wykonywane przez kowala, przy uëyciu narzêdzi kowalskich. Polega na ksztaôtowaniu metali. Miejsce pracy kowala nazywane jest kuéniá.

TEXT.English: [SPACE]In a blacksmith's house all knives are wooden -Spanish Proverb
TEXT.French: [SPACE]Dans la maison d'un forgeron tous les couteaux sont en bois - Proverbe Espagnol
TEXT.Polish: [SPACE]"Dobry kowal nie uderzy siê w palce." - przysôowie tuwiñskie

TEXT.English: [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]Smithing[COLOR_REVERT] allows you to train [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Swordsmen[COLOR_REVERT] and build [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Armourers[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_TECH_TEXT]maréchal-ferrant[COLOR_REVERT] permet de recruter des [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]spadassins[COLOR_REVERT] et de construire des [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]armureries[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Social Contract
TEXT.French: Contrat social
TEXT.Polish: Umowa Spoôeczna

TEXT.English: [TAB]Social contract, agreement or covenant by which men are said to have abandoned the "state of nature" to form the society in which they now live. The theory of such a contract, first formulated by the English philosophers Thomas Hobbes (in the Leviathan, 1651) and John Locke, assumes that men at first lived in a state of anarchy in which there was no society, no government, and no organized coercion of the individual by the group. Hobbes maintained that by the social contract men had surrendered their natural liberties in order to enjoy the order and safety of the organized state. Locke made the social contract the basis of his advocacy of popular sovereignty, the idea that the monarch or government must reflect the will of the people. Like Locke, the French philosopher Jean Jacques Rousseau, in Le Contrat social (1762), found the general will a means of establishing reciprocal rights and duties, privileges, and responsibilities as a basis of the state. Similar ideas were used as a justification for both the American and the French revolutions in the 18th cent.
